questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with painful swelling in the middle finger around the proximal phalanx. X-ray shows the presence of a radiolucent nodule of cartilage with central calcification as seen in the image below. The growth has heterozygous mutations in the IDH1 and IDH2 genes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is enchondroma.

Enchondromas are intraosseous benign, lobulated tumours of hyaline cartilage. They are usually solitary, central, metaphyseal lesions of tubular bones, which usually affect the small bones of the hand and feet followed by the femur and humerus. Enchondromatous tumours typically begin and grow in childhood arising from rests of growth plate cartilage or chondrocytes that proliferate and enlarge, then stop growing but remain present throughout adulthood. Enchondromas can transform into chondrosarcoma. 

They are associated with mutations in isocitrate dehydrogenase-1 (IDH1) and 2 (IDH2) genes. Isocitrate dehydrogenase is an enzymatic component of the Krebs cycle which helps to convert isocitrate to alpha-ketoglutarate. Mutations in IDH1 and IDH2 result in the alteration of the enzyme function and in increased levels of D-2-hydroxyglutarate (D-2-HG.). This elevation in D-2-HG results in inhibition of the osteogenic differentiation of mesenchymal stem cells; blocking osteogenic differentiation during the formation of the skeleton results in cartilaginous tumor formation.

Microscopically, enchondromas appear as grey-blue, translucent, hypocellular, non-vascular tumors with abundant hyaline cartilage. The nuclei of these cells are regular with few mitotic figures.

Diagnosis of enchondromas requires histopathologic examination, which shows punctate calcifications of the chondroid matrix and is composed of well-circumscribed nodules of benign hyaline cartilage. The nuclei of the chondrocytes are small and uniformly round with condensed chromatin.

Other options:

Option A: Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignancy of bone that produces osteoid matrix or mineralized bone. It has a bimodal age distribution. It is typically seen in the metaphyseal regions of the distal femur and proximal tibia. RB mutations are common and there is also the inactivation of CDKN2A, a tumor suppressor gene in many cases.

X-ray shows periosteal reaction and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance as shown below.


Option B: Ewing's sarcoma is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after osteosarcoma. It usually occurs at the younger age group and commonly involves the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, and humerus. Most tumours have a balanced (11;22) (q24;q12) translocation generating in-frame fusion of the EWSRI gene on chromosome 22 to the FL1 gene on chromosome 11. 

Onion-peel appearance due to deposition of periosteal reaction in layers is seen on radiology (as shown below) and Homer-Wright rosettes, which are round groupings of cells with a central fibrillary core may be seen histologically.


Option C: Osteoclastoma is also called a giant cell tumour because multinucleated osteoclast-type giant cells are present on histology. It exclusively affects adults and affects the epiphysis of long bones, commonly in the distal end of the femur followed by the proximal tibia. The neoplastic cells express high levels of RANKL which promotes the proliferation and differentiation of normal osteoclast precursors into osteoclasts.

The image below shows an X-ray of a giant cell tumor showing an eccentrically located solitary lytic lesion in the epiphysis and the typical soap bubble appearance

questions.text:
A 20-year-old female patient presents with petechiae and one episode of epistaxis. She gives a history of an upper respiratory tract infection 3 weeks ago. Her lab reports are given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?

Hemoglobin: 14 g/dL

Platelet count: 12,000 cells/μL
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient developing petechiae and one episode of epistaxis following upper respiratory tract infection, and lab reports showing a platelet count of 12,000/μL are suggestive of immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). Since this patient has had only one episode of epistaxis and her hemoglobin is normal, the most appropriate management for this patient would be prednisolone.

In patients without significant bleeding and without severe thrombocytopenia (platelet count < 5000 cells/μL), the initial treatment is with glucocorticoids such as prednisolone or dexamethasone.

If the patient has severe bleeding or severe thrombocytopenia, IVIg and glucocorticoids are used in conjunction. Anti-D is used as an alternative to IVIg, but is not preferred because of the risk of severe hemolytic reactions. Platelet transfusions (option B) are reserved for patients in whom there is a need to immediately raise the platelet counts. 

The decision to start treatment in a patient who is incidentally diagnosed and doesn't have any bleeding manifestations is based on the platelet count. Treatment is usually started for these patients if the platelet count is < 30,000 cells/μL.

Splenectomy (option C) has been used previously for patients who relapse after glucocorticoid therapy, but is now a reserved treatment option. In most adult patients, ITP resolves spontaneously, and so it is reasonable to observe the patient with intermittent treatment with IVIg before surgery is considered.

Other drugs which are used in the treatment of ITP include anti-CD20 antibody rituximab, and thrombopoietin (TPO) receptor agonists such as romiplostim and eltrombopag.  

Related Pearl: Idiopathic/Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)

It is characterized by

  • Isolated thrombocytopenia—the presence of antibody against platelet membrane glycoprotein and subsequent destruction in reticuloendothelial system
  • Normal bone marrow—normal or even increased number of megakaryocytes
  • Absence of other causes of thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man was on crutches for a few months after a road traffic accident. After the initial 2 weeks, he complained of an inability to extend his wrist. He achieved complete recovery a few weeks later. What is the mechanism behind this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
This is a case of, crutch palsy which is a type of neuropraxia. 

Neurapraxia is a reversible physiological block in nerve conduction. Some types of sensation and muscle power are lost in neuropraxia. The structure of the nerve is not changed and there is complete, spontaneous recovery after a few weeks. Neurapraxia occurs due to the segmental demyelination by mechanical pressure. 

Crutch palsy occurs when the radial nerve is compressed in the arm from direct pressure against a firm object (crutch). Other examples of neuropraxia include Saturday night palsy and tourniquet palsy.

Other options:

Option A- Neurotmesis occurs due to the damage in both axon and nerve by complete section or scarring of a segment in open fractures. A surgical nerve repair is required since spontaneous recovery doesn't take place.

Option B- Axonotmesis occurs due to the damage of axons with preservation of the internal architecture of the nerve. It is seen typically after closed fractures and dislocations. Spontaneous recovery can occur but may take a long time.

Option C- Neurolysis is the surgical removal of fibrotic tissue inside a nerve trunk.

Related Pearl: Seddon's classification of nerve injuries

Seddon's classification includes 3 groups:

  1. Neuropraxia
  2. Axonotmesis
  3. Neurotmesis

Neuropraxia:

  • Reversible physiologic conduction block
  • Occurs due to mechanical pressure causing segmental demyelination
  • Examples: Saturday night palsy, tourniquet, and crutch palsy

Axonotmesis: 

  • Axonal interruption
  • Conduction is lost but the nerve is in continuity and neural tubes are intact
  • Examples: Closed fractures and dislocations

Neurotmesis: 

  • Division of the nerve trunk
  • Endoneurial tube destruction also occurs
  • Example: Complete section of nerve in open fractures

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain, shortness of breath, and vomiting for a few hours. She is on ovulation induction therapy for infertility. The sonogram of both her ovaries is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the sonogram showing enlarged ovaries meeting in the midline having large cysts are suggestive of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome. 

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is characterized by mul­tiple ovarian follicular cysts accompanied by increased capillary permeability. It happens most often as a complication of ovulation­ induction therapy for infertility. It occurs due to the stimulation of vascular endo­thelial growth factor (VEGF) expression in granulosa-lutein cells by hCG.

They often present with shortness of breath, abdominal pain, and gastrointestinal disturbances like nausea, vomiting, and oliguria.

Abdominal pain occurs due to ovarian enlargement and accumulation of peritoneal fluid. Increased vascular permeability and loss of fluid, protein, and electrolytes into the peritoneal cavity cause ascites and result in hemoconcentration. Hemoconcentartion causes hyperviscosity and leads to hypercoagulability.  

Hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, leukocytosis, pleural effusion, and pericardial effusion can be associated with OHSS. 

Some of the risk factors for OHSS:

  • Polycystic ovarian syndrome
  • Young age
  • High estradiol during ovulation induction
  • Pregnancy

Classification of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome

Grade I Abdominal discomfort or distension
Grade II

Abdominal discomfort or distension + nausea and vomiting or diarrhea+ Enlarged ovaries (5-12 cm)
Grade III Ultrasonographic evidence of ascites
Grade IV Clinical evidence of ascites/hydrothorax/breathing difficulty
Grade V All of the above with decreased blood volume, hemoconcentration, diminished renal perfusion and function, and coagulation abnormalities. 

This condition can be prevented by

  • Withholding hCG in a cycle if there are more than 20 follicles on ultrasound and E2 level rises to 3000 pg/ mL.
  • Albumin 5% infusion in 500 mL lactated Ringer’s solution during and after oocyte retrieval
  • Dopamine agonist cabergoline 0.5 mg daily for 8 days starting on day 1 of hCG.

OHSS is primarily managed with general supportive care. Paracentesis is performed to ameliorate abdominal discomfort and relieve respiratory discomfort.

Other options:

Option B- Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) is the most common endocrine disorder of the reproductive age group. Patients with PCOS present with menstrual irregularities, hirsutism, acne, infertility, etc.

Sonographic criteria for PCOS include:

  • >/= 20 small cysts ( 2 to 9 mm diameter) or,
  • Increased ovarian volume (>10 mL), or both

The ultrasound examination image shown below is of PCOS showing enlarged ovaries with multiple cysts. 


Option C- Hyperreactio luteinalis is a condition in which one or both ovaries develop multiple large theca lutein cysts. They typically occur after the first trimester due to luteinization of the follicular theca luteal layer in response to exceptionally high HCG. They are commonly seen in:

  • Gestational trophoblastic disease
  • Multiple gestational preganancy
  • Fetal hydrops
  • Placentaomegaly

Ultrasonography shows a "spoke wheel pattern". Most of them resolve spontaneously after delivery. Surgical management is only required if it is complicated by torsion or hemorrhage. 

The below image shows bilaterally enlarged ovaries with multiple theca luteal cysts as in hyperreactio luteinalis.

 


Option D- Hematometra is a condition in which menstrual outflow obstruction traps the blood and distends the uterus. Depending on the level of genital blockage, blood can distend:

  • Vagina called hematocolpos
  • Uterus called hematometra
  • Fallopian tubes called hematosalpinx

Patients usually present with cyclic midline pain, low backache, amenorrhea, and pelvic fullness. A large uterus can compress the urinary bladder, and rectum causing urinary retention and constipation. blood may get infected and lead to pyometra causing fever and leukocytosis.

Ultrasonography is the diagnostic tool that shows a smooth, symmetric hypoechoic enlargement of the uterine cavity. Relieving the obstruction and evacuation of blood is the primary management.

The below ultrasonographic image shows a smooth, symmetric hypoechoic enlargement of the uterine cavity suggestive of hematometra.

questions.text: An elderly man who is a known case of hypertension and uncontrolled diabetes mellitus presents with decreased urine output and facial puffiness. His estimated glomerular filtration rate was 20 mL/min/1.73 sq. m. According to the KDIGO classification, what is the stage of his chronic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
According to the KDIGO classification, the stage of this patient's chronic kidney disease (CKD) is G4.

CKD is a spectrum of pathophysiological processes resulting in abnormal kidney function, with a progressive decline in glomerular filtration rate (GFR). According to the Kidney Disease Improving Global Outcome (KDIGO) classification, CKD can be stratified using both GFR and albuminuria to predict the risk of progression of CKD:

Stages of CKD based on GFR (mL/min/1.73 sq.m):

Stage GFR  Description
G1 ≥90 Normal or high
G2 60-89 Mildly decreased
G3a 45-59

Mildly to moderately decreased
G3b 30-44 Moderately to severely decreased
G4 15-29 Severely decreased
G5 <15 Kidney failure

Stages of CKD based on albuminuria (mg/g):

Stage Albuminuria Description
A1 <30 Normal to mildly increased
A2 30-300 Moderately increased
A3 >300 Severely increased

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient who is on medication for benign prostatic hyperplasia was posted for cataract surgery. Intraoperatively, the surgeon noticed a floppy iris with progressive intraoperative pupillary constriction. Which of the following is the most likely drug responsible for the above features?
questions.solution:
The most likely drug responsible for the above features is tamsulosin.

The above clinical scenario with a history of medication for benign prostatic hyperplasia and the intraoperative finding of floppy iris with progressive pupillary constriction is suggestive of floppy iris syndrome. The causative drug for floppy iris syndrome is tamsulosin.

Tamsulosin is an α1 receptor antagonist with receptor selectivity at α1A and α1D receptors. This selectivity causes blockade of the α1A receptor in the prostate. It is used in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia. It has very little effect on blood pressure due to its selective effect on α1A and α1D and hence is not used in the treatment of hypertension.

Some of the adverse effects of tamsulosin include orthostatic hypotension, abnormal ejaculation, and floppy iris syndrome characterized by the intraoperative finding of floppy iris, the propensity of iris prolapse, progressive pupillary constriction.

Examples of other drugs causing floppy iris syndrome include finasteride, benzodiazepines, donepezil, duloxetine. Some α1 receptor antagonists like alfuzosin, doxazosin, and terazosin are associated with floppy iris syndrome but have a very low risk compared to tamsulosin.

Other options:

Option B- Prazosin is an α1 receptor antagonist with equal potency to all the subtypes of α1 receptor. It is used in the treatment of hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia(BPH). Prazosin causes orthostatic hypotension after its initial dose.

Option C- Silodosin is an α1 receptor antagonist with more selectivity over the α1 subtype. It is approved in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia with lesser effects on blood pressure. The main adverse effect is retrograde ejaculation. Dizziness and orthostatic hypotension can also be seen.

Option D- Dutasteride is a 5α-reductase inhibitor that blocks the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone. It is approved in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia. Impotence is a documented side effect and gynecomastia is a rare side effect.

Related Pearl: Drugs acting on the receptors of autonomic nervous system

questions.text: A forensic pathologist is examining a venous specimen to look for the presence of antemortem clots. Microscopy reveals laminations with alternating light and dark bands. What are these laminations called?
questions.solution:
The laminations in the thrombus are called lines of Zahn.

Lines of Zahn are characteristic of thrombi that appear in blood vessels, very commonly in veins. These laminations or striae can be seen either macroscopically, in large vessels, or microscopically in smaller ones, as they form alternating light and dark bands. The light bands are composed of platelets and fibrin while the darker bands are referred to as red-cell-rich because they are composed of erythrocytes.

The presence of lines of Zahn helps to distinguish between antemortem and postmortem clots. They are present in antemortem clots as they are formed in the flowing blood.

Postmortem clots are usually bland and nonlaminated clots. They are gelatinous and have a lower dark red portion which is erythrocyte rich, formed as a result of gravitation of these erythrocytes and a yellow "chicken fat"  upper portion, that is not attached to the vessel wall.

The following image shows the lines of Zahn.

Other options:

Option A: Psammoma bodies are foci of dystrophic calcification. Necrotic cells form the focus for surrounding calcific deposition. They have a lamellated concentric calcified structure. Psammoma bodies are found in various tumors such as papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, meningioma, and serous cystadenoma of the ovary.

Option B: Hemosiderin is a hemoglobin-derived, yellowish-brown granular or crystalline pigment. In the body, iron is stored along with apoferritin to form ferritin micelles. However, when there is excessive iron present, ferritin forms hemosiderin granules, which may be observed in the mononuclear phagocytes of bone marrow, spleen, and liver.

The image below shows hemosiderin pigment within the alveolar macrophages in the lung.

Option D: Lipofuscin granules are insoluble brownish-yellow granular intracellular materials that are representative of complexes of lipid and protein, produced by polyunsaturated lipids which undergo free radical–catalyzed peroxidation. They accumulate in many tissues like the heart, liver, and brain, and are seen with aging or atrophy. It is indicative of past free radical injury. If the brown pigment is present in large amounts, it gives an appearance to the tissue called "brown atrophy".

The image below shows cardiac myocytes with lipofuscin granules in the perinuclear region.

Blood flow Associated with active blood flow Associated with sluggish blood flow
Sites Coronary, cerebral and femoral arteries Superficial and deep leg veins, ovarian periuterine veins
Propagation Grows in a retrograde manner from point of attachment Grows in an antegrade manner from point of attachment

questions.text: An infant had non-bilious projectile vomiting immediately after feeding, and an olive-shaped mass per abdomen. Sonography was done. All of the following features can be seen in this condition, except _______.
questions.solution:
An infant with non-bilious, projectile vomiting and an olive-shaped mass per abdomen is likely to have congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. On sonography, all of the following can be seen in this condition, except a shortened pyloric canal. The pyloric canal appears elongated with thickened and hypoechoic pyloric muscle.

Ultrasound has high sensitivity and specificity. It is the investigation of choice and confirms the diagnosis for most cases of suspected hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. Other sonographic findings include:

  • Hypoechoic thickened pyloric muscle with a hyperechoic central mucosa - Target sign
  • Hypertrophied pylorus resembles the uterine cervix - Cervix sign
  • Hypertrophic muscle bulging into the antrum of a fluid-filled stomach- Shoulder sign
  • Redundant pyloric mucosa protrudes into the antrum- Antral nipple sign 
  • Abnormal, exaggerated peristaltic waves 
  • Pyloric thickness is 3-4 mm, and pyloric length is 15-19 mm

The image below shows a sonographic image of pyloric stenosis showing the antral sign and the cervix sign.

 

Findings on Barium studies:

  • Elongated pyloric channel - String sign
  • Bulging of the pyloric muscle into the antrum - Shoulder sign
  • Parallel streaks of barium in a thin lumen - Double tract sign

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) most commonly presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. The vomiting is usually progressive and occurs immediately after a feed. As vomiting progresses, loss of fluid, hydrogen ions and chloride ions leads to hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis.

On examination, an olive-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium. When the infant is given a test feed, visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from across the abdomen, followed by projectile vomiting.

Management involves correcting the fluid, acid-base, and electrolyte losses initially. It is then treated surgically by performing a pyloromyotomy.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with complaints of shortness of breath for 6 months. On examination, he has a hyperdynamic apical impulse with wide pulse pressure and a diastolic murmur in the second intercostal space on the left sternal border. The systolic blood pressure of the lower limb exceeds that of the upper limb by 24 mmHg. Which among the following is the above-mentioned sign?
questions.solution:
In this patient, shortness of breath along with examination findings of wide pulse pressure, hyperdynamic apical impulse, and diastolic murmur in the second intercostal space on the left sternal border points toward a diagnosis of aortic regurgitation. In aortic regurgitation (AR), if the systolic blood pressure of the lower limb exceeds that of the upper limb at least by 20 mmHg, the sign is called Hill's sign.

Normally, the systolic blood pressure in the lower limb is 10-20 mm higher than the upper limb pressure. The increased blood pressure is due to the summation of reflected pressure waves. In aortic regurgitation, the systolic blood pressure in the lower limb is more than 20 mmHg higher than the systolic blood pressure in the upper limb.  

Further, there are a number of other signs seen in aortic regurgitation.

Other peripheral signs seen in AR:

  • de Musset's sign is the head bobbing with each arterial pulsation
  • Corrigan's sign is the rapidly rising water hammer pulse, which collapses quickly as arterial pressure falls rapidly during late systole and diastole
  • Traube's sign is the booming pistol shot sound over femoral arteries.

The total stroke volume ejected by the left ventricle is increased in aortic regurgitation. It is the sum of the effective forward stroke volume and the volume of blood that regurgitates back into the left ventricle. This occurs due to valve leaflets or primary aortic root disease. AR results in left ventricular (LV) volume overload. This increase in LV end-diastolic volume causes dilatation and eccentric hypertrophy of the LV. Over time, these adaptive measures fail, which leads to a further rise in the end-diastolic volume, and the forward stroke volume and ejection fraction (EF) decline.

LV decompensation results in decreased compliance and increased LV end-diastolic volume and pressure. The increase in LV mass leads to increased myocardial oxygen requirements and reduced coronary perfusion pressure. This results in exertional chest pain.

A high-pitched, blowing, decrescendo diastolic murmur, heard best in the third intercostal space along the left sternal border can be auscultated in aortic regurgitation. It is best heard when the patient leans forward with breath held in forced expiration. The below image shows auscultatory findings in aortic regurgitation.

questions.text: During your rural posting in a remote village, you were asked to help the community in the construction of a sanitary well. What are the recommended measurements of the marked structures in the image shown below?
questions.solution:
The image shows a sanitary well. 

Marking 1 is the stone wall well which should be at least 6m deep. 
Marking 2 refers to the distance of the well from a human dwelling- 100m. 
Marking 3 is the distance from a possible source of contamination- 15m. 
Marking 4 is the parapet wall, which has to be at least 70-75cm. 

A sanitary well is one that is properly located, well-constructed, and protected against contamination in order to yield a supply of safe water. 

The well should be at least 15m away from a likely source of contamination and located at an elevated area with respect to the possible contaminant zone. The distance between the well and the houses of the users should be less than 100m.

The lining of the well should be built of bricks or stones set in cement up to a depth of at least 6m so that water enters from the bottom and not from the sides of the well. The lining should be carried 60-90cm above the ground level. 

The parapet wall should be up to a height of at least 70-75cms above the ground.

A cement-concrete platform, with a gentle outward slope and a drain, should extend at least 1m in all directions around the well. The pucca drain carries off spilled water to a public drain or a soakage pit.

The top of the well should be closed by a cement-concrete cover to prevent contamination from an open-top. It also improves the bacteriological quality of the water. 

Lifting the water from the well sanitarily requires a hand pump.

Consumer precautions are required at the individual and family level to prevent water-borne diseases. Hand hygiene should be followed. There should be a strict prohibition of washing of clothes, personal ablutions, animal exposure, and dumping of waste. 

Related Pearl: Wells

  • Wells are a source of ground water and are widely used across India.
  • The two main types of wells are the shallow and deep wells, the difference between which are:
  Shallow Wells Deep Wells
Description They tap subsoil water, i.e., water from above the first impervious layer in the ground They tap water from the water-bearing stratum which is below the first impervious layer of the ground
Chemical quality Moderately hard water Very hard water
Contamination Very often grossly contaminated and liable to pollution Low contamination levels and purer than water from shallow wells
Yield Generally dry in summer Provides constant water supply
Prevalence in India Very common Less common than shallow wells
  • An artesian well is a type of deep well in which the water rises to the surface due to the pressure with which it is held between two impervious/impermeable layers. There is no pump or other manual methods needed to bring the water to the surface. These are not common in India.
  • Wells can also be classified according to the method of construction as dug wells and tube wells.

i) Dug wells:

  • They are the most common type of wells in India.
  • In rural India, two types of dug wells exist, namely the unlined katcha wells and the masonry or pucca wells.
  • The katcha wells are just big holes dug into the sand.
  • The pucca wells are well built with walls or linings made of brick or stones.
  • Step wells are types of pucca dug wells that have steps. These steps can be used by people to descend into the well and come in contact with water. This increases the risk of water contamination.

ii) Tube wells:

  • Shallow tube wells are also called driven wells and deep tube wells are called bore wells.
  • They are safer sources of water compared to other wells, relatively cheaper to build and maintain.
  • Tube wells use strainers at the bottom and hand pumps at the top attached by a pipe in between.

The following are the considerations for building a safe and sanitary well:

Location Must be at least 15 m away from sources of contamination. Must not be >100 m from households.
Lining Must be made of brick or stones set in cement to a depth of 6 m, so that water enters from bottom and not sides. Height of lining above ground level must be 60 – 90 cm.
Parapet Wall Must be at least 70 – 75 cm (28 inches) from the ground level.
Platform Should stretch at least 1 m around the well in all directions.
Drain It should be a pucca drain to carry spilled water to a public drain beyond the cone of filtration of the well.
Covering There should be a cement concrete covering over the well.
Hand-pump Should be able to withstand rough handling.
Consumer responsibility Consumers must practice basic precautions before handling the well.
Quality The water standards in terms of quality must be conformed to.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient was recently diagnosed with non-Hodgkin lymphoma and was started on an anticancer drug. After a few days, the patient started passing blood in the urine for which mesna was used as a treatment. Which of the following is responsible for the side effect?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient is suffering from hemorrhagic cystitis as an adverse effect, due to the toxic metabolite of cyclophosphamide called acrolein. This can be decreased by vigorous hydration and by the use of mercaptoethanesulfonate (mesna).

Cyclophosphamide is an alkylating agent that interferes with DNA integrity and function. It induces cell death in rapidly proliferating tissues. It is metabolised by hepatic cytochrome enzyme to form 4-Hydroxycyclophosphamide. The tautomer of 4-Hydroxycyclophosphamide called aldophosphamide cleaves non-enzymatically in the tumor cell to form phosphoramide mustard and acrolein.

Antitumor effects are due to phosphoramide mustard, while acrolein causes hemorrhagic cystitis. Vigorous intravenous hydration should be done in patients with high-dose treatment. Brisk hematuria in a patient receiving daily oral therapy should lead to immediate drug discontinuation.

Cyclophosphamide is an essential component of many effective drug combinations for non-Hodgkin lymphomas, other lymphoid malignancies, breast and ovarian cancers, and solid tumors in children.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male patient presented with quadriparesis for 6 months. Symptoms began as dysarthria and a stiff tongue, lower limb weakness which progressed to all four limbs. Bilateral extensor plantar response, exaggerated reflexes, fasciculations, and severe muscle atrophy are present. Bladder, bowel, and sensory functions are intact. Which of the following is used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and riluzole is used in its treatment.

Progressive upper motor neuron (UMN) palsy (exaggerated reflexes, extensor plantar), lower motor neuron (LMN) palsy (muscle weakness, atrophy, fasciculations), and pseudobulbar palsy (dysarthria, tongue spasticity), with normal bladder, bowel and sensory function are suggestive of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

Treatment:

  1. Riluzole acts by reducing excitotoxicity by diminishing glutamate release. It lengthens the survival of the patient. Side effects are minimal that include nausea, vomiting, dizziness, and elevated liver enzymes occasionally. 
  2. Edaravone (IV infusion) works in the central nervous system as a potent scavenger of oxygen radicals and is a newer drug that has the capability of slowing down ALS progression and improving survival.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is the most common form of progressive motor neuron disease. Genetic mutations in genes encoding cytosolic enzyme SOD1 (superoxide dismutase). The pathologic hallmark of motor neuron degenerative disorders is the death of lower motor neurons (consisting of anterior horn cells in the spinal cord and their brainstem homologs innervating bulbar muscles) and upper, or corticospinal, motor neurons (originating in layer five of the motor cortex and descending via the pyramidal tract to synapse with lower motor neurons, either directly or indirectly via interneurons).

Although at its onset, ALS may involve selective loss of function of only upper or lower motor neurons, it ultimately causes progressive loss of both categories of motor neurons.

Even in the late stages of ALS, sensory, bowel & bladder functions are preserved.

Clinical features:

  • LMN lesion: Fasciculations, muscle cramps, weakness, atrophy, and bulbar palsy
  • UMN lesion: Spasticity, increased reflexes, flexor spasms, and pseudobulbar palsy
  • Another frequent bulbar UMN symptom is the syndrome of the pseudobulbar effect. This is manifested as inappropriate laughing, crying, or yawning. 

Other options:

Option A- Tetrabenazine is a reversible VMAT2 inhibitor that depletes presynaptic catecholamines. It is used for chorea in Huntington's disease. The dosage is adjusted when it is given with CYP2D6 inhibitors like paroxetine, fluoxetine, bupropion as they decrease the metabolism of tetrabenazine. Adverse effects include hypotension and depression. 

Option B- Memantine acts by reducing excitotoxicity through use-dependent blockade of NMDA receptors. It is used in cases of moderate to severe Alzheimer's disease.

Option D- Rivastigmine is a carbamate derivative of physostigmine. It inhibits predominantly acetyl choline esterase enzyme (AChE). It is prescribed in cases of mild-moderate cases of Alzheimer's disease.

questions.text: The hysterosalpingography of a patient with chronic pelvic inflammatory disease shows bilateral fallopian tube blockage. Which of the following organisms has the highest propensity to cause this tube block?
questions.solution:
Chlamydia trachomatis has the highest propensity to cause bilateral fallopian tube blockage.

Chlamydia infection remains asymptomatic in the endocervix and produces minimal symptoms, and therefore the infection goes unnoticed and untreated, but the damage it causes to the fallopian tube is five times higher than Neisseria gonorrhoea.

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is usually a polymicrobial infection. The most common causes of PID are Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. 

Other organisms causing PID are Mycoplasma, E.coli, and anaerobes. PID commonly spreads as ascending infection along with sperms. Genital tuberculosis mostly has a hematogenous spread.

On ultrasound, a tubo-ovarian abscess may be seen which appears as a complex cystic adnexal or cul-de-sac mass with thick irregular walls and septations.

Related Pearl: Organisms Responsible for Pelvic Inflammatory Disease

Sexually transmitted: Gonococcus, Chlamydia, Mycoplasma, Trichomonas 
Aerobes: Staphylococci , Streptococci ,E. coli
Anaerobes: Bacteroides fragilis, Peptococcus, Clostridium, Actinomyces (IUD)
Others: Tubercular salpingitis
 

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient developed severe abdominal pain, vertigo, and convulsions after the consumption of the seeds shown in the image. Which of the following is the toxin present in this seed?
questions.solution:
The seeds shown in the image are those of the Abrus precatorius plant. Abrin is one of the toxic principles of this plant.

Toxic principles of Abrus precatorius:

  • Abrin (a toxalbumen)
  • Abrine (an amino acid)
  • Abralin (a glucoside)

Abrin acts by inhibiting protein synthesis, thereby resulting in cell death. The clinical features after oral ingestion of these seeds include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bloody diarrhea, weakness, cold perspiration, trembling, weak rapid pulse, and miosis. Faintness, vertigo, dyspnea, and convulsions can also occur. If taken by injection, painful swelling, ecchymosis with inflammation, and necrosis are seen at the site of injection.

Medicolegal Importance:

  • It is commonly used as cattle poison in Indian villages by injecting the seed extract into the animal in the form of certain fine needle-shaped structures known as sui (meaning needle in Hindi).
  • These are prepared by mixing the seed extract with opium, datura, and spirit/water and then blended into a paste, shaped into fine needles and dried in the sun, and used to kill cattle by driving it deep into the animal body by blowing through a hollow bamboo pipe.

Other options:

Option A: Ricin is the toxic principle of the Ricinus communis plant. It causes the burning of oral mucosa similar to alkali burn, severe abdominal pain, hemolysis, convulsions, uremia, collapse, and death. 

The image below shows the seeds of Ricinus communis.

Option B- Crotin is the toxic principle of Croton tiglium. They present with hot burning pain from mouth to stomach, salivation, purging, vertigo, prostration, collapse, and death.

The image below shows the seeds of Croton tiglium.

Option D- Capsaicin is the toxic principle of Capsicum annum. Consuming in large doses causes difficulty in swallowing, abdominal pain, and inflammation of the esophagus and stomach.

The image below shows seeds of Capsicum annum.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman has the following flow pattern of umbilical arteries on a doppler. What does this pattern indicate?
questions.solution:
The given flow pattern of umbilical arteries represents an absence of end-diastolic flow (AEDF) in the umbilical arteries.

In case of absent end-diastolic flow (AEDF), the waves just touch the baseline, but do not appear below it. This is associated with intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR). 

Pregnant women having intrauterine growth restriction with AEDF in the umbilical artery are managed expectantly until delivery at 34 weeks. 

Umbilical artery vessels usually have forward flow throughout the cardiac cycle.  As gestation increases, there is a gradual fall in all the placental resistance indices, so the amount of the forward diastolic flow increases and the S/D ratio (systole to diastole ratio) decreases as the period of gestation increases.

Note: Reverse end-diastolic flow has seen an insignificant increase in resistance to blood flow within the placenta. They are managed expectantly until delivery at 32 weeks.

The below image shows various patterns of end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery on Doppler.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents to the ENT OPD with complaints of difficulty in hearing. A pure tone audiometry test is performed and the result is given below. What is the interpretation?
questions.solution:
The given pure tone audiometry is suggestive of right-sided sensorineural deafness.

Interpretation of the result:

  • Red indicates the right ear.
  • O indicates air conduction(AC). The threshold here is >15 dB indicating abnormal AC.
  • < indicates bone conduction(BC). The threshold is >25 dB indicating abnormal BC.
  • Both AC and BC are abnormal which indicates a sensorineural hearing loss.
  • There is no air-bone gap.
  • Hence, it is right side sensorineural hearing loss.

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with complaints of generalized lymphadenopathy and a significant loss of weight for the past 6 months. On further evaluation, he is found to be immunocompromised and having low CD4+ counts. He also tells that he has not taken any medications in the recent past. What is the most common ocular feature of the likely diagnosis seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of HIV (Human immune deficiency virus) infection. Microangiopathy affecting the conjunctiva and retina is the most common ocular feature of HIV infection. It is a non-infectious condition characterized by telangiectasia, segmental dilatation, comma-shaped fragments, and sludging in the smaller blood vessels.

Other opportunistic infections include- 

  • Adnexal lesions such as Kaposi sarcoma, herpes zoster ophthalmicus, pyogenic infections, and molluscum contagiosum
  • Anterior segment changes such as infective keratitis and uveitis
  • Posterior segment changes such as cytomegalovirus retinitis, Pneumocystis carinii choroidopathy, and fungal endophthalmitis
  • neuro-ophthalmic manifestations such as papilledema, optic atrophy, headaches, and nerve palsies. 

Other options-

Option B- Immune recovery uveitis (IRU) is an ocular adverse effect in patients receiving highly active antiretroviral therapy. It is associated with a paradoxical worsening of the treated opportunistic infection or the unmasking of the previously subclinical infection. Visual complications of IRU include cataract, cystoid macular edema (CME), glaucoma, and epiretinal membrane formation.

Option D- Cataracts are lenticular opacities which can be associated with various viral illnesses including herpes simplex virus, congenital rubella infection, and toxoplasmosis.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presented with a 3-month history of painless ulcers over the penis. Physical examination revealed multiple beefy-red, non-tender, round ulcers on the glans of the penis. The base of the ulcers shows granulation tissue that bleeds on the touch. A smear was made from the lesion and stained with Wright- Giemsa stain which showed Donovan bodies. What can be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a patient presenting with multiple beefy red, round, non-tender ulcers on the penis that bleeds on touch and microscopy showing Donovan bodies inside mononuclear cells is suggestive of granuloma inguinale (donovanosis).

Granuloma inguinale is a chronic, progressive sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Klebsiella granulomatis. Commonly affected sites in men are prepuce, coronal sulcus, frenulum, and glans while in women it is in labia minora and fourchette.

The following image shows Donovan bodies. 

 

While collecting a sample for smear, the lesion should first be cleaned with a dry cotton swab to remove debris. Care should be taken not to disrupt any small blood vessels, to minimize bleeding. If donovanosis is suspected clinically, the swab should always be obtained before another testing to maximize tissue collections.

Granulation tissue can be obtained by using either forceps or scalpel and then crushed between two slides as an alternative method to obtaining a smear.

On direct microscopy, Donovan bodies are seen inside large, mononuclear cells (pund cells) as gram-negative intracytoplasmic cysts filled with deeply staining bodies.

They can have a characteristic safety pin appearance due to bipolar condensation of the chromatin material. When these cyst structures rupture, infectious organisms are released. The stains commonly used are the Giemsa stain and the Wright stain.

Klebsiella granulomatis can be grown on egg yolk medium and on modified Levinthal's agar.

Histopathological examination shows chronic inflammation with plasma cells and neutrophil infiltration. Epithelial changes like ulceration, microabscesses, and elongation of rete ridges are seen.

Azithromycin 1 gm on day 1 and 500 mg daily for 7 days is one of the effective treatments. Other antibiotics used in the treatment are doxycycline, erythromycin, tetracycline. Advanced lesions are managed with surgical intervention.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.

questions.text: A 40-year-old lady presents with complaints of chest pain and dysphagia. The chest pain increases during eating, exertion, and with heightened emotional stress. There is no history of acid reflux and cardiac workup was within normal limits. Her barium study is shown below. The most likely underlying cause is:
questions.solution:
The most likely underlying cause is diffuse oesophagal spasm.

The given clinical vignette of a woman presenting with chest pain and dysphagia, that increases on eating, exertion and emotional stress, without acid reflux and the findings from the barium esophagogram are indicative of diffuse oesophagal spasm (DES).

DES is a hypermotility disorder of the oesophagus which manifests as dysphagia. It is associated with an impairment of inhibitory innervation. This leads to premature and rapidly propagated contractions in the distal oesophagus. Also, patients with DES may have defective endogenous nitric oxide synthesis and/or degradation, which is supported by an improvement in symptoms with phosphodiesterase inhibitors and nitrates. It is commoner in women.

Patients with diffuse oesophagal spasms present with dysphagia for solids and liquids. The dysphagia is characterized by difficulty in swallowing several seconds after initiating a swallow and having a sensation of food getting stuck in the oesophagus. This may also occur in association with retrosternal chest pain and patients may also have symptoms of heartburn or regurgitation.

In patients with DES, severe nonperistaltic contractions may result in a rosary bead or corkscrew appearance of the esophagus on barium swallow, as shown in the image below.

 

Oesophageal manometry is the key to establishing a diagnosis of DES. Manometric findings are characterized by the frequent occurrence of simultaneous high amplitude wave-forms and multipeaked oesophagal contractions. In DES, there remain some peristaltic waveforms in excess of those seen in achalasia.

Treatment is with long-acting nitrates, calcium channel blocking agents, sedatives and anticholinergics. Bougie dilation of the oesophagus relieves dysphagia in many patients. Intrasphincteric injection of botulinum toxin has been tried.

Surgery is indicated for patients who fail to respond to medical or endoscopic therapy. 

Other options:

Option A: Achalasia cardia is characterised by the absence of oesophagal peristalsis. It affects men more than women. A barium swallow shows the presence of a characteristic birds beak appearance. It is shown below.

Option B: Nutcracker oesophagus is an oesophagal motility disorder that manifests as chest pain. Barium swallow is usually normal and manometry shows normal propagation of the peristalsis waves without any simultaneous contractions. However, the peristaltic waves in the distal oesophagus, are of high amplitude and duration.

Option D: Zenker diverticulum is the most common of all the oesophagal diverticula. It is much commoner in men, after age 60. Patients present with dysphagia, regurgitation and hallitosis. Barium study shows the presence of a diverticulum. It is shown in the image below, indicated by the red arrow.

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient presented with dyspnea. She does not have hoarseness of voice or change in voice. She underwent total thyroidectomy 2 days back. Laryngoscopy reveals the vocal cords to be in paramedian position. All of the following can be done in the management of this patient except:
questions.solution:
All of the above management options can be done in this patient except Thyroplasty type I that is medialization of the vocal cords.

The above clinical scenario of breathing difficulty with a good voice (no hoarseness), history of total thyroidectomy, and the laryngoscopy revealing the vocal cords in the paramedian position are suggestive of bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.

Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury is often acute. Neuritis or surgical trauma (thyroidectomy) are the most important causes. Other causes include carcinoma thyroid, cervical lymphadenopathy, and carcinoma of the cervical esophagus. The vocal cords lie in the median or paramedian position due to the paralysis of all the intrinsic muscles of the larynx and the unopposed action of cricothyroid muscles. This leads to dyspnoea and stridor but the voice is good.

Treatment: Many cases of bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy develop stridor and dyspnea that requires tracheostomy as an emergency procedure. Widening the respiratory airway without a permanent tracheostomy can be achieved by:

  • Lateralization of the vocal cords.
  • Thyroplasty type II- This creates a lateral expansion of the larynx similar to lateralization of the vocal cords.
  • Arytenoidopexy is the fixing of the arytenoid in the lateral position.
  • Transverse cordotomy (Kashima operation)- This involves excising laterally the soft tissue at the junction of membranous cord and vocal process of arytenoid with laser.
  • Partial arytenoidectomy- This involves excision of the medial part of the arytenoid with laser.
  • Reinnervation procedures- Innervation of the paralyzed posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is achieved by implanting a nerve-muscle pedicle of sternohyoid or omohyoid muscle with its nerve supply from ansa hypoglossi.

Other options:

Option C- Thyroplasty type I that is medialization of the vocal cord is done in cases of complete paralysis (recurrent and superior laryngeal nerve paralysis). This is achieved by Teflon paste injection lateral to the paralysed cord or thyroplasty I procedure.

questions.text: A study on the prevalence of diabetes was conducted and the sampling method shown below was used. Identify the sampling method used.
questions.solution:
In this study, the population is separated into homogenous sub-groups and from these, random samples are drawn. This sampling method is called stratified random sampling.

Related Pearl: Sampling

1. Simple random sampling

  • In simple random sampling, samples are drawn in such a way that every element in a population has equal chances of being included.
  • Randomness refers to the method of picking the sample and not the outcome.

2. Stratified random sampling

  • In stratified random sampling, the population is first divided into homogeneous groups, or strata. From these strata, random samples are drawn.
  • For example, dividing a population into the strata of men, women, and children and then picking samples randomly from these strata.

3. Cluster sampling

  • In cluster sampling, the population is divided into internally heterogeneous groups. Then a simple random sampling is done of these clusters and taken as the samples.
  • In other words, the clusters are the sampling unit.
  • This is usually done when large-scale simple random sampling or stratified sampling is laborious or expensive.
  • This is the method used in assessing the immunization status of children.
  • Cluster sampling involves a design effect, which is an adjustment to allow for design structure. It aids in the correlation between clusters.
  • Multistage sampling is a form of cluster sampling, where sampling clusters are chosen from the already divided clusters.

4. Systematic random sampling

  • In systematic sampling, there is a systematic pattern to selecting the elements of a sample.
  • For example, every 3rd baby to be born can be selected.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman underwent ultrasonography of the abdomen and pelvis prior to a procedure. Her abdominal ultrasonogram incidentally showed mobile, echogenic foci producing acoustic shadows in the gall bladder. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Echogenic foci in the gall bladder that produce acoustic shadows on ultrasonography are suggestive of cholelithiasis or gallstones.

Gallbladder stones or cholelithiasis is the most common gallbladder disease. It is usually discovered incidentally and becomes symptomatic when the stones obstruct the cystic duct. In symptomatic cases, patients may experience dull or colicky right upper quadrant or epigastric pain radiating to the back.

Ultrasonography (USG) is the most accurate initial imaging modality of choice for the diagnosis of gallbladder stones. These stones appear as echogenic foci producing acoustic shadows. USG allows measurement of the size of the gallbladder and the thickness of the wall, as well as the detection of stones or polyps. USG also helps assess inflammation around the gallbladder, the size of the common bile duct, and stones in the extrahepatic biliary tree. The sensitivity of USG for gallstones is >95%.

The image below shows ultrasonography of the gall bladder.

 

Plain radiograph of the gallbladder may show radiopaque gallstones in only 10% of patients. Rarely, the center of a stone may contain radiolucent gas in a triradiate or biradiate fissure. This gives rise to the ‘Mercedes–Benz’ or ‘seagull’ sign.

Prophylactic cholecystectomy is not warranted in most asymptomatic patients. Patients with severe or recurrent symptoms have a higher rate of complications of the disease. Hence they should undergo elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

Other options:

Option B: Gallbladder polyps appear as small echogenic non-shadowing foci that are adherent to the gallbladder wall. They are often seen in a non-dependent part. They can be differentiated from stones by the lack of mobility and shadow.

Option C: Porcelain gallbladder is an uncommon condition, where calcification is seen to follow the contour of the gallbladder wall. It can be seen on CT scans. On USG, it appears as a curvilinear echogenic focus along the entire gallbladder wall, with posterior shadowing.

Option D: Gallbladder mucocele is the result of chronic gallbladder obstruction, without superimposed infection. The gallbladder may be distended and fluid-filled, and the mucocele may present as a mass.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic Evaluation of the Gall Bladder

  • Gallbladder Ultrasound: Investigation of choice for detection of gall stones
  • Abdominal X-ray: Useful in 
    • Calcified gall stones
    • Emphysematous cholecystitis
    • Porcelain gallbladder
    • Limey bile
    • Gallstone ileus
  • Radioisotope scans (HIDA/DIDA/DISIDA)
    • Indicated for confirmation of suspected acute cholecystitis
    • Useful in diagnosis of acalculous cholecystopathy

  • HIDA: Hepatobiliary IminoDiacetic Acid scan
  • DIDA/DISDA: Di-isopropyl IminoDiacetic Acid - Dynamic Tc99m DIDA Cholescintigraphy

questions.text: All of the following indicate a favorable prognosis for neuroblastoma except:
questions.solution:
All of the above are favorable diagnostic factors except n-MYC gene amplification.

The image shown below is that of Homer-Wright pseudorosettes, which are typically seen in neuroblastoma. The factors indicative of an unfavorable prognosis in neuroblastoma are n-MYC gene amplification and histological examination of the tumor showing no evidence of schwannian stroma and gangliocytic differentiation.

Neuroblastoma is the most frequently-occurring extracranial childhood tumor. They most commonly occur in the adrenal glands but can occur anywhere in the sympathetic nervous system like in the paraspinal ganglia and less frequently in the thorax, pelvis, and cervical areas, after having originated from neural crest progenitor cells.

In children younger than 2 years of age, neuroblastomas generally present as large abdominal masses with fever and weight loss. In older children, they can cause bone pain, respiratory symptoms or metastasize through the hematogenous and lymphatic systems to the liver, bones, and bone marrow. The periorbital region is a common metastatic site and as a result, proptosis and ecchymosis may occur. In neonates, disseminated neuroblastomas may present with multiple cutaneous metastases that cause deep blue discoloration of the skin (blueberry muffin baby).

About 90% of neuroblastomas produce catecholamines, which are an important diagnostic feature; this includes elevated blood levels of catecholamines and elevated urine levels of the metabolites vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) and homovanillic acid (HVA).

Histologic confirmation is required to establish a diagnosis of neuroblastoma. Tumor cells are concentrically arranged around a central space filled with neuropil, an arrangement called Homer-Wright pseudorosettes. MRI is done as a part of preliminary imaging for good resolution and surgical excision planning.

The following image shows the Homer Wright rosettes. 

Due to sympathetic neuronal uptake of mIBG (metaiodobenzylguanidine), owing to its analogous nature to norepinephrine, the extent of neuroblastoma metastasis can be delineated with an mIBG scan with high accuracy and quality. Bone marrow biopsy is required for tumor staging.

Common paraneoplastic conditions associated with neuroblastoma include opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome and intractable secretory diarrhea (Kerner-Morrison syndrome) due to vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) secretion, Pepper syndrome characterized by extensive metastasis to the liver, Horner syndrome, etc.

A CT scan of the abdomen and chest is recommended to look for calcifications and metastatic lesions.

The prognostic factors for neuroblastoma are:

Factor  Favorable  Unfavorable
Stage Stage 1, 2A, 2B, 4S Stages 3 and 4
Age < 18 months > 18 months
DNA ploidy Hyperploid Near-diploid
MYCN Not amplified  Amplified
Chromosome 1p loss Absent Present
Chromosome 11q loss Absent Present
Evidence of schwannian stroma and gangliocytic differentiation on histology Present Absent
Mitosis-karyorrhexis index (number of mitotic/karyorrhectic cells per 5000 tumor cells) <200 >200

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman came with complaints of bloating,  recurrent abdominal pain for more than 6 months. The frequency of this has increased to 1 day per week for the last 3 months and pain is relieved with defecation. There is a hardening of stools since her symptoms have started.  Laboratory investigations are unremarkable.  All the following drugs can be prescribed for her condition except?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a female presenting with recurrent abdominal pain for more than 6 months with increased frequency of one episode per week for the last 3 months, pain relived during defecation, hardening of stools are suggestive of constipation-predominant irritable bowel disease (IBS).  Among the given drugs, alosetron is prescribed for diarrhea-predominant IBS while all others are used for constipation dominant IBS.

Alosetron is a 5HT-3 receptor antagonist. 5HT-3 receptors enhance the sensitivity of afferent neurons projecting from the gut. Alosetron reduces the perception of painful visceral stimulation in IBS. It also induces rectal relaxation, increases rectal compliance, and delays transit from the colon. 

Lubiprostone (option A) is a chloride channel activator. It promotes the secretion of water and chloride into the bowel and improves bowel movements. It is effective in the treatment of constipation predominant IBS.

Linaclotide (option C) is a minimally absorbed 14-aminoacid peptide guanylate cyclase-C (GC-C) agonist. They bind and activate GC-C on the luminal surface of the intestinal epithelium. This triggers the secretion of fluid, sodium, and bicarbonate into the lumen.

Psyllium husk (option D) is fiber supplementation that helps to improve the stool pattern and abdominal pain in constipation dominant IBS. They tend to produce less bloating and rectal distension. 

IBS is a functional bowel disorder. It is characterized by abdominal pain or discomfort and altered bowel habits in the absence of detectable structural abnormalities. Diagnosis is based on ROME IV criteria. 

IBS can be presented in any age group. However, most of the patients have their symptoms before 45 years of age. They are predominantly present in females. 

Alteration in bowel habits is the consistent clinical feature in IBS. Alternating constipation and diarrhea with one of these symptoms predominating are the most common pattern seen in IBS. 

Patients with constipation-predominating IBS can have weeks or months of constipation interrupted with brief periods of diarrhea. 

Related Pearl: Drugs used in irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

For abdominal pain

  • Antispasmodics - Dicyclomine
  • Tricyclic antidepressants - Amitriptyline, Imipramine
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Citalopram

For diarrhoea

  • Opiate - Loperamide
  • 5-HT3 antagonist - Alosetron
  • Bile acid sequestrant - Cholestyramine resin

For constipation

  • Laxatives such as psyllium/ispaghula husk and polyethylene glycol
  • Cl- channel activator - Lubiprostone
  • Guanylate cyclase agonist - Linaclotide
  • 5-HT4 agonist - Tegaserod
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Paroxetine

Related Pearl: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

  • Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)
  • Associated with a change in stool frequency
  • Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with onset of some symptoms at least 6 months before diagnosis.

questions.text: A 78-year-old diabetic male patient presents with a week-long history of severe pain in and discharge from the right ear and pain in the jaw while chewing. Examination reveals exquisite tenderness, multiple cranial nerve palsies, and granulation tissue on the floor of the external auditory canal. Which of the following is the appropriate management for this condition?

choices.text: Continue topical therapy for one week
Intravenous anti-pseudomonas drugs along with ear toileting
Biopsy of granulation tissue and topical steroid therapy for one week

questions.solution:
The appropriate management for the given condition is initiating intravenous anti-pseudomonal drugs along with ear toileting. 

The given clinical scenario of an elderly diabetic developing severe pain, whitish discharge from the right ear associated with pain while chewing, multiple cranial nerve palsies, and the finding of granulation tissue in the inferior portion of the external auditory canal, is suggestive of malignant otitis externa. This is a life-threatening condition; the patient must be admitted and started on intravenous ciprofloxacin (anti-pseudomonal agents). 

Malignant (necrotizing) otitis externa is an inflammatory condition seen in elderly diabetics and those on immunosuppressive drugs due to pseudomonal infection. It is an infective condition and not a malignant condition. It mimics diffuse otitis externa associated with excruciating pain, discharge, and granulations on the floor of EAC. Bony erosion aids in the spread of infection. Facial paralysis is common. Multiple cranial nerve palsies can occur when the infection spreads to the skull base and jugular foramen. The infection can spread anteriorly into the temporomandibular fossa. 

Diagnosis: Severe ear pain associated with granulation tissue in the external auditory canal in a diabetic patient should raise the suspicion of malignant otitis externa. CT scan helps in detecting bony erosions and demineralization of the bones. Gallium-67 is more useful in the diagnosis and follow-up of the patient. Technetium 99 bone scan reveals bone infection but cannot be used to monitor the disease as the test remains positive for a year or so.

Treatment: The treatment of malignant otitis external would include control of diabetes, ear toileting to remove the discharge, debris or granulation tissue, antibiotic therapy against Pseudomonas with fluoroquinolones, third-generation cephalosporins, beta-lactam antibiotics with/without aminoglycosides.

Other options:

Option B- Prolonged antibiotic treatment has replaced radical surgery and resections which were done previously for this condition.

questions.text: The histopathological analysis of a myocardial biopsy taken from a patient with acute rheumatic carditis is shown below. What type of necrosis is associated with the finding seen in the below image?
questions.solution:
The most likely lesion shown in the myocardial biopsy specimen of acute rheumatic carditis is Aschoff's bodies, which shows fibrinoid necrosis.

Fibrinoid necrosis is usually the result of the deposition of immune complexes and plasma proteins in the arterial wall. On biopsy, fibrinoid necrosis appears as bright pink and amorphous deposits in the vessel wall. 

The Aschoff bodies consist of a focus of fibrinoid necrosis of collagen fibers, leukocyte infiltrates, and occasional large histiocytes called Anitschkow cells. The Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and large, vesicular nuclei, as seen in the image below.


Other options :

Option A - Coagulative necrosis is a form of necrosis in which the architecture of the dead tissue is preserved for some days. it has a firm texture. The injury denatures the structural proteins and enzymes so the dead cell proteolysis is blocked. The necrotic cells are broken down by the action of lysosomal enzymes derived from infiltrating leukocytes, and they also remove debris from the dead cells by phagocytosis. 

The image below shows the coagulative necrosis of cardiomyocytes.


Option C- Fat necrosis is a focal area of fat destruction, due to the release of activated pancreatic lipases into the substances of the pancreas and the peritoneal cavity. It is mainly seen in acute pancreatitis. 

The following image shows an area of fat necrosis within the breast tissue.


Option D- Caseous necrosis is often seen in foci of tuberculosis infection. On microscopy, these necrotic areas appear as a structureless collection of fragmented or lysed cells and amorphous granular debris enclosed within a distinctive inflammatory border. This appears as a characteristic focus of inflammation called a granuloma.

The image below shows tuberculoid granuloma associated with caseous necrosis (upper right) and surrounding epithelioid cells, Langhans' multinucleated giant cells.

questions.text: A 40-year-old obese smoker presents with hypertension, moon facies, and easy bruisability. On examination, multiple purple striae are noticed over the abdomen. Which of the following statements is true about this condition?

choices.text: Basal plasma ACTH level is used as a screening test.
Raised late night salivary cortisol level is used for diagnosis.
Overnight 100-mg dexamethasone-suppression test is used for diagnosis.
24-h urine free cortisol level is raised

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an obese patient with hypertension, moon facies, and easy bruisability with multiple purple striae over the abdomen is suggestive of Cushing's syndrome. 24-h urine-free cortisol level is raised and is a cost-effective screening test.

Cushing syndrome is characterized by prolonged exposure to high circulating levels of cortisol, i.e., hypercortisolism, which can be due to endogenous or exogenous causes. 

Endogenous hypercortisolism can be ACTH dependent or ACTH independent. ACTH-dependent hypercortisolism caused by an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma is termed Cushing's disease. ACTH-dependent hypercortisolism can also be caused by ectopic ACTH-secreting tumors. ACTH-independent hypercortisolism is mainly caused by adrenal hyperplasia, adenoma, and carcinoma.

Exogenous hypercortisolism due to the prolonged use of glucocorticoids is the most common cause of Cushing's syndrome.

Excess cortisol increases the rate of gluconeogenesis, glycogenolysis, and insulin resistance. Cortisol directly affects the transcription and translation of enzyme proteins involved in the metabolism of fats, glycogen, protein synthesis, and Krebs' cycle. The excess catabolism of proteins causes purplish striae of the torso, osteoporosis, and poor wound healing. 

24-h urine-free cortisol (UFC) can detect endogenous overproduction of cortisol and is used as a screening test. An overnight 1-mg dexamethasone suppression test (Option C) can be used to identify patients with hypercortisolism.

Elevated midnight serum or salivary samples of cortisol are suggestive of Cushing’s disease. But, in smokers, late-night salivary cortisol can be falsely high (Option B) due to the inhibition of 11-beta-hydroxy dehydrogenase on the salivary gland, and hence it is not confirmatory. 

Basal plasma ACTH levels distinguish patients with ACTH-independent (adrenal glucocorticoid) from those with ACTH-dependent (pituitary ACTH) Cushing’s syndrome. Mean basal ACTH levels are higher in patients with ectopic ACTH secretion.  

  • Following dynamic tests are used to distinguish between ectopic and pituitary sources of excess ACTH:
    • ACTH stimulation in response to CRH 
    • Differential sensitivity to glucocorticoid feedback

Most ACTH-secreting pituitary tumors are <5 mm in diameter, and about 50% are undetectable by sensitive MRI.

Tapering exogenous steroids is the best therapy for iatrogenic Cushing's syndrome. The treatment of choice for Cushing's disease is selective transsphenoidal resection, and radiotherapy can be used in failed transsphenoidal surgery.

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child was referred to a urologist following symptoms of hematuria, fever, and hypertension and the detection of a left-sided abdominal mass. On further investigation, he was diagnosed with Wilms tumor. Which of the following is the most important prognostic factor of the tumor?

choices.text: Histology and stage of the tumor
Age less than 1 year at presentation

questions.solution:
The histology and stage of the tumor are the most important prognostic factors of Wilms tumor. 

Wilms tumor/nephroblastoma is an embryonal renal neoplasm. It is usually diagnosed before the age of five. Wilms tumor is caused by abnormal renal development, resulting in the proliferation of the metanephric blastema.

Children may present with a mass abdomen, fever, and hematuria, which is indicative of the extension of the tumor into the renal pelvis. Hypertension is also observed in a considerable percentage of patients.

Prognostic factors for Wilms tumor:

  • Histology
  • Stage
  • Age
  • Tumor weight
  • Response to therapy
  • Loss of heterozygosity at 1p and 16q 

The two most important factors are the histology and the stage of the tumor.

Most of the tumors have favorable histology and are characterized as the “classic” type that consists of three components—blastemal, stromal, and epithelial (tubules) tissues. 

Unfavorable tumors are those with focal or diffuse anaplasia. Two principal staging systems are used:

  • The COG system is based on findings prior to the initiation of treatment. There exists a local stage and a disease stage. The local stage defines the extent of abdominal disease while the disease stage considers both local disease and metastasis. Metastasis commonly occurs in the lungs.
  • The SIOP classification is based on the histologic appearance of the tumors at resection and the outcomes. They are classified as completely necrotic (low risk), blastemal (high risk) and other histological types.

Imaging with USG abdomen and pelvis, CT scan, MRI etc., shows a solid space-occupying lesion in the kidney.

Management is mainly by chemotherapy and nephrectomy.

questions.text: A child is brought to a pediatrician for a regular check-up. He observed that the child could run stiffly, crawl up or downstairs, scribble, and build a tower of 3 blocks. What could be the possible age of the child?
questions.solution:
The child is possibly 18 months old.

At age 18 months, the child the milestones attained by the child are:

  • Motor:
    • Run
    • Crawl up and downstairs
    • Explore drawers and wastebasket
  • Adaptive:
    • Make a tower of 3-4 blocks
    • Can scribble
  • Language:
    • Name pictures
    • Identify 1 or more parts of the body
    • A vocabulary of around 10 words
  • Social:
    • Feed themselves
    • Seek help when in trouble
    • May complain when wet or soiled

Other options:

Option B- At 24 months of age, the child can run well, walk up and down the stairs one step at a time, jump. He would be able to build a tower of 6-7 cubes and make circular strokes. He can make 3-word sentences. 

Option C- At 12 months, the child walks with one hand-held, has a mature pincer grasp, and can say 1-2 words with meaning. He may be able to play a simple ball game.

Option D- At 30 months, the child can climb stairs with alternating feet, and build a tower of 9 cubes. He can copy a circle. He knows his full name, and refers to himself as "I".
