questions.text: Identify the type of injury shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
A spindle-shaped wound with clean-cut margins as seen in the image indicates an incised wound. 

An incised wound is a clean-cut wound made with a sharp-edged instrument, through the skin and subcutaneous tissues, including blood vessels. The length of the wound is more than the depth and width.

The edges are well-defined and usually everted, free from contusions and abrasions. It is usually spindle-shaped. The depth is more at the commencement and progressively becomes shallower, known as tailing. Tailing determines the direction of the force applied when creating the wound.

Other options:

Option A- A laceration is a tear or a split in the skin, mucous membrane, muscle, or any internal organ produced by blunt force. They are also termed tears or ruptures. 

Margins are irregular and ragged. Tears that are seen at the ends, diverging away from the main laceration are called swallow-tails. Bruising is seen around the wound.

Deeper tissues are unevenly divided with tissue tags at the bottom of the wound. Hair and epidermal tags are driven deeply into the wound and hair bulbs are crushed. The depth of the wound contains abundant foreign material. 

Classification of a laceration:

  • Split laceration (incised-like laceration)
    • This occurs when the skin is crushed between two hard objects
  • Stretch laceration
    • It occurs due to the over-stretching of the fixed skin.
    • Usually seen in run over by a motor vehicle, kicking, and compound fractures
  • Avulsion or shearing laceration
    • An avulsion is a lesion where the skin separates or peels off by tearing from the underlying tissues due to shearing force delivered at an acute angle
    • This is common in road traffic accidents
  • Tears - Tearing of skin and subcutaneous tissue can occur from localized impact
  • Cut laceration - Deep and wide cut over the body tissues by a heavily sharp-edged instrument

The below image shows a lacerated wound.


Option B- Incised-like lacerated wounds are seen at sites where the skin overlies an area of the bone where there is scanty underlying subcutaneous tissue. A blunt force on the areas of the skin close to the bone causes linear splitting of the tissue which results in the laceration resembling an incised wound. There will be some tissue crushing present but the margins will be relatively sharp. 

The common sites are the scalp, forehead, eyebrows, zygoma, lower jaw, perineum, shin, and iliac crest.

The image below shows incised-like lacerated wound.


Option C- Chop wounds or slash wounds are deep gaping wounds caused by a blow with a heavy sharp cutting-edged weapon. The dimensions of the wound correspond to the crosssection of the penetrating part of the weapon. The margins are sharp and show slight abrasion and bruising with the destruction of underlying organs. The presence of an incised wound on the skin with an underlying fracture or deep grove in the bone indicates a chop wound.

The image below shows a chop wound.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency room in an unconscious state. Several hours later, upon regaining consciousness, he gives a history of head trauma. On examination, he has right-sided mydriasis and left-sided hemiparesis. CT brain shows the following findings. Identify the false statement about his condition.

choices.text: Rare in children below 2 years of age
A lucid interval is pathognomonic of this condition
Middle meningeal artery most commonly involved
Management is generally by surgical evacuation

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of head trauma with the given CT scan showing a typical hyperdense, biconvex mass adjacent to the skull is indicative of an extra-dural hematoma (EDH). The presence of a lucid interval, ipsilateral mydriasis, and contralateral hemiparesis also support the diagnosis. However,  a lucid interval is not pathognomonic of this condition, as it may be associated with other post traumatic mass lesions as well. (Option B is false)

EDH refers to the accumulation of blood in the potential space between the inner table of the skull and the dura mater. It is common in young adults. It is rare in children below 2 years of age because of the plasticity of the immature calvarium, and after age 60 because the dura is adherent to the overlying bone.

The hematoma arises from arterial disruption, especially of the middle meningeal artery. The middle meningeal vein and diploic veins may also be implicated.

A lucid interval is not pathognomonic for EDH as other post-traumatic mass lesions like a subdural hematoma, and temporal lobe contusion can also present with a lucid interval. Patients present with head injury with lucid interval, ipsilateral mydriasis, and contralateral hemiparesis.

On head CT, the blood clot is bright, biconvex or lentiform in shape, and has a well-defined border. An EDH is typically found over the convexities but may rarely occur in the posterior fossa as well.

Open craniectomy for evacuation of the congealed clot and hemostasis generally is indicated for EDH. In some cases, patients who meet all of the following criteria may be managed conservatively:

  • Clot volume <30 cm3
  • Maximum thickness <1.5 cm
  • Glasgow come score >8.

Prognosis after successful evacuation is good for EDH.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presented to the emergency department with left wrist pain following a fall. On examination, the patient was found to have swelling and tenderness at his left thumb base. His x-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the above image are suggestive of Bennett fracture.

Bennett fracture is an intraarticular fracture that separates the palmar ulnar aspect of the base of the first metacarpal from the rest of the first metacarpal. It is the most common fracture involving the base of the thumb. 

The fracture is oblique and extends into the carpometacarpal joint. The strong pull of the abductor pollicis longus tendon that remains attached to the shaft of the metacarpal makes the fracture very unstable. X-ray shows a small triangle fragment remained in contact with the medial edge of the trapezium.

Plaster is applied with a felt pad over the fracture, and the first metacarpal is held in abduction and extension by flexing the MCP joint. Surgical fixation is done by passing a K-wire across the metacarpal base unto the carpus. 

Other options:

Option B: Rolando fracture is an intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration. The fracture can be managed with closed reduction and k wiring or by open reduction and plate fixation.

While both Bennett and Rolando fractures are intra-articular fractures of the metacarpal base, the differentiating feature is that Rolando fracture is a comminuted fracture producing 3 parts, whereas Bennett fracture is a 2 piece fracture.

The X-ray shown below depicts a Rolando fracture.

 

Option C: Boxer fracture is a fracture of the neck of the fifth metacarpal, as shown below.

 

Option D: Barton fracture is a split of the volar edge of the distal radius, as shown below.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.  

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: A couple comes to a hospital for genetic counselling and upon further evaluation, the husband is found to have Marfan syndrome. The inheritance pattern and mutation associated with this condition are:

choices.text: Autosomal dominant, mutation in FBN-1 gene
Autosomal recessive, mutation in FBN-1 gene
Autosomal dominant, mutation in FBN-2 gene
Autosomal recessive, mutation in FBN-2 gene

questions.solution:
The inheritance pattern in Marfan syndrome is autosomal dominant and is associated with a mutation in FBN-1 gene.

Marfan syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder affecting connective tissues associated chiefly with cardiovascular, ocular, and musculoskeletal abnormalities, although involvement of other organ systems like the central nervous system, respiratory system and skin has also been observed. It results from an inherited defect in an extracellular glycoprotein called fibrillin-1.

Fibrillin occurs in two homologous forms, fibrillin-1 and fibrillin-2, encoded by two separate genes, FBN-1 and FBN-2, located on the long arms of chromosomes 15 and 5, respectively. Mutations of FBN-1 give rise to marfan syndrome while mutations of the related FBN-2 gene give rise to congenital contractural arachnodactyly, characterized by skeletal abnormalities, which is less common. 

Fibrillin-1 is a regulator of TGF-β which is responsible for inflammation, fibrosis, and activation of specific matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs), particularly MMP-2 and MMP-9, which result in the loss of extracellular matrix.

Patients with Marfan syndrome are tall and have a decreased upper to lower segment ratio with long arms, hands, and fingers. Deformities of the chest wall, vertebral column, and foot arches may be present.

Associated cardiovascular abnormalities include mitral valve prolapse leading to mitral regurgitation and dilatation of aortic root/sinuses of Valsalva leading to aortic regurgitation, aortic dissection, and rupture.

Ocular features include ectopia lentis, retinal detachment, cataracts and refractive errors like myopia due to increased axial length.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman presents with dry cough and mild fever for 5 days and musculoskeletal pain for one week. Examination reveals increased respiratory rate and skin lesions all over her body as shown below. Other findings are given below. What is the most effective drug for this condition?

Temperature: 37.8 degrees

Pulse rate: 98 bpm

Blood pressure: 100/70mmHg

Chest X-ray shows patchy consolidation

Bronchoalveolar lavage culture shows a fried egg appearance
questions.solution:
The given scenario point towards pneumonia whereas the constitutional symptoms, patchy consolidation on chest Xray and fried egg appearance on culture is suggestive of atypical pneumonia caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae. Azithromycin is the most effective drug for the treatment of M. pneumonia.

Pneumonia due to M. pneumonia is also referred to as Eaton agent pneumonia, primary atypical pneumonia, and walking pneumonia. Other bacterial causes of atypical community-acquired pneumonia are Chlamydia pneumonia and Legionella.

Upper respiratory tract infection (tracheobronchitis/ pharyngitis) and pneumonia are common pulmonary manifestations. Majority of patients with Mycoplasma pneumonia present with dry cough, sore throat and fever.

It is also can present with extrapulmonary manifestations including erythema multiforme/Steven-Johnson syndrome (SJS), cold agglutinin disease, Guillain Barre syndrome, and transverse myelitis, arthritis, myocarditis, pericarditis and encephalitis.

Investigations include PCR of respiratory secretions and chest X-rays. Chest X-ray shows patchy consolidation with thickened bronchial markings and subsegmental atelectasis.

Culture shows a typical fried egg appearance (central opaque granular area of growth sorrounded by a flat translucent peripheral zone) on PPLO agar. The diagnosis is made by serology or by PCR. 

Azithromycin is the most effective drug for management. Other drugs used are doxycycline, clarithromycin, erythromycin, moxifloxacin, levofloxacin, gemifloxacin.

Other options:

Options A and B: Amoxicillin and Cefotaxime are beta-lactam antibiotics (cell-wall synthesis inhibitors), hence they are not effective on M.pneumoniae as they lack a cell wall.

Option D: Ciprofloxacin and ofloxacin are not recommended because of their high minimal inhibitory concentrations against M. pneumoniae isolates.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male patient complains of chest pain radiating to the neck and the left arm. He was started on medications that included trimetazidine as one of them. Which of the following correctly describes the mechanism of this drug?

choices.text: Shift from glucose to free fatty acid metabolism
Shift from free fatty acid to glucose metabolism
Agonist at ATP sensitive potassium channels

questions.solution:
Trimetazidine causes the metabolism to shift from free fatty acids to glucose. This requires less oxygen and is beneficial in ischemia. 

Trimetazidine is an antianginal agent which blocks the thiolase enzyme, the final enzyme in the β-oxidation of fatty acids. This causes a partial shift in the metabolism of the myocardium from free fatty acids to glucose. Glucose oxidation provides lesser ATP but also requires less oxygen. This is beneficial in ischemic states. 

The most important adverse effect of trimetazidine is the increased risk of movement disorders like Parkinson disease. This risk is higher in older patients and those with kidney dysfunction. Hence, it is used only as an add-on drug in the treatment of angina.

Ranolazine is another second-line anti-anginal drug that acts by blocking late sodium current (option B). Nicorandil acts as an agonist at ATP-sensitive potassium channels (option D) and causes vasodilation of both arterial and venous vascular beds. This leads to decreased preload and afterload of the heart.

Related Pearl: Anti-anginal drugs

Anti-anginal drugs can be divided into the following categories:

  • Nitrates - dilates veins > arteries, reduces preload
  • Calcium channel blockers - blocks L-type calcium channels
    • Dihydropyridines - amlodipine, nifedipine
    • Non-dihydropyridines - verapamil, diltiazem
  • Beta-blockers - decreases heart rate, contractility and oxygen demand
  • Other drugs: 
    • Ranolazine - late Na+ channel blocker
    • Ivabradine - inhibit funny currents in SA node
    • Nicorandil - K+-ATP channel agonist
    • Trimetazidine - pFOX inhibitor
    • Fasudil - rho-kinase inhibitor

questions.text: A 65-year-old lady presents to you with multiple joint pains for the past 6 years. On examination, you notice the following deformity over the fingers. What is this deformity known as?
questions.solution:
The given deformity is a swan-neck deformity, seen in rheumatoid arthritis (RA). It is characterized by hyperextension of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints and flexion of the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP). It occurs due to imbalance of extensor versus flexor action at the PIP joint, and laxity of the palmar plate.

Other deformities in RA:

  • Boutonniere deformity: Hyperextension of DIP joints and flexion at PIP joints
  • Z deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits.
  • Subluxation of MCP joints, with subluxation, or the partial dislocation of the proximal phalanx to the volar side of the hand leads to ulnar deviation
  • Inflammation of the ulnar styloid and tenosynovitis of the extensor carpi ulnaris causes distal ulna subluxation that results in the "piano key movement" of the ulnar styloid
  • Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), Hallux valgus, hammer toe
  • A flat foot occurs due to chronic inflammation of the ankle and midtarsal regions.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient who presented with hemoptysis and hematuria was diagnosed as a case of Goodpasture syndrome. This type of hypersensitivity reaction is initiated by:
questions.solution:
Goodpasture syndrome is an example of a type II hypersensitivity reaction that is initiated by IgG and IgM antibodies.

Antibody-mediated hypersensitivity, also known as type II hypersensitivity involves the production of IgG and IgM antibodies that bind to the antigen on the target cell or tissue and initiate phagocytosis or lysis of target cell by activated complement or Fc receptors and recruitment of leukocytes.

The end result of this is phagocytosis and lysis of cells, inflammation and in some cases occasionally, functional derangements without cell or tissue injury.

Goodpasture syndrome is an autoimmune disease that affects both the kidneys and lungs, characterized by the presence of autoantibodies against type IV collagen. It is called anti-GBM disease or Goodpasture disease with only renal involvement and Goodpasture syndrome is characterized by renal and pulmonary involvement. It has a bimodal age distribution with the first peak occurring between 20-30 years of age and the second between 60-70 years of age. The disease is common in younger men and older women.  

The circulating autoantibodies are responsible for the activation of the complement system in the glomerular basement membrane, resulting in an inflammatory response and tissue injury in that area and this is observed as crescentic glomerulonephritis.

Though the alveolar basement membrane, too, shares the same collagen target as that of the glomerulus, which is α-3 type IV collagen, the alveolar endothelium acts as a barrier against the circulating autoantibodies and pulmonary symptoms and complications don't develop. However, as a result of increased capillary permeability due to a number of factors like tobacco smoking, bacteremia, upper respiratory tract infections and increased inspired oxygen, the antibodies can cross the endothelium and bind to the basement membrane.

Patients present with symptoms of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, which include hematuria, moderate proteinuria, hypertension, and edema; due to lung involvement, there is an increased respiratory rate, cyanosis, recurrent hemoptysis, and pulmonary hemorrhage that can be fatal.

A kidney biopsy is a gold standard for diagnosis and the biopsy findings are:

Investigation Findings
Light microscopy Proliferative or necrotizing glomerulopathy with cellular crescents 
Immunofluorescence Linear deposits of immunoglobulin G (IgG) and complement (C3) on the glomerular basement membrane
Electron microscopy Ruptures in the glomerular basement membrane 

Other options:

Option A: IgE antibody is implicated in type I hypersensitivity reactions.

Option C: Antigen-Antibody complexes are implicated in type III hypersensitivity reactions.

Option D: Activated T lymphocytes are responsible for the initiation of type IV or delayed hypersensitivity reactions.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with generalized body aches, fatigue, and anxiety for the past 4 months, but her sleep is not affected due to pain. On examination, increased pain sensitivity and tender bony prominences are noted. Laboratory and radiological investigations were normal. You suspect fibromyalgia in her. Which of the following drugs is preferred in this patient?
questions.solution:
Duloxetine is preferred in fibromyalgia patients having pain along with fatigue and anxiety, as it has antidepressant action as well.

The examination findings of tender bony prominences (earlier considered as a part of the diagnostic evaluation) and increased pain sensitivity with associated low mood favor the diagnosis of fibromyalgia.

Fibromyalgia is characterized by chronic musculoskeletal pain and tenderness. Other symptoms include fatigue, depression, sleep disturbances, cognitive dysfunction, and anxiety. It is predominantly seen in females. 

Patients with fibromyalgia have an increased prevalence of other syndromes associated with pain and fatigue. This includes chronic fatigue syndrome, chronic headaches, irritable bowel syndrome, interstitial cystitis/painful bladder syndrome, and other pelvic pain syndromes. It is a diagnosis of exclusion.

Treatment strategies include physical conditioning, strength training, exercise programs, cognitive-behavioral strategies, and transcutaneous electric nerve stimulation (TENS) for movement-evoked pain and fatigue.

Pharmacotherapy with single agents to treat multiple symptom domains is recommended. Cyclobenzaprine, pregabalin, and sedating antidepressants like amitriptyline are used in fibromyalgia pain associated with sleep disturbances (Option A, B). However, in patients having pain associated with fatigue, anxiety, or depression, drugs that have both analgesic and antidepressant/anxiolytic effects, such as duloxetine or milnacipran, are used.

Option C: Glucocorticoids are not effective against fibromyalgia-related symptoms.

questions.text: Biopsy of a renal mass in a 10-month-old reveals a triphasic combination of blastema, stroma, and epithelium with anaplasia. His previous reports reveal omphalocele, hemihypertrophy, and macroglossia at birth. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome. It is an example of a disorder of genomic imprinting. The genetic locus that is involved in these patients is in chromosome 11 band p15.5 (WT2 locus). It is characterized by-

  • Neonatal hypoglycemia
  • Macrosomia
  • Macroglossia
  • Hemihyperplasia
  • Omphalocele
  • Visceromegaly
  • Embryonal tumors such as Wilms tumor, hepatoblastoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, and neuroblastoma.

Wilm's tumor is the most common renal neoplasm of childhood. Clinically, the most common finding is an asymptomatic abdominal mass. Other presentations of Wilm's tumor include Hematuria, hypertension, fever, weight loss, tumor rupture causing acute abdomen. The most common site of metastasis of Wilms tumor is the lungs.

On microscopy, the classic triphasic combination of blastemal (small, round blue cells), stromal, and epithelial cell types is observed in most lesions, although the percentage of each component is variable. Nephrogenic rests are precursor lesions of Wilms tumors. 

Below image shows macroglossia seen in a baby diagnosed with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.

 

Other options:

Option A: WAGR is a contiguous gene syndrome that is characterized by Wilms tumor, aniridia, genitourinary anomalies, mental retardation.

Option B: Sturge-Weber syndrome is also known as encephalotrigeminal angiomatosis. It is a neurocutaneous syndrome characterized by angioma of the face, choroid, and leptomeninges. In the facial territory of the trigeminal nerve capillary, vascular malformation called port-wine stain or nevus flammeus is usually seen. 

Option C: Denys-Drash syndrome presents with early-onset nephrotic syndrome, progressive renal insufficiency, ambiguous genitalia, and Wilms tumor.

questions.text: An HIV patient on antiretroviral therapy presents with seizures and unilateral facial nerve palsy. The CD4 count was 150/microlitre and the MRI showed a lesion as shown below. Which among the following is the best treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and an image of MRI showing ring-enhancing lesions are suggestive of cerebral toxoplasmosis and the best treatment is the combination of sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine with leucovorin.

In HIV patients, seizures are associated with cerebral toxoplasmosis, primary CNS lymphoma, cryptococcal meningitis, and HIV encephalopathy.

Toxoplasmosis is one of the most common causes of secondary CNS infection in patients with AIDS, but its incidence is decreasing now due to combination antiretroviral therapy (ART). It is generally a late complication of HIV infection and usually occurs in patients with CD4+T cell counts less than 200/microlitre.

Fever, headache, and focal neurologic deficits are the most common clinical presentation of cerebral toxoplasmosis in patients with HIV infection. Patients present with seizure, hemiparesis, or aphasia as a manifestation of these focal deficits or accompanying cerebral edema. It is characterized by confusion, dementia, and lethargy, which can progress to coma.

The diagnosis is suspected on the basis of MRI findings of multiple lesions in multiple locations, although in some cases a single lesion is only seen. These lesions pathologically exhibit inflammation and central necrosis and, as a result, demonstrate ring enhancement on contrast MRI.

Standard treatment is sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine with leucovorin administered for a minimum of 4–6 weeks.

Other options:

Option A- Conventional amphotericin B is given through intrathecal infusion in patients with meningitis caused by Coccidioides.

Option B- Acyclovir reduces mortality and improves the neurological outcome in herpes simplex virus encephalitis.

Option C- Isoniazid (INH), rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol are used in the treatment of tuberculous meningitis.

questions.text: A man who was working at a construction site suddenly collapsed on a hot summer afternoon. Bystanders reported that there was no sweating despite the hot weather. On examination, his pupils were constricted and the skin was dry, hot, and flushed. The physician found that the rectal temperature was 42ºC.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is heat stroke.

The given clinical scenario of the patient collapsing suddenly on a hot summer afternoon while working, with no signs of sweating, constricted pupils, and a rectal temperature of 42ºC, is highly suggestive of heat stroke.

Heat stroke/thermic fever/heat hyperpyrexia is a condition characterized by a raised rectal temperature of >41°C associated with psychosis, stupor, coma, and convulsions. It is caused by failure of cutaneous circulation and sweating that leads to the failure of the heat regulation center of the hypothalamus. The predisposing factors include high temperature, increased humidity, minor infections, old age, lack of acclimatization, and alcoholism.

Heat stroke types:

  • Exertion-induced heat stroke is seen in people with prolonged exposure to or physical exertion in high temperatures, usually without adequate training.
  • Sedentary heatstroke is a disease of elderly or infirm people whose cardiovascular systems are unable to adapt to the stress of a hot environment and release sufficient heat such that body temperature rises.

There is a sudden onset of symptoms with a sudden collapse accompanied by unconsciousness. Typical vital sign abnormalities include tachypnea, tachycardia, and hypotension. The skin is dry, hot, and flushed with no signs of sweating. The pupils are constricted. Other specific signs include rapid Kussmaul type of breathing, delirium, coma, and convulsions. 

Although there is no single specific diagnostic test, clinical features of exposure to heat stress, CNS dysfunction, and core temperature of >41°C help establish the preliminary diagnosis.

Autopsy findings include the presence of edema and reduction of Purkinje's cells in the cerebellum.

Other options:

Option A - Heat cramps are seen in people working at high temperatures with profuse sweating. It is due to rapid dehydration of the body by the loss of water and electrolytes in the sweat. It has a sudden onset associated with sudden, painful paroxysmal cramps in the muscles of the arms, legs, and abdomen. The pupils are dilated with facial flushing.

Options C and D - Both heat syncope and heat prostration are conditions resulting from increased exposure to heat without a raise in the body temperature. They are precipitated by increased muscular work and unsuitable clothing. The clinical signs include cold skin, subnormal temperature, dilated pupils, pale face, thready pulse, and loss of consciousness (in heat syncope).

questions.text: The given cylinder is supposed to be attached to a patient for labour analgesia in a maternity suite. Which pin index corresponds to this cylinder, as a safety measure to prevent incorrect cylinder attachment?
questions.solution:
The given image of a cylinder with a blue body and white shoulder is the Entonox cylinder, its PIN index is 7, which is number 4 of the given PINs.

Entonox is 50:50 mixtures of nitrous oxide and oxygen, popularly used as labour analgesia in maternity suites

 

The pin index system (PISS) is a safety measure to prevent incorrect cylinder attachment.

  • Each gas cylinder has two holes (except Entonox) in its cylinder valve that fits the corresponding pins in the yoke of the anesthesia machine. The relative positioning of the pins and holes is unique for each gas that constitutes the pin index system.
  • The PISS should only be considered as partial protection because pin index failures have been reported due to bent or broken pins.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with low backache for three months. On examination, his ankle and knee jerk reflexes were absent. But, pain and temperature sensations were preserved. MRI shows lumbar disc prolapse at L3-L4. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of cauda equina syndrome secondary to a lumbar disc prolapse.

Compression of the lumbosacral nerve roots below the level of termination of the spinal cord that is L1-L2 results in cauda-equina syndrome (CES). Common causes of CES include ruptured lumbosacral intervertebral disc, epidural hematoma, vertebral fracture, and compressive tumor. 

Patients with CES usually present with low back pain, asymmetrical weakness, variable areflexia, diminished sensation in the buttocks and posterosuperior thighs, and perineal region. Absent bulbocavernosus, patellar (knee), and Achilles (ankle) reflexes are characteristically seen in CES.

MRI of the entire spine must be done promptly.

Management includes starting dexamethasone immediately, radiation therapy plus glucocorticoids in case of spinal cord compression, and surgical decompression by laminectomy or diskectomy for disc rupture.

Other options:

Option A: Central cord syndrome results due to damage to the gray matter nerve cells and the spinothalamic tract crossing the central canal. Patients present with features are loss of pain and temperature sensation which are not seen in this patient.

Option B: Conus medullaris syndrome is characterized by bilateral saddle anesthesia, and prominent bowel and bladder dysfunction. Also, anal and bulbocavernosus reflexes are absent. 

Option D: Brown-Sequard syndrome is a hemi-transection of the spinal cord. It presents with ipsilateral weakness (corticospinal tract), ipsilateral loss of position, vibration sense (posterior column), and contralateral loss of pain and temperature one or two levels below the lesion.

questions.text: An international traveler wants to get vaccinated against typhoid. Which of the following is true when concerning the safety of the Ty21a vaccine?

choices.text: It can be given simultaneously with other live vaccines
It can be given to patients taking anti-bacterial drugs
It is efficacious in patients having acute diarrhoea
It can be given safely to HIV patients with CD4 <200 as long as they are asymptomatic

questions.solution:
Other live vaccines can be given simultaneously with the Ty21a typhoid vaccine. 

Ty21a is a live-attenuated oral vaccine for individuals ≥5 years of age.

  • The regimen is 1st, 3rd, and 5th day - 3 doses.
  • Repeat every 3 years for endemic areas, and every year for traveling individuals. 

Not recommended in:

  • Patients on antimitotic drugs and immunosuppressants
  • Acute febrile illness
  • Acute intestinal infestation
  • Congenital or acquired immunodeficiency

Ty21a vaccine can be administered in an HIV-positive asymptomatic patient as long as the CD4+ count is >200/ cubic mm. 

Proguanil and antibacterial drugs should be stopped from 3 days before to 3 days after the vaccine. 

The vaccine is unlikely to be effective if it is administered at the time of ongoing diarrhea.

Other available vaccines against typhoid include:

  • Inactivated whole cell vaccine
  • Injectable Vi polysaccharide vaccine
  • Vi-rEPA vaccine

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presented with 12 weeks of amenorrhea. The ultrasonography of the abdomen and pelvis revealed twin gestation, as shown in the image below. This type of twin gestation results if the division of the inner cell mass occurs:
questions.solution:
The image shows the lambda sign or twin peak sign seen in dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy. If the division of the inner cell mass occurs within 3 days of fertilization, it results in this type of twin gestation. 

Placental chorionicity is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. A thick septum between the two gestational sacs is present in dichorionic twins.

A triangular projection is seen at the base of the membrane. This is known as lambda or twin peak sign. The presence of lambda or twin peak sign indicates a dichorionic placenta.

questions.text: During your rural posting, a 24-year-old male patient came to you to know about the dietary modification for the prevention of coronary heart disease. According to WHO standards, the dietary goal of saturated fatty acid for an adult male should not be more than:
questions.solution:
According to WHO standards, the dietary goal of saturated fatty acid for an adult male should not be more than 10%.

Dietary modification in the prevention of CHD:

  • Reduction of the fat intake to 15–30% of total energy intake
  • Consumption of saturated fats must be limited to less than 10% of total energy intake
  • Increase in complex carbohydrate consumption (i.e vegetable fruits, whole grains, and legumes)
  • Avoidance of alcohol consumption and reduction of salt intake to 5gm daily or less

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is seen over multiple visits for complaints of gastric ulcers despite the use of ranitidine. Further evaluation revealed elevated levels of gastrin and evidence of ulcers involving the jejunum suggesting a diagnosis of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. Which of the following agents would be most useful in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Lansoprazole is the most useful in the management of this patient.

Lansoprazole is an H1/K1-ATPase proton pump inhibitor useful in the treatment of patients who have failed histamine H2-blocker therapy and patients with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.

Patients with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome develop pancreatic or duodenal gastrinomas that stimulate the secretion of very large amounts of acid, sometimes in the setting of multiple endocrine neoplasia, type I. This can lead to severe gastroduodenal ulceration and other consequences of uncontrolled hyperchlorhydria.

Proton pump inhibitors are activated by the proton-catalyzed formation of a tetracyclic sulfenamide. This leads to the trapping of the drug so that it does not diffuse back across the canalicular membrane. The activated compound forms a covalent bond with sulfhydryl groups of cysteines in the H+/K+ ATPase irreversibly, thus inactivating the pump molecule. They primarily promote healing of gastric and duodenal ulcers and is used to treat gastroesophageal reflux disease, including erosive esophagitis, that is complicated or unresponsive to treatment with H2 receptor antagonists. They are used along with antibiotics for the eradication of Helicobacter pylori. They are used as the mainstay treatment of pathological hypersecretory conditions, including the Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.

Other options:

Option A- Famotidine is a histamine H2-blocker.

Option C- Misoprostol is a prostaglandin analogue used to prevent ulcers in patients taking nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).

Option D- Propantheline is a quaternary ammonium anticholinergic agent which inhibits the muscarinic actions of acetylcholine on autonomic nerve endings. Propantheline were being used to alleviate symptoms of irritable bowel syndrome, painful gastrointestinal motility disorders and peptic ulcer disease. It has been replaced by more effective antiulcer agents.

questions.text:
A 59-year-old man presented with complaints of abdominal pain and fever for the past 2 days. Examination shows palmar erythema, testicular atrophy, and distended abdomen with diffuse tenderness. Shifting dullness is present. His vital signs and laboratory findings are given below. He has a history of alcohol consumption for the past 30 years. Which of the following is the next best step in the management?

Vitals and laboratory findings:

  • BP: 138/90 mmHg
  • Pulse: 93 bpm
  • Temp: 101.8 F
  • WBC: 12,500/mm3
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points towards liver cirrhosis with ascites. The raised temperature and the increased WBC count are most likely due to spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. Paracentesis and ascitic fluid analysis is the next best step in the management of this patient.

Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) is the spontaneous infection of the ascitic fluid without an intraabdominal source. Abdominal paracentesis within 12 hours of admission is the investigation of choice. The diagnosis of SBP is made when the ascitic fluid has an absolute neutrophil count >250/μL.

Infection with E.coli and other gut bacteria is most commonly seen. However, gram-positive bacteria like Streptococcus viridans, Staphylococcus aureus, and Enterococcus sp., can also be found.

Management: The first line of empirical treatment is with a third-generation cephalosporin or a combination of beta-lactam/beta-lactamase agents. In patients who have had an episode of SBP and recovered, prophylactic antibiotics are given to prevent a recurrence.

Other options:

Option A- Liver biopsy is the gold standard for the diagnosis of liver cirrhosis. It determines the grading of inflammation and staging of fibrosis of the liver. Ultrasonography, CT, and MRI are not sensitive to detect liver cirrhosis. It is not the next best step for this patient.

Option B- The administration of fluids is not the best next step for this patient.

Option D- Administration of furosemide and spironolactone is done for the treatment of ascites along with dietary restrictions. However, the patient has a fever and abdominal pain which is a concern for SBP, for which diuresis is not indicated.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents with left eyelid swelling for the past two days and denies any history of ocular trauma. He reports that he had a mild flu-like illness one week back for which he took some medications. He is febrile. Ophthalmic examination reveals normal visual acuity with no ophthalmoplegia and no proptosis.  What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with eyelid swelling and fever following an infection without proptosis, and ophthalmoplegia with normal visual acuity are suggestive of preseptal cellulitis/ periorbital cellulitis.

Preseptal cellulitis is an infection of the subcutaneous tissues anterior to the orbital septum. The commonly implicated bacteria include Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pyogenes.

The mode of spread of infection can occur through skin trauma, insect bites, acute hordeolum, dacryocystitis, conjunctivitis, sinusitis, Upper respiratory tract infection, and middle ear infection.

Clinical features include,

  • Tender, firm, erythematous eyelid swelling
  • Conjunctiva - usually no chemosis
  • Proptosis - absent
  • Ocular movements - normal
  • Visual acuity - normal
  • Systemic symptoms: fever, leucocytosis

Treatment: 

  • Antibiotics - oral or i.v depending on severity.
  • Systemic analgesics
  • Warm compresses

Complications include spread of infection and may develop into orbital cellulitis, abscess formation, meningitis, cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Option A:  Endophthalmitis is the inflammation of the inner coats of the eye due to intraocular colonization of infectious agents. There is exudation within intraocular fluids. It generally occurs after trauma, surgery, or due to an endogenous source. It is characterized by poor visual acuity, corneal edema, hypopyon, vitreous inflammation, and poor fundus visualization. 

Option B: Orbital cellulitis refers to the acute infection of the contents of the orbit behind the orbital septum. Features include:

  • Pain, lid edema, erythema, chemosis, and axial proptosis.
  • Increased pain with movement of eyes and ophthalmoplegia (decreased ocular motility) is a classic symptom
  • A rapid loss of vision is due to the involvement of the optic nerve, diplopia.
  • Systemic symptoms include malaise and fever.
The image shown below is of a patient with orbital cellulitis and orbital apex syndrome presenting with complete ptosis, proptosis, total ophthalmoplegia, chemosis, and congestion.

Option D- Lid tumors can be variable in etiology. A few examples include squamous papilloma (raspberry-like growth), eyelid actinic keratosis (yellow plaque-like lesions), or capillary hemangiomas (bright red colored lesions over the eyelids).

questions.text: A month-old neonate was brought to the outpatient department with fever, poor feeding, and lethargy. His respiratory rate was high, and you suspect pneumonia. What respiratory rate would be defined as fast breathing in this child?
questions.solution:
A neonate or an infant within 2 months of age presenting with a respiratory rate of more than 60 breaths/minute is considered to have fast breathing.

If the infant has >60 breaths/minute, it is advised to recount, as respiration in infants is usually erratic, and some infants may stop breathing for a few seconds, and rapidly breathe later.

Three key clinical signs are used to assess a sick child with a cough or difficulty breathing:

  • Respiratory rate: It distinguishes children who have pneumonia from those who do not. A child is said to have rapid breathing if he/she has
    • >60 breaths/minute for infants aged less than two months.
    • >50 breaths/minute for infants aged 2 months to 12 months.
    • >40 breaths/minute for children aged 12 months to 5 years of age.
  • Lower chest wall indrawing
    • Indicates pneumonia
  • Stridor
    • Indicates severe pneumonia requiring hospital admission

According to the recent WHO guidelines, children with fast breathing with/without chest indrawing are classified as having "pneumonia."

Danger signs of severe pneumonia:

  • Not able to drink
  • Convulsions
  • Lethargic or unconscious
  • Stridor in a calm child
  • Severe malnutrition

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient came with complaints of pain over the heel that is most severe while taking the first step in the morning. On examination, localized tenderness was present over the medial aspect beneath the heel. A radiograph of his foot is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of pain and tenderness over the heel which worsens on standing or walking after rest and an X-ray showing a calcaneal spur is suggestive of plantar fasciitis. 

Plantar fasciitis is a painful condition of the sole of the foot that limits normal functions. The plantar fascia or aponeurosis is seen to be thickened, stiff, and may have micro-tears. Typically, the pain worsens while patients stand or walk from a resting position, often when waking up in the morning.

They have a localized tenderness at the medial aspect beneath the heel. An X-ray often shows a calcaneal spur which is associated with plantar fasciitis.

It is managed with proper rest and NSAIDs. Night splints can be used for the prevention of stiffening of the plantar fascia.

Other options:

Option A: Achilles tendinitis is a condition with pain and swelling around the Achilles tendon due to local irritation. It's often seen in athletes and hikers. 

Option C: Traction apophysitis is a traction injury. It is also known as Sever's disease. It is predominantly seen in boys of age around 10 years. They mostly present with pain and tenderness at the Achilles tendon insertion. X-ray shows increased density and fragmentation of the apophysis. 

Option D: Tarsal tunnel syndrome is a condition with pain and sensory disturbance occurring in the medial part of the forefoot, unrelated to weight-bearing. This is due to compression of the posterior tibial nerve behind and below the medial malleolus. Typically the pain worsens at night and gets relieved on walking or stamping the foot.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented with pain and swelling in the knee joint. The physician advised for the examination of synovial fluid from the knee joint on polarized light microscopy, which showed needle-shaped crystals. What is the composition and birefringence pattern shown by these crystals?

choices.text: Monosodium urate crystals with negative birefringence
Calcium pyrophosphate crystals with negative birefringence
Calcium oxalate crystals with positive birefringence

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the presence of needle-shaped crystals in synovial fluid point towards the diagnosis of gouty arthritis. It is caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals (MSU), which are needle-shaped and show negative birefringence on polarized light microscopy.

The below image shows negative birefringent needle-shaped crystals seen in gout.

Other options:

Option A- Calcium apatite crystals can occur in areas of tissue damage (dystrophic calcification) and in hypercalcemic or hyperparathyroid states (metastatic calcification). Clumps of these crystals may appear as intra- or extracellular nonbirefringent globules or aggregates that stain purplish with Wright’s stain and bright red with alizarin red S.

Option C- Calcium pyrophosphate crystals (rhomboid-shaped) deposition is seen in pseudogout. These crystals are rod-shaped or rhomboid-shaped and are weakly positive or nonbirefringent crystals.

Option D- Calcium oxalate crystals (CaOx) are seen in chronic renal failure. These crystals can be deposited in visceral organs, blood vessels, bones, and joints. The synovial fluid analysis will show the presence of variable-shaped crystals (commonly bipyramidal crystals are seen) with variable birefringence to polarized light.

NOTE:

Though pseudogout is the condition in which the knee joint is most commonly involved, gout can also involve the knee joint.

Below image shows the crystals seen in pseudogout.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about the adductor canal except?

choices.text: Roof is bound by the fascia and sartorius

questions.solution:
All of the following statements are true about the adductor canal/Hunter's canal/subsartorial canal, except that femoral nerve is a content.

The adductor canal is an intermuscular space situated in the distal two-thirds of the medial aspect of the thigh. This canal extends from the apex of the femoral triangle to the distal attachment of the adductor magnus. On cross-section, it is triangular in shape. 

The adductor canal is bound anterolateral by the vastus medialis (option D), posteromedially by the adductor longus, and distal to the adductor longus by the adductor magnus. Its anteromedial boundary or the roof is by a strong and dense fascia (option A) that extends from the medial surface of the vastus medialis to the medial edge of the adductors longus and magnus. This fascia is below the sartorius muscle and hence is termed the subsartorial fascia. 

The contents of the adductor canal are:

  • Femoral artery (option C)
  • Femoral vein
  • Saphenous nerve
  • Nerve to vastus medialis
  • Descending genicular and muscular branches of the femoral artery

The femoral vessels travel through the adductor canal and enter the popliteal fossa via the adductor hiatus which is an opening in the adductor magnus tendon adjacent to the femoral shaft.

questions.text: During the ophthalmology postings of your internship, you notice the following instrument being used by one of the senior resident. This instrument could be used to

choices.text: Test the color vision of patients
Refine the power and axis of cylindrical lens
Measure the degree of heterotropia or heterophoria
To visualize the angle of anterior chamber

questions.solution:
The given image shows Jackson’s cross cylinder (flip-cross technique), which is used to refine the power and axis of the cylindrical lens during refraction.

Other options:

Option A: Nagel’s anomaloscope given below is used to tests color vision.

Option C: Maddox rod consists of parallel red or colorless cylinders stacked together. Maddox rod test is a macular function test used to measure the degree of heterotropia or heterophoria in cases of torsional diplopia.

Option D: Angle of the anterior chamber is visualized with the help of a gonioscope and slit lamp. The image given below shows goniolens used for gonioscopic examination.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient came to the physician with complaints of chronic back pain and easy fatigability.  An X-ray of his skull is shown below. Laboratory investigations show decreased hemoglobin, hypercalcemia, normal alkaline phosphatase, elevated ESR. He should be started on which of the following combination therapy?
questions.solution:
This patient's history and clinical findings are suggestive of multiple myeloma. Lenalidomide +Bortezomib+Dexamethasone is the treatment of choice in multiple myeloma.

This patient's anemia, hypercalcemia, normal alkaline phosphatase, elevated ESR are consistent with the diagnosis of multiple myeloma. The skull demonstrates the typical “punched out” lesions characteristic of multiple myeloma. 

Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone. Bone pain is the most common presenting symptom in multiple myeloma. The next most common clinical problem in patients with myeloma is susceptibility to bacterial infections. The most common infections are pneumonia and pyelonephritis, and the most frequent pathogens are Streptococcus pneumoniae, Staphylococcus aureus, and Klebsiella pneumoniae in the lungs and Escherichia coli and other gram-negative organisms in the urinary tract.

Chemotherapy followed by autologous stem cell transplantation prolongs overall survival in multiple myeloma patients.

The combination of lenalidomide, bortezomib, and dexamethasone achieves close to a 100% response rate making it one of the preferred induction regimens in transplant-eligible patients.

NOTE: The U.S. FDA has approved ABECMA, the first cell-based gene therapy to treat adult patients with multiple myeloma who have not responded to, or whose disease has returned after, at least four prior lines (different types) of therapy.

questions.text: An intern was asked to give an intravenous injection to a vein in the cubital fossa. All of the following are true about the cubital fossa except:

choices.text: Musculocutaneous nerve is one of the contents
Radial nerve enters the fossa laterally
Median cubital vein forms the roof

questions.solution:
All of the above statements are true about the cubital fossa except the musculocutaneous nerve is one of the contents.

The cubital fossa is a triangular depression present in the anterior side of the elbow joint. The boundaries of the cubital fossa include medially by the lateral border of the pronator teres, laterally by the medial border of the brachioradialis (option A), the base is formed proximally by an imaginary line joining the epicondyles of the humerus and the apex is pointed downwards by joining of the lateral and medial boundaries.

The roof is formed by the skin, superficial fascia containing median cubital vein (option D) joining the cephalic and basilic veins, lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm, medial cutaneous nerve of the forearm, bicipital aponeurosis, and deep fascia. The floor is formed by brachialis and supinator muscles.

The contents of the brachial fossa are (from medial to lateral side):

  • Median nerve
  • Brachial artery, terminating into radial and ulnar arteries
  • Biceps brachii tendon with the bicipital aponeurosis
  • Radial nerve enters the fossa laterally (option C) in the groove between the brachialis and brachioradialis

Clinical significance:

  • The median cubital vein is the most commonly preferred vein of choice for intravenous injections. 
  • Auscultation of the brachial artery in front of the elbow helps in measuring the blood pressure.

questions.text: In a society, people follow certain customs which they think are the right ways of doing things in the less vital areas of human conduct. These customs are called:
questions.solution:
The customs that are considered as the right ways of doing things in less vital areas of human conduct are called folkways.

Customs are the practices promoted by the conveniences of the individuals in a society. They can be folkways or mores. Folkways refer to as the right ways of doing things in less vital areas of human conduct. Mores (option B) are stringent customs followed by society.

Culture is the learned behavior that is socially acquired. It is passed onto generations through formal and informal learning. Culture is the representation of customs, beliefs, laws, arts, and moral values of a society. Cultural factors have a large part to play in health.

Other options:

Option C- Acculturation means "culture contact".There is a diffusion of culture when there is contact between two people with different types of culture. Different ways by which culture contact takes place are, 

  • Trade and commerce
  • Industrialization
  • Propagation of religion
  • Education
  • Conquest.

Option D- The role is the function or duties assumed by a person of a particular society.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male on multiple drugs presents with a round macule on his right leg for the last 7 days. The patient gives a history of similar episodes in the past which resolved spontaneously. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
This is a case of fixed drug eruption and the most likely cause is ibuprofen.

Fixed drug eruptions are characterized by sharply demarcated dull red to brown lesions. They occur in lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, and oral mucosa, and cause a burning sensation. The lesion recurs in the same locations upon re-exposure to the offending drug.

Some of the drugs commonly known to cause fixed drug eruptions are Sulphonamides, NSAIDs, Analgesics, and Hypnotics.

Diagnosis is based on history and lesion morphology. Discontinuation of the offending drug is the first step in management.

Phenytoin and carbamazepine can lead to Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) and drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome).

questions.text: A young man presents with multiple mucosal ulcers. On examination, Nikolsky sign is positive. Immunofluorescence microscopy shows the following finding. Which of the following is the most common target antigen for the antibodies in this disease?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the immunofluorescence showing the intercellular deposition of antibodies around the keratinocytes is suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris. Desmoglein 3 is the most common target antigen for the antibodies in pemphigus vulgaris.

Pemphigus vulgaris is caused due to the production of antibodies mainly against desmoglein 3. Rarely, antibodies against desmoglein 1 can also be found. The antibodies are commonly IgG antibodies.

Desmoglein 3 is mainly present in the basal and suprabasal layers of the skin and mucosa. The patients, therefore, present with flaccid bullae over the skin and mucosal ulcerations. Patients show a positive Nikolsky sign (on applying the pressure, the epidermis separates from the dermis).

Oral mucosa is commonly affected. Other areas where ulceration can be seen are the conjunctiva, nasopharynx, larynx, etc. Cutaneous lesions are more common over the scalp, face, neck, upper chest, and back.

Direct immunofluorescence will show the deposition of antibodies around the keratinocytes in the epidermis.

It is treated with steroids, azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil, rituximab, etc.

Other options:

Option A: Antibodies against desmoglein 1 are mainly seen in pemphigus foliaceous. They are visible as scattered, scaly lesions involving the seborrheic areas of the scalp, face, chest, and upper back. Mucosal involvement is not seen in this condition.

Option C: Desmoglein 2 is not a target for the antibodies in immunobullous diseases.

Option D: Antibodies against desmoplakin are found in paraneoplastic pemphigus. The lesion is commonly associated with non‐Hodgkin lymphoma, chronic lymphocytic leukemia, Castleman disease, thymoma, and Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia. It is characterized by stomatitis; conjunctivitis that may lead to scarring; and esophageal, genital mucosal, and flexural involvement, with bullous and erosive lesions.

questions.text: A 43-year-old diabetic woman notices that on the extension of her fingers, the middle finger requires extra force to extend and snaps while doing so. There is an audible click when the finger is flexed. The extension is as depicted below. This is caused due to the involvement of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The condition depicted in the video is a trigger finger which involves the flexor tendon.

Trigger finger is caused by stenosing tenosynovitis of the flexor sheath. There is nodular or fusiform swelling on the flexor tendon that prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. When the finger is flexed or extended, the nodular swelling passes through the A1 pulley with a snap, leading to a triggering effect. The nodule can get trapped behind the A1 pulley leading to a locking of the finger in flexion.

Surgical treatment involves the release of the A1 pulley, which is thickened and fibrosed. Early cases may be treated with a steroid injection into the tendon sheath.

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: A 26-year-old bride-to-be presented with nausea, vomiting, and recurrent episodes of postprandial epigastric pain. She has lost nearly 25 kgs in the last 6 months to look good in her wedding dress. Proton pump inhibitors were tried but were unsuccessful. A barium meal follow-through of the patient is given below. Which of the following is false about her condition?

choices.text: Weight gain is part of the management
Lying in prone position postprandially improves symptoms
The second part of duodenum is commonly involved

questions.solution:
The false statement about her condition is that the second part of the duodenum is commonly involved.

The given clinical scenario with rapid weight loss and the barium follow-through demonstrating dilation of the duodenum with an abrupt cut-off at its third part, coinciding with the line of the superior mesenteric artery is suggestive of superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome. The third part of the duodenum is involved in SMA syndrome. 

SMA syndrome (also known as Wilkie's syndrome) is usually seen in young asthenic women. It is a rare condition characterized by compression of the third portion of the duodenum by the SMA against fixed retroperitoneal structures.

SMA syndrome is associated with:

  • Rapid childhood growth
  • Profound weight loss
  • Abdominal surgery
  • Inflammatory diseases of the abdomen
  • Short ligament of Treitz
  • Immobilization in a cast that increases lordosis (cast syndrome)

Its clinical features include:

  • Episodic vomiting
  • Profound nausea
  • Abdominal distention
  • Postprandial epigastric pain

Upper gastrointestinal barium swallow or hypotonic duodenography demonstrates abrupt or near-total cut-off of the flow of barium from the duodenum to the jejunum. CT and magnetic resonance (MR) arteriography can also be used for additional anatomical detail.

The normal aortomesenteric angle is between 28-65 degrees. This is reduced to less than 25 degrees in SMA syndrome. A CT scan showing the reduced aortomesenteric angle is given below:

In SMA syndrome, initial conservative management includes:

  • Frequent small feedings 
  • Lying in a prone position or on the left side postprandially 
  • Weight gain (to increase mesenteric fat pad and thereby increase the aorto-mesenteric angle)
  • Removal of a body cast in cast syndrome 

Laparoscopic lysis of the ligament of Treitz is beneficial in few cases. If all the above treatments fail, duodenojejunostomy is done.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male patient with a history of gout and diabetes mellitus underwent regular investigations, which revealed elevated triglyceride and total cholesterol levels. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Niacin should be avoided in this patient due to the history of gout and diabetes mellitus.

Niacin should be used cautiously in diabetes mellitus as it induces insulin resistance that can cause severe hyperglycemia. Niacin can also result in hyperuricemia and may reactivate gout. Hence, a history of gout is a relative contraindication for niacin.

Niacin is a water-soluble B-complex vitamin and is the only vitamin that affects that lipid levels. Niacin acts by inhibiting the lipolysis of triglycerides by hormone-sensitive lipase in the adipose tissue. Niacin reduces the free fatty acid transport to the liver and decreases triglyceride synthesis by inhibiting both the synthesis and esterification of fatty acids. There is also a reduction of very-low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) cholesterol and low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol levels by decreasing their productivity and enhancing their clearance. High-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol levels are raised due to the decreased clearance of apo A-1 in HDL.

The indications of niacin are hypertriglyceridemia and elevated LDL cholesterol.

The most common serious side effect of niacin is hepatotoxicity. Other adverse effects of niacin include dyspepsia, cutaneous flushing, and pruritus. Flushing and pruritus can be controlled with aspirin as they are prostaglandin mediated. Concurrent use of niacin with a statin can result in myopathy. Niacin is avoided in pregnant females as it resulted in birth defects in experimental animals.

Other options:

Options A and B- Cholestyramine and colestipol are bile acid sequestrants. These are highly positively charged and bind to negatively charged bile acids resulting in their excretion in the stool. Hepatic cholesterol content reduces due to the increased bile acid synthesis. This increases the LDL receptors in the liver resulting in increased LDL cholesterol clearance. These agents are relatively safe but severe hypertriglyceridemia is a contraindication to its use as these agents increase the triglyceride levels.

Option C- Clofibrate is a halogenated fibric acid derivative. Fibrates bind to PPAR-α and reduce triglycerides through PPAR-α mediated stimulation of fatty acid oxidation, increased lipoprotein lipase synthesis, and reduced expression of apo C-III. The adverse effects include rash, urticaria, hair loss, myalgias, fatigue, headache, and impotence. Clofibrate can result in myopathy and gall stone formation. Fibrates should not be used in children or pregnant women. Renal failure and hepatic dysfunction are relative contraindications to the use of fibrates.

questions.text: A study was conducted on the efficacy of oral contraceptive pills. Out of 100 women who took the pills, 10 women became pregnant within 24 months. What is the Pearl Index?
questions.solution:
The Pearl index is calculated to be 5 per hundred woman years.

Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/Total months of exposure

In this scenario, the total number of accidental pregnancies is 10.

There are 100 couples who are exposed to the method.

So, the total months of exposure are 24 months x 100 = 2400.

We arrive at this: Pearl index = 10 x 1200/2400 = 5 per hundred woman-years

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady who was a victim of rape was brought by the lady constable to the gynecologist for examination. During the genital examination, the doctor obtained a sample from in and around the vagina. What test needs to be done on this sample to identify the presence of semen?
questions.solution:
The acid phosphatase test is used to identify seminal stains.

The prostatic secretion contains acid phosphatase. Semen recovered from the vagina retains acid phosphatase concentrations up to 36 hours after its deposition. It is expressed in Bodansky units. The acid phosphatase test is conclusive in case of the absence of demonstrable sperms or aspermia. 

The absolute proof of semen is finding at least one unbroken spermatozoon or electrophoretic LDH isoenzyme detection of sperms.

  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy came with complaints of toothache for a few days. Oral examination revealed the presence of dental caries. The bacteria isolated from the lesion demonstrates alpha hemolysis and the growth was not inhibited by optochin. Which of the following bacteria is commonly implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of dental caries with bacteria showing alpha hemolysis and optochin resistance is suggestive of streptococcus mutans.

Streptococcus mutans belong to the viridans group of streptococci and they are the common organism causing dental caries. Streptococcus mutans break down the dietary sucrose resulting in the production of acid and a tough adhesive dextran. The acid damages dentine while the dextrans bind together with food debris, epithelial cells, mucus, and bacteria to form dental plaques, leading to the formation of dental caries.

Viridans streptococci show alpha hemolysis on blood agar and are resistant to optochin. It includes:

  • Streptococci mitis 
  • Streptococci mutans
  • Streptococci salvarius
  • Streptococci sanguis (causes sub-acute bacterial endocarditis)

Other options:

Option B- Streptococcus pyogenes are beta-hemolytic and they mainly cause upper respiratory tract infection, pyoderma, rheumatic fever, and glomerulonephritis. 

Option C- Streptococcus bovis are gamma hemolytic and they mainly cause endocarditis. 

Option D- Streptoccoci agalacatcise are beta-hemolytic and they mainly cause neonatal meningitis, septicemia, and urinary tract infection.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with excruciating pain in her lips, gums, and cheeks for the past 6 months. The pain is usually triggered by talking and brushing her teeth. Each pain episode lasts for 1-2 minutes. On examination, there is no sensory loss over the face. Which of the following is the first-line management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of trigeminal neuralgia. The first-line management of this patient is carbamazepine.

Trigeminal neuralgia is a condition characterized by excruciating paroxysmal pain in the lips, gums, cheek, or chin and, rarely ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve. It is also known as tic douloureux (a painful condition of the face). It is commonly seen in middle-aged and elderly women. 

The large myelinated fibers of the trigeminal nerve carry tactile stimuli from the face and do not carry pain fibers themselves. In trigeminal neuralgia, due to compression or other pathologies, the large fibers undergo demyelination. These demyelinated large fibers become hyperexcitable and electrically coupled with the surrounding smaller unmyelinated pain fibers of the trigeminal nerve. This explains why tactile stimulation of trigger zones (lips, gums, cheek, or chin) leads to pain paroxysms. Symptoms occur due to ectopic generation of action potentials in pain-sensitive afferent fibers of the trigeminal nerve root just before entering the pons.

The pain may occur spontaneously or after movements like chewing, speaking, smiling, washing the face, brushing teeth, or exposure to wind. On examination, the physician will not find any sensory loss over the area. The pain usually lasts for seconds or minutes. The intensity of pain is severe, so much so that the patient winces. Therefore it is called a 'tic'.

Carbamazepine is the first-line drug in the management of patients with trigeminal neuralgia. Lamotrigine, Phenytoin, Topiramate, or Gabapentin are other options that may be tried if Carbamazepine is ineffective. Microvascular decompression of the trigeminal nerve can be done if medical therapies fail.

Differential diagnoses of trigeminal neuralgia include:

  • Migraine and cluster headaches - They tend to have deep-seated and continuous pain while trigeminal neuralgia has more of a superficial stabbing quality pain and is episodic. 
  • Short-lasting unilateral headache with conjunctival tearing (SUNCT) - It will typically present with unilateral conjunctival congestion, tearing, and nasal stuffiness. 
  • Temporal arteritis - It will usually be accompanied by myalgias and signs of systemic inflammation. ESR and CRP will be elevated.
  • If trigeminal neuralgia develops in a young patient or is bilateral, a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis should be considered. In such cases, the cause of the pain is a demyelinating plaque near the entry point of the trigeminal nerve in the pons.

questions.text: A drunk father was playing with his baby and fell asleep as shown in the image, resulting in the death of the baby. What type of suffocation is seen here?
questions.solution:
The type of suffocation seen in this scenario is overlaying.

Overlaying is a type of suffocation resulting from compression of the nose, mouth, and chest, preventing breathing. It occurs in cases when a parent, under the influence of alcohol shares the bed with an infant. The guardian accidentally rolls over the child during sleep, leading to accidental occlusion of the air passages. There will be limited movements of the thoracic cavity, resulting in the reduction or absence of respiratory movements. 

Postmortem findings: The face, nose, and chest of the child appear compressed and pale. The nostrils may be filled with blood-stained froth. The usual findings of asphyxia like intrathoracic petechiae may be found. Death occurs as a result of neurogenic cardiac arrest.

Medicolegal importance: It can be purely accidental. It may also be a case of infanticide. 

Other options:

Option A: Traumatic asphyxia is a type of suffocation resulting from respiratory arrest due to mechanical fixation of the chest that prevents the normal movement of the chest.

Option B: Burking is a type of homicidal asphyxial death comprising of smothering and traumatic asphyxia. In burking, the assaulter kneels or sits on the chest of the victim, preventing chest movements, and then covers the nose and mouth of the victim with his hands. 

Below is the image showing burking.

Option C: Smothering is a type of suffocation resulting from blockage of the external respiratory orifices either by hand or any other means such as introducing a foreign object (paper, cloth).

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with an itchy elevated lesion on her face as shown in the image. On dermoscopy, there is an atypical pigmented network. From which structure is the cell responsible for this lesion derived?
questions.solution:
The given image shows asymmetrical pigmented lesion on the face with an irregular border. This is suggestive of malignant melanoma arising from the melanocytes. Melanocytes are derived from neural crest cells (NCC). 

During neurulation, when the neural folds elevate and fuse, the cells at the lateral border (the neural crest) of the neuroectoderm dissociate from their neighboring cells. These neural crest cells undergo an epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition while leaving the neuroectoderm and then migrate to the underlying mesoderm.

NCCs contribute to many organs and tissues and are sometimes referred to as the fourth germ layer:

  • In the trunk region, they form: 
    • Melanocytes
    • Sensory ganglia
    • Sympathetic and enteric neurons
    • Schwann cells
    • Adrenal medulla cells
  • In the cranial region, they contribute to the: 
    • Craniofacial skeleton
    • Neurons for cranial ganglia
    • Satellite glial cells
    • Melanocytes
  • Some of the other neural crest derivatives are:
    • C cells of the thyroid gland
    • Conotruncal septum in the heart
    • Odontoblasts
    • Smooth muscle cells to blood vessels to face and forebrain.

Option A: Lateral plate mesoderm is the lateral layer of the intraembryonic mesoderm. This is a thin layer. This layer develops a large cavity called the intraembryonic cavity and gives rise to a somatic or parietal mesodermal layer and a splanchnic or visceral mesodermal layer. The intraembryonic cavity gives rise to pericardial, pleural, and peritoneal cavities.

Option B: Intermediate mesoderm is a longitudinal strip of intraembryonic mesoderm that connects paraxial with the lateral plate mesoderm. The urinary and genital systems are derived from the intermediate mesoderm.

Option D: Paraxial mesoderm is the thickened plate of the intraembryonic mesoderm close to the midline, on either side of the notochord. This forms the somitomeres and somites.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient who has been diagnosed with aggressive pancreatic cancer presents with intractable abdominal pain unresponsive to opioids. The anesthetist decides to opt for a regional block. Which of the following would he choose?
questions.solution:
The block he would choose in a case of pancreatic cancer is celiac plexus block.

The celiac plexus block is indicated in patients with pain arising from the abdominal viscera, specifically intraabdominal cancers. 

The celiac ganglia are generally clustered at the level of the body of the L1 vertebra, posterior to the inferior vena cava on the right and lateral to the aorta on the left. It is posterior to the pancreas. 

The patient should be placed in a prone position and 15-20 ml of local anesthetic is injected under fluoroscopic, CT, or ultrasound guidance. The needle should be inserted 7-8 cm from the midline at the inferior edge of the spinous process of L1. 

The approaches that can be taken for this block include the posterior retrocrural approach, posterior anterocrural approach, posterior transaortic approach, and an anterior approach. 

The most common complication is postural hypotension. This occurs due to blocking of visceral sympathetic innervation which results in vasodilation. To prevent this, the patient should be adequately intravenously hydrated. 

Other complications include diarrhea (secondary to blockade of sympathetic fibers), pneumothorax, retroperitoneal hemorrhage and visceral organ injury.

Other options: 

Option A - The stellate block is indicated in patients with head, neck, arm, and upper chest pain. 

Option C - The lumbar sympathetic block is indicated in painful conditions involving the pelvis and lower extremities like a peripheral vascular disease. 

Option D - The superior hypogastric plexus block is indicated in pelvic pain that is unresponsive to lumbar or caudal epidural blocks. It is used in patients with cancer of the pelvic organs or non cancer pelvic pain.

questions.text: Which type of aquaporin is present in the portion of the nephron that is responsible for maximum reabsorption of Na +?
questions.solution:
Maximum reabsorption of Na + occurs in proximal convoluted tubules and Aquaporin 1 is present at this site in the kidney.

Despite a handful number of aquaporins present in the human body, the kidneys predominantly have the aquaporins 1, 2, 3, and 4.

Aquaporin 1 is present in the proximal convoluted tubules. It is localized to both the basolateral and apical membrane of the proximal tubules. Its presence allows water to move rapidly out of the tubule along the osmotic gradients and isotonicity is maintained. 

Aquaporin 2, which is located in the collecting duct is under the influence of the antidiuretic hormone (ADH). Interaction of ADH with V2 receptors in the basolateral membrane causes the insertion of aquaporin 2 channels in the apical membrane of the tubular cell to facilitate water reabsorption.

AQP-3 and AQP-4 are present on the basolateral side of the cell membrane, especially in the collecting ducts. They provide a path for water to rapidly exit the cells, and are not regulated by ADH.

HMG-CoA reductase is the rate-limiting enzyme of cholesterol synthesis.
