questions.text: An 11-month-old infant is brought with the given finding for the past 1 month. The mother is concerned that the lesions are itchy as the baby has been fussy and not sleeping well.  What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This image shows fish-like scales on the skin that is characteristic of ichthyosis vulgaris.

It is an autosomal dominant condition that is associated with filaggrin mutations. This leads to a reduction in the natural moisturizing factors (NMF) in the skin. It develops at 3-12 months of life and presents with generalized, itchy, small, light-grey scales and xerosis that are more marked over extensor surfaces and trunk. The groin and flexures are spared. 

X-linked recessive ichthyosis occurs only in males. It results in larger, dirty-brown scales.

questions.text: Some people underwent general health checkups at your hospital. This included a health questionnaire, clinical examination, and a range of biochemical tests on blood and urine specimens. This type of screening is an example of:
questions.solution:
The given scenario of annual health check-ups would be an example of multiphasic screening.

Multiphasic screening is the application of two or more screening tests in combination at one time to a large number of people instead of screening separately for individual diseases.

This procedure includes a health questionnaire, clinical examination, and investigations that can be performed rapidly with the appropriate staffing organization and equipment. 

Other options 

Options A and C-  High-risk or selective screening is done on high-risk groups. For example, MRI screening of breast is done annually in 25-year old women with BRCA 1, BRCA 2 mutations in the first-degree relative.

Option D- Mass screening is a screening of a whole or large population like using chest X-rays for TB screening in large populations. It is done for diseases with high prevalence.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman at 28 weeks of gestation presents with severe acute pain abdomen. Her past history is significant for a uterine fibroid. On examination, her temperature is 38.5°C and the uterus is tender. Investigations revealed leukocytosis and elevated ESR. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this case, there is a severe acute pain abdomen with fever and elevated leukocyte count in a 28-week pregnant woman with fibroid. Hence the most likely diagnosis is red degeneration of fibroid.

Red degeneration is the most common complication of fibroids in pregnancy. It is due to the breakdown of fibroid resulting in ischemia and pain. Key clinical features in this condition are:

  • Low-grade fever
  • Tender uterus on palpation
  • Elevated leukocytes
  • Elevated ESR

The diagnosis is confirmed with an ultrasound. It is usually self-limiting and can be managed with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

Other options

Option A - Calcareous degeneration of fibroid is associated with deposition of phosphates and carbonates in the periphery along the course of the vessels. It is seen in old patients with long-standing myomas. They are described as 'womb-stones' in graveyards. They can be detected on a plain X-ray of the abdomen.

Option B - Sarcomatous change of fibroid is rare in women <40 years of age. It is more commonly seen in a postmenopausal woman, who presents with a tumor which grows suddenly, causing pain and postmenopausal bleeding.

Option D - Torsion of fibroid is seen with pedunculated fibroids and can present with abdominal pain in pregnancy. However, it is not associated with fever and elevated leukocytes.

  • A pedunculated fibroid which can undergo torsion
  • A fibroid causing pressure on the ureter/ bladder, leaving residual urine and causing a urinary infection.
  • Rapidly growing fibromyoma in a menopausal woman implying impending malignancy
  • When the nature of the tumor cannot be ascertained clinically (laparotomy is needed on this occasion).

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy with persistent diurnal incontinence and abdominal distention is being evaluated for a posterior urethral valve. What is the investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) is the investigation of choice for evaluating the posterior urethral valve.

Posterior urethral valves (PUV) are obstructing membranous folds within the lumen of the posterior urethra, which hinders the outflow of urine from the urinary bladder. It may precipitate chronic renal disease in children. It is the most common cause of urinary tract obstruction in male newborns.

On performing a VCUG, the posterior urethral valve appears as a sharply defined perpendicular or oblique lucency in the distal prostatic urethra. The posterior urethra is dilated and elongated with a shield-like appearance. The bladder is trabeculated with clear demarcation of the hypertrophied bladder neck.

Children with PUV who are not diagnosed before birth may present with delayed voiding or a poor urinary stream. Infants are predisposed to repeated UTIs. Other common signs and symptoms may include a palpable abdominal mass, failure to thrive, lethargy, poor feeding, urosepsis, and urinary ascites. Older boys may have persistent diurnal incontinence or abdominal distention. Physical examination in the newborn reveals a palpable bladder. 

In addition, a VCUG can also be used for the evaluation of hydronephrosis, abnormalities of the bladder wall such as ureteroceles, calculi, foreign bodies, and to assess bladder emptying.

The below image shows a micturating cystourethrogram of PUV.

Prenatally, the urethral obstruction appears as a keyhole sign during the ultrasound. The most common cause for this is the posterior urethral valve.

The below image shows a keyhole sign of urethral obstruction. The white arrow points to the main hole and represents the distended urinary bladder. The black arrow points to the slit, which is the distended proximal urethra.

Other options:

Option A: Trans-rectal ultrasound scan (TRUS) is usually performed in conjunction with a biopsy of the prostate to diagnose prostate cancer. 

Option B: Renal nuclear scintigraphy with a technetium-99m-labeled dimercaptosuccinic acid can be used to visualize any abnormality or thinning of the renal parenchyma, like renal scarring.

Option D: A non-contrast CT scan is the investigation of choice in a patient with suspected urinary tract calculi.

  • Retrocaval ureter
  • Aberrant renal vessels
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (Ormond’s disease)

Intramural obstruction

  • Congenital PUJ obstruction - most common congenital cause
  • Congenital stenosis
  • Ureterocele
  • Ureteric stricture - iatrogenic/ inflammatory
  • Neoplasm of the ureter or bladder involving the ureteric orifice

  • Renal stones - most common acquired unilateral cause
  • Sloughed papilla in papillary necrosis (especially, in patients with diabetes, analgesic abuse, or sickle cell disease)

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman complains of difficulty in swallowing for the past few months. She also complains of bluish discoloration of fingers on exposure to cold for the past 5 years. On examination, she is found to have thickening of the skin of the hands and multiple dilated capillaries over the face. Which of the following is most specific for this disease?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of CREST syndrome / limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, and anti-centromere antibodies are most specific for this disease.

CREST syndrome consists of :

  • Calcinosis cutis
  • Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Esophageal dysmotility
  • Sclerodactyly
  • Telangiectasia

Systemic sclerosis (SSc) is a chronic autoimmune disease. Progressive fibrosis due to the deposition of extracellular matrix components in different tissue and organs is the prominent feature of SSc. 

The characteristic features of SSc are vascular damage, inflammation, and the presence of specific autoantibodies. 

SSc is classified into two based on the extent of skin involvement.

  • Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis / CREST syndrome
  • Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis

In limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc), fibrosis in the skin of acral parts of the body, like the face and limbs (distal to elbow and knee) takes place. 

Skin fibrosis in limited type has a slow progression but microcirculation disturbances like Raynaud's phenomenon start long before the skin symptoms and are associated with the involvement of the lungs and esophagus. 

Since it has late and slow organ involvement, it is associated with a good prognosis with a 10-year survival of over 90%. 

Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are present in 90 - 95% of cases with SSc.

Autoantibodies specific to Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis include,

  • Anti- centromere
  • Anti-Th/To
  • Anti-U1-RNP
  • Anti-hUBF

Management is based on disease-modifying and organ-specific drugs. For peripheral vasculopathy and digital ulcers, calcium channel blockers like nifedipine, amlodipine is used and for refractory cases, phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitors are recommended.

Intravenous prostanoids are used for the healing process of digital ulcers and the improvement of microcirculation. The commonly used immunosuppressants for skin fibrosis are methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, and mycophenolate mofetil. When these drugs are ineffective or contraindicated, low-dose glucocorticosteroids or rituximab (anti-CD20) are used. 

Other options:

Options A and C- Anti-ds DNA antibodies and  Anti-Sm antibodies are specific for SLE.

Option D- Anti-SRP antibodies are characteristically seen in necrotizing myopathies.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the outpatient department with complaints that the scrotum is sometimes empty. On examination,  stimulation of the skin of the scrotum or thigh causes the testis to ascend and temporarily disappear into the inguinal canal. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate method of management of this condition would be to advise no treatment.

This patient with complaints of temporary disappearance of testis from the scrotum and his examination findings are suggestive of retractile testis. A patient with retractile testis usually requires no treatment.

A retractile testis is a normally developed and descended testis that retracts back into the inguinal canal due to hyper-reflexive cremasteric muscle contraction.

Therefore any stimulation of the skin of the scrotum or thigh causes the testis to ascend and temporarily disappear into the inguinal canal. When the cremaster relaxes, the testis reappears in the scrotum.

The scrotum of a boy with such a retractile testis is normal, that is, normal rugosity is seen.

Chair test helps to differentiate retractile testis from ectopic testis because both of them involve the testis lying in an abnormal position. In this test, the young patient is asked to sit on a chair hugging his knees to his chest. This manoeuvre helps the retractile testis to get pushed down back to the bottom of the scrotum and retractile testis can be differentiated from the ectopic testis.

Other options:

Option B: Orchidectomy, removal of the testis is considered in cases of undescended testis if the incompletely descended testis is atrophic, particularly in the postpubertal boy if the other testis is normal.

Option C: Surgical exploration is the treatment of choice for testicular torsion. 

Option D: Orchidopexy is the treatment of choice for ectopic testis.

questions.text: A middle-aged man, who smokes around 8-9 cigarettes per day for the past 15 years presented with chronic cough and breathlessness. Initially, breathlessness was mild, but now it has gradually affected his day-to-day activities. A pulmonary function test showed FEV1/FVC to be 0.65 and FEV1 is 75% of the predicted value. What is the severity of the disease?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical vignette, the patient is a chronic smoker and has chronic progressive breathlessness, along with chronic cough. The diagnosis is likely to be chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. According to Gold's criteria, the severity of the disease in this patient is moderate.

The severity of COPD is assessed by using the Global Initiative for Lung Disease (GOLD) criteria. In pulmonary function testing, a postbronchodilator FEV1/FVC ratio of <0.70 is considered diagnostic for COPD. 

The Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease (GOLD) system categorizes COPD into following stages,

questions.text: Identify the instrument given in the image below:
questions.solution:
The image is that of a Bulldog clamp.

The utility of a bulldog clamp is as follows:

  1. To clamp the common hepatic duct to control the flow of bile during pancreaticoduodenectomy. 
  2. Clamping the middle colic artery during left colonic interposition, for oesophageal replacement. 
  3. Clamping of mesenteric vessels during Roux-en-y-replacement.

Other options: 

Option A: DeBakey's forceps are useful for holding vessel walls in vascular surgery. They allow the surgeon to grasp tissues firmly while minimising damage to the tissue held in the jaws of the forceps.

Option B: Payr's crushing clamp is a stout, heavy instrument with a double level in the handle and it crushes the bowel once applied. It is used in gastrectomy.

Option D: Lister’s sinus forceps are used for blunt dissection. It is used during Hilton's method of abscess drainage to break the bacterial loculi and is also used for inserting or removing packing in the sinus cavity.

questions.text: Which of the following components is a part of the Physical Quality of Life Index?
questions.solution:
Literacy rate is one of the components of the Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI). All other options are components of the human development index (HDI).

Physical Quality of Life Index measures three indicators:

  • Infant mortality rate
  • Life expectancy at age one
  • Literacy rate

For each indicator, the performance of a country is rated from 0 to 100, where 0 is the worst performance and 100 is the best performance. PQLI is calculated by taking the average of the three indicators, with equal weightage for each of the indicators. 

The index is used for international and national comparisons. It measures the results of social, economic, and political policies. The PQLI does not take into account the per capita income of the country. Therefore, the Middle Eastern countries that are rich, have a lower PQLI compared to Sri Lanka or the state of Kerala in India.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man was brought to the emergency room in a semi-conscious state after falling from his bike. He was intubated by the paramedics on the way to the emergency room. He opens his eyes to painful stimuli, and on observation of his posture, he is seen to have a decorticate posture. What would his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score be?
questions.solution:
The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score based on the given clinical scenario is E2 VNT M3.

It is calculated as follows:

  • E: Opening of the eyes to a painful stimulus - 2
  • V: Intubated. Thus, not testable - NT
  • M: Decorticate posturing - 3

GCS is used in the assessment of patients with a head injury.

Decorticate posture:

  • It is caused due to damage to the upper midbrain.
  • The upper limbs are flexed, lower limbs are extended with toes pointed slightly inward, and head is extended.
  • Decorticate posturing is given a score of 3 in best motor response in GCS.

Decerebrate posture:

  • It is caused due to damage to the lower midbrain and upper pons.
  • Here, lower extremities are extended with toes pointed inward and upper extremities extended with fingers flexed and forearms pronated. Neck and head are extended. 
  • Decerebrate posture has a score of 2 in best motor response in the GCS.

The below image shows decerebrate and decorticate posturing.

  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is brought with tremors of his hands at rest. His son says that he has difficulty initiating movements and seems to be moving very slowly. On examination, shuffling gait, pill-rolling tremors, and rigidity on passive arm movement are noted. Which of the following is not seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of Parkinson's disease. This condition is not associated with Pick cells and Pick bodies. They are seen in Pick’s disease or frontotemporal dementia.

In Parkinson's disease, there is loss of the substantia nigra neurons projecting to the striatum. This leads to pallor of the substantia nigra as well as a decrease or absence of dopamine in the striatum. This leads to slowing of movements and tremors.

Lewy Bodies are seen within the neurons of affected patients. They are filamentous projections of the protein α‐synuclein or ubiquitin. They are present in surviving neurons and can be found in the cortex.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male patient presented with severe restlessness, palpitations, facial flushing, and sweating. The patient had an episode of dysentery 2 days prior and had been prescribed medication for that. The patient reports taking alcohol 2 hours after his medications. Which of the following drug does not cause similar effects?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient developing symptoms like restlessness and flushing after taking alcohol after medication is suggestive of a disulfiram-like reaction. Among the given drugs, ofloxacin is not associated with a disulfiram-like reaction.

Some important drugs which cause a disulfiram-like reaction are:

  • Metronidazole, Tinidazole
  • Some cephalosporins like cefoperazone
  • 1st generation sulfonylureas like tolbutamide
  • Procarbazine

These drugs inhibit aldehyde dehydrogenase, similar to disulfiram. When alcohol is combined with these drugs, acetaldehyde accumulates and causes unpleasant symptoms like flushing, sweating, tachycardia, hypotension, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, and headache.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient is diagnosed with gastric carcinoma. Which of the following is the best investigation to assess the depth of cancer in locally invasive gastric carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Endoscopic ultrasound is the best investigation to assess the depth of cancer in locally advanced gastric cancer.

Endoscopic ultrasound is the most sensitive investigation used to assess the preoperative local staging of gastric carcinoma. Five layers of the gastric wall can be visualized and the depth of invasion (T component of the staging) of cancer can be assessed with more than 90% accuracy. It can also show enlarged perigastric and celiac lymph nodes. In addition, it can identify liver metastases and assess gastric emptying. 

The limitation of this investigation is operator dependency and it may underestimate the lymph node involvement as normal-sized nodes (<5 mm) may harbor metastasis.

Other options:

Option A- MRI has a higher sensitivity in detecting liver metastasis of gastric carcinoma than conventional CT imaging.

Option B- CT scan of the abdomen/pelvis with intravenous and oral contrast is the best in preoperative staging of gastric cancer. However, it lacks sensitivity in detecting smaller lesions and is less accurate in T staging than endoscopic ultrasound.

Option C- Barium swallow is up to 75% sensitive in gastric tumors but has been replaced with endoscopic ultrasound in most centers as it is the gold standard for the diagnosis of gastric carcinoma.

questions.text: A middle-aged female dead body was retrieved from a lake. On postmortem examination, adipocere formation was noted in the face, breast, buttock and abdomen. All of the following statements about adipocere formation are true except:

choices.text: Occurs due to hydrolysis of body fat
Has distinct sweetish offensive or ammoniacal odor
Time since death cannot be determined
Warm, moist environment promotes adipocere formation

questions.solution:
All the above statements about adipocere formation are true except the time since death cannot be determined.

Adipocere is a modification of putrefaction. It is characterized by the formation of a waxy, soft, moist and whitish substance with a sweetish offensive or ammoniacal (early stages) odor. It is more commonly seen in bodies recovered from damp, warm environments or immersed in water.

Adipocere consists primarily of fatty acids that are produced due to postmortem hydrolysis and hydrogenation of body fats. These combine with calcium and ammonium ions to form insoluble acidic soaps that inhibit putrefactive bacteria. This is a water-dependent process. The factors that promote adipocere formation are warm, moist, anaerobic environment, females, well-nourished mature newborn babies, obesity, and dead bodies immersed in water for a long period.

The pattern of distribution includes areas of fatty tissues in the dead body. It first forms in the subcutaneous tissue and most commonly in the face, breast, buttock, and abdomen.

The rate of adipocere formation is variable and depends on the surrounding temperature. In India, it begins with 4 to 5 days of death. Complete conversion to adipocere requires at least 3 to 6 months.

Medicolegal importance - Well-preserved facial features in adipocere formation can help in identification. The time since death and the cause of the death can be determined as the injuries can be recognised.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old G2P1L1 at 36 weeks of gestation comes to the emergency with complaints of decreased fetal movement. Sonography shows elevated MCA peak systolic velocity and you suspect a feto-maternal hemorrhage. Which of the following is the most accurate test to determine the quantity of feto-maternal bleed in this case?

MCA- Middle cerebral artery
questions.solution:
Flow cytometry is the best test for the quantification of fetomaternal hemorrhage. It is more sensitive and accurate as compared to the Kleihauer-Betke test. 

Flow cytometry can analyze a larger number of cells and is not influenced by maternal levels of fetal hemoglobin and fetal levels of maternal hemoglobin. It utilizes monoclonal antibodies to haemogliobin F or D antigen followed by quantification by fluorescence. 

The most common presenting complaint with significant fetomaternal hemorrhage is decreased fetal movement. Ultrasonography demonstrates elevated MCA peak systolic velocity which is the most accurate predictor of fetomaternal hemorrhage.

The most common test used is the acid elution or the Kleihauer-Betke test. It detects fetal cells in the maternal circulation. It works on the principle that hemoglobin F is more resistant to acid elution as compared to hemoglobin A, thus on exposing the blood to acid, fetal RBCs containing HbF stay red, whereas the adult RBCs with HbA appear as ghost cells. Fetal cells are then counted and expressed as a percentage of the adult cells.

It is inaccurate in maternal hemoglobinopathies (high maternal HbF) and near term/term pregnancies (Fetal HbA production)

 

Causes of feto-maternal hemorrhage-

  • Pregnancy loss
    • Ectopic
    • Spontaneous abortion
    • Elective abortions
    • Fetal death
  • Procedures
    • Chorionic villus sampling
    • Amniocentesis
    • Fetal blood sampling
    • Evacuation of molar pregnancy
  • Placental
    • Abruption
    • Previa
    • Chorioangioma
    • Vasa previa
    • Manual placenta removal 
  • Others
    • Delivery 
    • Abdominal trauma 
    • Unexplained vaginal bleeding 
    • External cephalic version

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with visual disturbances and fatigue. He finds it difficult to see in the dark for the past few months. There is a tingling sensation in his upper limbs. On examination, there is weakness, sensory loss and dry scaly patches over both lower limbs as shown in the picture, which responds to emollients. The enzyme deficiency likely to be seen in this patient is:
questions.solution:
The enzyme deficiency likely to be seen in this patient is phytanoyl CoA α-hydroxylase.

The clinical features of this patient represent Refsum’s disease and the enzyme deficient is phytanoyl CoA α-hydroxylase, also known as phytanic acid alpha oxidase.

The given image shows ichthyosis of the shin and the patient complaints of poor vision with extremely affected dark/night vision which is suggestive of retinitis pigmentosa.

It occurs due to a defect in the enzyme phytanoyl-CoA hydroxylase (PAHX). It typically occurs in individuals between 10-15 years. Refsum disease is a rare, autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of peroxisomal Phytanoyl CoA α-hydroxylase, an enzyme involved in the alpha oxidation of phytanic acid (branched-chain fatty acid). This results in the accumulation of phytanic acid in the plasma and tissues.

The manifestation of classic adult Refsum disease includes

  • Ichthyosis
  • Retinitis pigmentosa
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Ataxia
  • Occasionally cardiac arrhythmias
  • cardiac conduction defects
  • elevated cerebrospinal fluid protein levels without an increase in cells.

It can be diagnosed by elevated levels of phytanic acid and decreased activity of PAHX in the fibroblasts. very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA) levels are normal in this condition.

Treatment: Restriction of dietary phytanic acid (found in dairy products, fish oils, and green leafy vegetables).

Infantile Refsums disease is a distinct entity, which presents at one to six months of age with severe developmental delay but generally without the dysmorphic features.

The given image shows fundoscopic findings of retinitis pigmentosa characterized by 

  • Attenuated arteries
  • Waxy and pale optic disc
  • Bony pigmented spicules

questions.text: A patient has profuse bleeding upon the removal of a cannula after a small bowel resection. He was given broad-spectrum antibiotics during his hospital admission. His lab investigations show an elevated prothrombin time (PT). The deficiency of which of the following vitamins is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The deficiency of vitamin K is responsible for this.

Patients with vitamin K deficiency usually present with a history of bleeding either at venipuncture sites or minor trauma. Additionally, broad-spectrum antibiotics can precipitate Vitamin K deficiency by reducing the numbers of gut bacteria, which synthesize menaquinones. Vitamin K deficiency in adults may be seen in patients with chronic small-intestinal diseases like celiac disease, Crohn’s disease, obstructed biliary tracts, and after small-bowel resection.

Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin that has two natural forms: Vitamin K1, also known as phylloquinone, from vegetable sources, and vitamin K2, or menaquinones, which are synthesized by bacterial flora and found in hepatic tissue.

Vitamin K is required for the posttranslational carboxylation of glutamic acid, which is necessary for calcium binding to γ-carboxylated proteins such as

  • prothrombin (factor II)
  • factors VII, IX, and X
  • protein C, protein S
  • proteins found in bone-like osteocalcin

Warfarin-type drugs inhibit γ-carboxylation by preventing the conversion of vitamin K to its active hydroquinone form.

Vitamin K is found in green leafy vegetables such as kale and spinach, and good amounts are also found in margarine and liver. Vitamin K is present in vegetable oils like olive, canola, and soybean oils.

Vitamin K deficiency usually is diagnosed on the basis of an elevated prothrombin time or reduced clotting factors. Vitamin K deficiency is treated with a parenteral dose of 10 mg. For patients with chronic malabsorption, 1–2 mg/d should be given orally or 1–2 mg per week can be taken parenterally.

Other options:

Option A: Riboflavin or Vitamin B2 deficiency manifests as angular stomatitis, magenta tongue, seborrhea, corneal vascularization. It is seen in alcoholism, and individuals with a poor diet and decreased intake of dairy products.

Option B: Vitamin E deficiency manifests as peripheral neuropathy, spinocerebellar ataxia, skeletal muscle atrophy, and retinopathy. Usually seen with fat malabsorption or genetic abnormalities of vitamin E metabolism.

Option C: Niacin deficiency manifests as pellagra, which includes symptoms of diarrhea, a pigmented rash over sun-exposed areas, bright red tongue, memory loss, and altered sensorium. Alcoholism, vitamin B6 deficiency, riboflavin, and tryptophan deficiencies predispose to this condition.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with distal leg weakness reduced muscle stretch reflexes, with no complaints of tingling or numbness. On examination, there is atrophy of the muscles below the knee. The following clinical findings are seen. The most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The given image shows muscle atrophy, high arch of the foot, and hammer-toes, which, along with the other clinical features mentioned above, are suggestive of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease.

Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease (CMT) is the most common type of hereditary neuropathy. CMT is a syndrome of many genetically distinct disorders.

CMT type 1 is the most common form of hereditary neuropathy. It usually presents in the first to third decade of life with distal leg weakness, e.g., foot drop. The following findings are seen:

  • No numbness or tingling
  • Reduced sensation to all modalities apparent on examination
  • Reduced muscle stretch reflexes
  • Atrophy of the muscles below the knee, leading to inverted champagne bottle legs 

Diabetic neuropathy, primary amyloidosis, neuropathy associated with Sjogren’s syndrome, and rheumatoid arthritis are acquired forms of neuropathies.

Other options:

Option B- Refsum's disease is a hereditary disorder of lipid metabolism. They can manifest in infancy to early adulthood with classic tetrad of:

  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Retinitis pigmentosa
  • Cerebellar ataxia
  • Elevated CSF protein concentration

They have elevated serum phytanic acid, and they are autosomal recessive. 

Option C- Sjogren syndrome is a chronic, slowly progressing autoimmune disease characterized by lymphocytic infiltration of the exocrine glands. Predominately seen in middle-aged women. The majority of them present with impaired lacrimal and salivary gland function. Neuropathy associated with Sjogren's syndrome is either sensory or sensorimotor polyneuropathy like mononeuritis multiplex and myelitis.

Option D- Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disease characterized by symmetric polyarthritis. The incidence increases between the ages of 25 and 55 years. Chronic inflammation of the ankle and midtarsal regions leads to pes planovalgus or flat feet. Other deformities seen in RA are: 

  • Swan-neck deformity
  • Boutonniere deformity
  • Z-line deformity

Related Pearl: Neuropathic Disorders

Hereditary neuropathic disorders 

  • Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (Most common hereditary neuropathy)
  • Tangier disease
  • Friedreich’s ataxia
  • Familial Amyloid Polyneuropathy
  • Hereditary Neuropathy with Liability to Pressure Palsies (HNPP)
  • Hereditary Neuralgic Amyotrophy (HNA)
  • Hereditary Sensory and Autonomic Neuropathy (HSAN)
  • Fabry’s disease (angiokeratoma corporis diffusum)
  • Refsum’s disease

Causes of acquired neuropathies

  • Primary or AL amyloidosis
  • Diabetic neuropathy
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Sjögren’s syndrome
  • Rheumatoid arthritis (RA)
  • Scleroderma, Sarcoidosis
  • Infectious (VZV,CMV,EBV,Hepatitis, HIV, Diphtheria, Leprosy) 
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Critical illness polyneuropathy (CIP)
 

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits. 

Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), hallux valgus (shown below), hammertoe.

Windswept deformities of toes - Valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in the other foot. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis.

questions.text: A 62-year old woman was admitted for further management of a retrosternal goiter. CT imaging showed the goiter extending into the anterior mediastinum, beyond the sternum up to the superior aspect of the aortic arch. How is this case further managed?
questions.solution:
A retrosternal goiter that does not cross the superior aspect of the aortic arch can be resected via the standard transcervical thyroidectomy incision.

Most retrosternal goiters can be resected via standard cervical thyroidectomy incision since most are anterior and do not extend lower than the superior aspect of the aortic arch, on cross-sectional imaging. Proper neck extension, patient positioning, and a longer incision with mobilization of strap muscles improve access and help in the resection of the entire goiter.

Sternal split and partial or even total median sternotomy may be done in:

  • Malignant or revision cases
  • Extending into the posterior mediastinum
  • Extending below the aortic arch
  • Crossing the midline
  • When the diameter of the goiter exceeds that of the thoracic inlet

Thoracic surgery assistance is often needed for the more difficult substernal goiters requiring sternotomy or other mediastinal access.

In elderly patients with incidental retrosternal goiters, observation is preferred over treatment.

Substernal (or retrosternal) goiters include a significant proportion of the gland extending into the mediastinum through the thoracic inlet. 60% of cases occur among patients above 60 years of age. Subtypes of retrosternal goiter:

  • Extension into the anterior mediastinum, which is the most common.
  • Extension posteriorly to the great vessels, trachea, and/or recurrent laryngeal nerve, occasionally into the contralateral neck.
  • Isolated mediastinal goiter with no connection to the normal gland, receiving blood supply from the chest (least common)

Retrosternal goiters are associated with local compressive symptoms such as shortness of breath, orthopnea and dysphagia. This is due to the mediastinal extension of the gland which compresses the trachea, esophagus, and vascular structures within the thoracic inlet.

questions.text: A 65-year-old hypertensive man presents with acute pain in the chest which radiates to the interscapular region of the back. He is diagnosed to have aortic dissection. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: Involvement of only the descending aorta requires emergency surgical repair
Can be associated with Marfan syndrome

questions.solution:
The management of aortic dissection that involves only the descending aorta (Stanford type B) is antihypertensive drugs, not emergency surgery.

Aortic dissection occurs due to the formation of a defect in the intima of the aorta, leading to the tracking of the blood through the layers of the aorta, splitting the medial layer, and thus forming a false lumen. The predisposing factors to aortic dissection include:

  • Hypertension
  • Marfan syndrome and other disorders of connective tissue that can cause degeneration of the tunica media of the aorta, like Ehlers–Danlos syndrome and giant cell arteritis.
  • Pregnancy

The patients present with a sudden onset, tearing interscapular pain with dyspnea. General physical examination may show hypotension or hypertension and loss of pulses. Extension of the dissection in either direction can lead to symptoms related to the organ with compromised perfusion, as given below:

  • Proximal extension can involve head and neck vessels (causing stroke or transient ischemic attack), coronary vessels (causing myocardial infarction) and the root of the aorta (causing aortic regurgitation).
  • Distal extension can involve renal arteries (acute kidney injury), mesenteric arteries (mesenteric ischemia), spinal arteries (paraplegia) and iliac arteries (acute limb ischemia).
  • The dissection may also result in aortic wall rupture into the pericardium (cardiac tamponade) or mediastinum (left haemothorax).

Transesophageal echocardiography can be done at the bedside in patients who are too unstable for transportation. In otherwise stable patients, the diagnosis is established by a CT scan. Depending on the part of the aorta involved, aortic dissections are classified as shown in the image below. 

 

The initial management of patients diagnosed with aortic dissection (irrespective of the type) is to control hypertension and pain. A β-blocker is used parenterally, such as intravenous esmolol, to control the BP and reduce the heart rate. Sodium nitroprusside can be further added to reduce the systolic pressure to <120 mmHg.

Further management depends on the type of aortic dissection. In Stanford type A dissections, surgical intervention is required. In type B dissections, antihypertensive management is usually enough. Further intervention is indicated in type B dissections if:

  • There is an increase in the pain — which could be a sign of impending rupture
  • Dissection is associated with signs of reduced perfusion of organ or limb

In these complicated type B dissections, percutaneous endovascular stenting is done. Surgery is reserved for patients in whom this procedure fails.

questions.text: Which of the following findings would you not expect in a female approaching menopause?

choices.text: Fall in the level of Inhibin A
Rise in the level of FSH

questions.solution:
A fall in the level of Inhibin B (not Inhibin A) is seen in women who are approaching menopause.

Menopause is defined as the time of cessation of ovarian function resulting in permanent amenorrhoea.

Prediction of approaching menopause

  • A fall in the level of inhibin B causes a rise in FSH level
  • A fall in the level of anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) suggests low ovarian reserve and low antral follicular count
  • A rise of FSH, which is more than normal LH level 

The study of FSH levels on days 2–5 after the last menstrual period is used to detect the premenopausal stage. Perimenopause is defined as a time period 3–4 years before menopause and followed by 1 year of amenorrhoea.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old man presented with weight loss, easy fatiguability, and bone pain for 6 months duration. A bone marrow aspirate is shown in the image below. Immunohistochemistry was negative for tDt but was positive for MPO. Cytogenetic studies revealed the presence of t(15:17). What is the likely diagnosis in this case?

MPO: Myeloperoxidase

TDT : Terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase 

Hb- 9g/dl

RBC-1million/cumm

WBC-50,000/cumm

Platelet-30,000/microliter
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of an elderly man presenting with anemia, thrombocytopenia, positive MPO in immunohistochemistry, characteristic translocation(15;17), and peripheral smear showing faggot cells is suggestive of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

AML is a hematopoietic progenitor malignancy that causes immature myeloblast accumulation in the bone marrow.  Incidence increases with age and peaks after 60 years of age. Occupational exposure to benzene leads to epoxide formation which in turn predisposes to the development of AML. Clinically, the patients present with symptoms resulting due to pancytopenia (anemia, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia). There is generalised fatigue, bone pain, bleeding tendencies and an increased risk of recurrent infections. Hemorrhagic complications such as disseminated intravascular coagulation may be seen more commonly in a subtype of AML, acute promyelocytic leukemia.

Other distinctive features of AML include

  • Bone marrow/peripheral smear shows a large, uniform population of cells (myeloblasts) with prominent nucleoli (yellow arrow). It shows the presence of primary cytoplasmic granules
  • Auer rods: needle-shaped azurophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies formed by the fusion of lysosomes. (black arrow)
  • Multiple Auer rods clustered together within a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks known as faggot cells (seen in peripheral smear).
  • This is characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukemia (AML M3) or AML associated with PML-RARɑ fusion gene or t(15;17). Other cytogenetic abnormalities, seen in AML are t(8;21) and inversion 16. 

For acute myeloblastic leukemia (AML) diagnosis, the blast cell count should be ≥20% in the peripheral blood or bone marrow

The treatment of choice for AML-M3 with t(15;17) is all-trans-retinoic acid (ATRA).

Other options:

Option A- Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) arises from immature B (pre-B) or T (pre-T) cells called lymphoblasts. Immunohistochemistry for terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) is positive in pre-B and pre-T lymphoblasts. Peripheral smear shows lymphoblasts that have condensed chromatin, less conspicuous nucleoli, and smaller amounts of cytoplasm which lacks granules as shown below.

Option B- Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia is associated with the deletions of 13q, 11q, 17q, and trisomy 12q. Lymph nodes are diffusely effaced by small lymphocytes with proliferation centres. The image shows small round lymphocytes and smudge cells seen in CLL.

Option D- Chronic myeloid leukemia is characterised by the presence of a Philadelphia chromosome resulting from reciprocal translocation t(9;22) forming the BCR-ABL fusion gene. They have a hypercellular marrow due to a massively increased number of maturing granulocytic precursors. The image below shows peripheral smear findings of CML with neutrophils, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and band cells.

Related Pearl: WHO classification of Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)

The 5th edition of WHO (2022) classification classifies acute myeloid leukemia (AML) as follows:

AML with defining genetic abnormalities (gene or chromosome changes):

  • Acute promyelocytic leukemia with PML::RARA fusion
  • AML with RUNX1::RUNX1T1 fusion
  • AML with CBFB::MYH11 fusion
  • AML with DEK::NUP214 fusion
  • AML with RBM15::MRTFA fusion
  • AML with BCR::ABL1 fusion
  • AML with KMT2A rearrangement*
  • AML with MECOM rearrangement
  • AML with NUP98 rearrangement
  • AML with NPM1 mutation
  • AML with CEBPA mutation
  • AML, myelodysplasia-related#
  • AML with other defined genetic alterations

 AML, defined by differentiation:

  • AML with minimal differentiation
  • AML without maturation
  • AML with maturation
  • Acute basophilic leukaemia
  • Acute myelomonocytic leukaemia
  • Acute monocytic leukaemia
  • Acute erythroid leukaemia
  • Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia

Most AML with defining genetic abnormalities are diagnosed with < 20% blasts except AML with BCR: ABL1 and AML with CEBPA mutation that require at least 20% blasts for diagnosis.

*AML with KMT2A rearrangement is the new term that replaces “AML with t(9;11)(p22;q23); KMT2A-MLLT3

#AML with myelodysplasia-related changes has been renamed as AML, myelodysplasia-related (AML-MR).

questions.text: An autopsy of a male patient who died in a road traffic accident was done. The structure marked as "A" was injured. Which of the following muscles is affected in the injury of this marked structure?
questions.solution:
The muscle affected in the injury of the marked structure "A" is sternohyoid.

The structure marked as A in the above image is the inferior root of ansa cervicalis.

Ansa cervicalis is a loop of nerves that are a part of the cervical plexus. It is made up of two roots. The superior root has contributions from the first cervical spinal nerve and the inferior root has contributions from the second and third cervical spinal nerves. The superior root (descendens hypoglossi) emerges out of the hypoglossal nerve and curves around the occipital artery. It descends anterior to the carotid sheath. 

The inferior root (descendens cervicalis) descends on the lateral side of the internal jugular vein and continues downwards to join the superior root anterior to the common carotid artery, forming the ansa cervicalis (ansa hypoglossi).

The two roots after joining innervate the sternohyoid, sternothyroid, and inferior belly of omohyoid muscles. The superior root before joining with the inferior root provides innervation to the superior belly of the omohyoid muscle.

Other options:

Options B and C- Thyrohyoid and geniohyoid are not supplied by ansa cervicalis. They are supplied by the first cervical spinal nerve, via the hypoglossal nerve.

Option D- Stylohyoid is supplied by the stylohyoid branch of the facial nerve.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy presents with acute onset of testicular pain. On examination, the left testis is enlarged and tender. Histopathological examination of orchidectomy specimen shows intense congestion, widespread hemorrhage, and areas of infarction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of testicular torsion.

Testicular torsion is typically seen in adolescence and presents with the sudden onset of testicular pain.

It results from a bilateral anatomic defect that leads to increased mobility of the testes (bell­clapper abnormality). Twisting of the spermatic cord typically cuts off the venous drainage of the testis. But, thick-walled arteries remain patent, producing intense vascular engorgement, followed by hemorrhagic infarction.

The morphologic changes range from intense congestion to widespread hemorrhage to testicular infarction depending on the duration of torsion. In advanced stages, the testis is markedly enlarged and consists entirely of soft, necrotic, hemorrhagic tissue.

If the testis is manually untwisted within approximately 6 hours of the onset of torsion, there is a good chance that the testis will remain viable. Contralateral orchiopexy is performed to prevent recurrence in the unaffected testis.

Neonatal torsion can occur either in utero or shortly after birth and the cause is unknown.

The below image shows a gross specimen of torsion testis.

Other option:

Option A- Testicular seminoma produce bulky masses. They have a homogenous grey white, lobulated, cut surface, devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis. 

Option B- Testicular atrophy can occur due to:

  • Progressive atherosclerotic narrowing of the blood supply
  • End-stage inflammatory orchitis
  • Cryptorchidism
  • Hypopituitarism
  • Irradiation
  • Antiandrogens
  • Cirrhosis
  • Klinefelter syndrome
  • Exhaustion atrophy

Histopathological examination of an atrophied specimen of testis due to cryptorchidism shows thick basement membranes, small tubules having Sertoli cells showing no spermatogenesis along with an apparent increase in Leydig cells.

Option C- Acute orchitis is characterized by congestion, edema, and infiltration by neutrophils.

questions.text: A 1-year-old male child is brought with abdominal distension, recurrent pain, nausea, and vomiting. The vomitus was bilious, and the child had stiffened and pulled his legs up to the abdomen. Past history is insignificant. An ultrasound revealed the finding shown in the image. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of abdominal distention, recurrent abdominal pain, bilious vomiting, and the USG showing the doughnut sign (target sign) and pseudokidney sign are all suggestive of an intussusception.

Intussusception occurs when a portion of the alimentary tract is telescoped into an adjacent segment. The most common location of intussusception is ileocecal. 

The majority of cases of intussusception in children are idiopathic in nature. It can be seen in infants during the weaning period following the introduction of new food, vaccination, or upper respiratory tract infection. The currently approved rotavirus vaccines are associated with a slightly increased risk of intussusception.

Clinical features include sudden, cramping abdominal pain associated with “currant jelly” stools and a palpable mass on physical examination. During the cramping episodes, the child may stiffen and pull the legs up to the abdomen. Between attacks, the child may appear comfortable. Normal bowel movements will stop as the obstruction progresses and become associated with bilious emesis and increasing abdominal distention. 

USG findings in intussusception include:

  • Target sign (also known as the doughnut sign)- The appearance is generated by concentric alternating echogenic and hypoechogenic bands. The echogenic bands are formed by mucosa and muscularis whereas the submucosa is responsible for the hypoechoic bands.
  • Pseudokidney sign is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel. The edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma.

Treatment is mainly by hydrostatic reduction of intussusception by enema. It should be done immediately after the diagnosis.

Other options:

Option A: Acute gastroenteritis in children manifests as vomiting and/or diarrhoea, fever, abdominal pain, and anorexia. The most common cause of gastroenteritis in children is a viral infection, with the etiologic agents being rotaviruses, noroviruses, enteric adenoviruses, caliciviruses, astroviruses, and enteroviruses.

Option B: Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis presents with non-bilious vomiting that is projectile in nature and usually affects male infants between 2 and 8 weeks of age and is rarely seen after 13 weeks. An olive-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant. A test feed shows visible gastric peristalsis.

Option D: Hirschsprung's disease usually presents in the neonatal period with symptoms of delayed passage of meconium, abdominal distension, and bilious vomiting; later, in adult life, it usually manifests as severe chronic constipation. It is characterized by the congenital absence of intramural ganglion cells in the distal large bowel.

questions.text: A 40-year-old tourist presents with complaints of abdominal pain and watery diarrhea. He reports having food that had a disagreeable smell and taste at a local restaurant the previous night. The serotype of E. coli most likely responsible for these symptoms is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a tourist with abdominal pain and watery diarrhea following food intake at an unhygienic place is indicative of traveler’s diarrhea. The serotype of E.Coli most likely responsible for these symptoms would be Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC).

Enterotoxigenic E.Coli is the most common cause of traveler's diarrhea. It has a heat-labile (LT) and a heat-stable toxin (ST). LT has 2 fragments A1 and A2. A1 activates the adenyl cyclase which forms cAMP. This leads to increased outflow of water and electrolytes in the gut, thus causing watery diarrhea. The heat-stable toxin ST acts by increasing cGMP in the intestine.

Other options:

Option A: Enteroinvasive E.coli (EIEC) invades interstitial epithelial cells in the intestine and causes bloody diarrhea resembling shigellosis. This ability to invade epithelial cells is determined by a plasmid.

Option B: Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) produces verocytotoxin and Shiga-like toxin. They target the vascular endothelium. EHEC also causes bloody diarrhea and can cause severe cases like hemorrhagic colitis and hemorrhagic uremic syndrome (HUS).

Option D: Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) causes diarrhea in infants and children in developing countries. It adheres to the mucosal surface of the small intestine using EPEC adhesion factor and LEE (chromosomally coded locus of enterocyte effacement). This causes the effacement of microvilli and disruption of the brush border. 

The electron micrographic image below shows EPEC adherent to effaced microvilli of the small bowel:


Note: Enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC) produces the stacked brick pattern of adherence on HEp-2 cells. EAEC has been associated with persistent diarrhea.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman, who was on treatment for sinusitis presents with right eye pain associated with high-grade fever, chills, and headache. Examination of the right eye reveals periorbital edema, ptosis, sluggish pupillary response, and lateral rectus palsy. Bilateral proptosis and papilledema are also present. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with sinusitis presenting with fever, bilateral proptosis, eye pain, ptosis, sluggish pupillary reaction, lateral rectus palsy, and papilloedema is pointing towards the diagnosis of cavernous sinus thrombosis.

The cavernous sinuses lie on either side of the body of the sphenoid bone.

The contents of the cavernous venous sinus include-

  • Cavernous segment of the internal carotid artery
  • Perivascular sympathetic plexus
  • Abducens nerve (running through the Dorello’s canal)
  • Oculomotor nerve, trochlear nerve, and the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve as part of the lateral wall.

Clinically, the feature that strongly suggests the diagnosis is the pattern and bilaterality of the proptosis. In cavernous sinus thrombosis, proptosis is initially unilateral but soon becomes bilateral due to the spread of infection to the contralateral sinus through intercavernous communication. 

Other features of cavernous sinus thrombosis are-

  • Fever
  • Severe Headache
  • Eye signs-
    • Early abducent nerve (6th cranial nerve) involvement causing lateral rectus palsy (since it runs through the cavernous sinus)
    • Later involvement of oculomotor (3rd cranial nerve) and trochlear nerve (4th cranial nerve) causing palsy (as they are related to the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus)
    • Proptosis, restricted eye motility
    • Severe supraorbital pain
    • Chemosis
    • Absence of corneal sensation due to the involvement of the ophthalmic division of the 5th cranial nerve
    • Ipsilateral ptosis, dilated pupil, and absence of direct and consensual pupillary right reflex are signs of 3rd cranial nerve palsy.
  • Oedema in the mastoid region due to thrombosis of the emissary vein is a pathognomic sign.
  • Focal neurological deficits
  • Focal or generalized seizures
  • Altered mental status. 

Investigation using brain magnetic resonance imaging or magnetic resonance venography should be done urgently. Following early diagnosis, management of cavernous sinus thrombosis typically includes intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics, analgesics, anti-inflammatory drugs, and anticoagulants. 

Other options :

Options A - Orbital cellulitis presents with unilateral proptosis with pain and decreased ocular motility.

Option B - Carotid cavernous fistula presents with a classical triad of pulsatile proptosis, chemosis, and bruit. It usually presents within days or weeks following a history of trauma.

Option C - Orbital abscess presents with severe unilateral proptosis, marked chemosis, complete ophthalmoplegia, and pus points below the conjunctiva. It is a complication of orbital cellulitis.

questions.text: A 30-year old patient comes to the hospital with complaints of blood-tinged nasal discharge. The anterior rhinoscopy shows a pink polypoidal mass in the right nose and the same is biopsied. The image given below is the histological slide of the specimen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the histopathology showing several sporangia is most likely suggestive of the diagnosis of rhinosporidiosis.

Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi. Patients clinically present with blood-tinged nasal discharge, and pink polypoidal mass in the nose.

Histopathology shows several sporangia, oval, or round in shape and filled with spores which may be seen bursting through its chitinous wall.

It is treated by completely excising the mass with a diathermy knife followed by cauterization of the base.

Other options :

Option A: Rhinophyma is a slow-growing benign tumor due to hypertrophy of the sebaceous glands of the tip of the nose, often seen in cases of long-standing acne rosacea. It is also called a potato tumor.

The image below shows rhinophyma.

Option C: Rhinoscleroma is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus). Histopathology shows large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing the causative bacilli, which are Mikulicz cells. There are also homogenous eosinophilic inclusion bodies consisting of the immunoglobulins in the plasma cells called the Russell bodies.

The image given below shows non-ulcerative granulomatous nodules with subdermal infiltration giving the feel of a woody nose in rhinoscleroma. The histology shows large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing the causative bacilli, which are Mikulicz cells.

Option D: Rhinitis sicca is a crust-forming disease seen in patients who work in hot, dry, and dusty surroundings, e.g. bakers, iron- and goldsmiths. The ciliated columnar epithelium undergoes squamous metaplasia with atrophy of the seromucous glands.

Related Pearl: Rhinosporidiosis

  • It is a chronic granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi which is recently reclassified as a member of the protistan Mesomycetozoa
  • It is more common in the southern states of India
  • It affects immunocompetent individuals
  • Most commonly a waterborne disease
  • Clinical features: Blood tinged nasal discharge, frank epistaxis, nasal stuffiness
  • Findings: 
    • Leafy, polypoidal mass, pink to purple in color and attached to the nasal septum or lateral wall
    • Sometimes, it extends into the nasopharynx and may hang behind the soft palate
    • The mass is very vascular and bleeds easily on touch
    • Its surface is studded with white dots representing the sporangia
  • Diagnosis: Biopsy which shows sporangia

Histologic section showing sporangium (arrow) which is fully packed with immature sporoblasts at the periphery and mature ones at the center

Treatment: Complete excision of the mass with diathermy knife and cauterization of its base. Recurrence may occur after surgical excision. Dapsone is also used.

questions.text: A 7-month-old boy presents with brief episodes of head drops and flexion of the body, followed by tonic extension of arms and legs. These movements last 1 to 2 seconds and occur in several clusters per day, with 15 to 30 spasms per cluster. EEG is given below and is suggestive of infantile spasms. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for infantile spasms is adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). The EEG shows a specific type of abnormal chaotic brainwave pattern called hypsarrhythmia. It is characterized by continuous, high-amplitude, asynchronous delta activities with interspersed independent, multiple spikes. Hypsarrhythmia on EEG can occur even between attacks.Excessive corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) production is hypothesized to cause infantile spasms. ACTH administration suppresses CRH secretion and hence controls the seizures.

Infantile spasms (West syndrome)

  • Age of onset is 3–8 months of life
  • Characterized by salaam spells (sudden dropping of the head or flexion of arms, followed by tonic extension of arms and legs) and hypsarrhythmia on EEG.
  • Causes include hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy, neurocutaneous syndromes, and idiopathic.
  • Drug of choice: Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), Vigabatrin.

questions.text: During a microbiology experiment, the gene for diphtheria toxin from Corynebacterium diphtheriae is carried on corynebacteriophages, and the toxin is produced only by the bacteria that are lysogenized by the phages. Which of the following methods of horizontal gene transfer is outlined in the above example?
questions.solution:
The transfer of genes for diphtheria toxin on a corynebacteriophage occurs by transduction.

Transduction can be defined as the transfer of a portion of DNA from one bacterium to another by a bacteriophage. This type of horizontal gene transfer may occur by two mechanisms:

  • Lytic cycle - In the lytic cycle, also known as the virulent cycle, a large number of progeny phages build up inside the host bacterium; eventually, the host cell ruptures, releasing the bacteriophages. Some of the bacteriophages will now contain bacterial DNA, which can then be transferred to other bacteria.
  • Lysogenic cycle - In the temperate or non-lytic cycle, the host bacterium is not lysed. Rather, the phage DNA becomes integrated with the bacterial chromosome. This phage DNA multiplies with the host cell and is transferred to daughter cells. 

Option A - Conjugation is the method of gene transfer in bacteria that involves physical contact by a male or donor bacterium with a female or recipient bacterium through an extracellular protein extrusion or appendage called the sex pili. The genetic material that is transferred is usually derived from plasmids. The bacteria that possess the ability to form the sex pili contain the F+ plasmid and are designated as F+. The F+ bacteria can transfer a single strand of the F+ plasmid DNA to F- bacteria via the sex pili. 

Option C - Transformation is the direct uptake of naked DNA by the bacterial cell from the environment. Several bacteria such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Neisseria undergo transformation. 

Option D - Transposition is a process of gene transfer that involves special segments of DNA called transposons (jumping genes).

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presents with swelling in the lips, and face for the last 2 days. She gives a history of multiple similar episodes in the past and also says some of her relatives have similar complaints. On examination, non-pruritic subcutaneous edema is noted. This condition is associated with the deficiency of which of the following complements?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Hereditary angioneurotic edema, which is associated with a deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitor. 

Hereditary angioneurotic edema (HAE) is an autosomal dominant condition due to low levels of plasma protein C1 inhibitor. Deficiencies of C1 inhibitors facilitate the unchecked activation of the classic complement pathway and biochemical systems including bradykinin systems. Bradykinin is an inflammatory mediator that caused neutrophil chemotaxis, capillary dilatation with plasma leakage, and smooth muscle relaxation.

Hereditary angioneurotic edema is characterized by episodic angioedema of the subcutaneous tissue like the face, hands, arms, genitals, or of the mucosa of the respiratory or alimentary tracts. They can present with non-pruritic subcutaneous tissue edema, paroxysmal colicky pain, or laryngeal edema.

Drugs like ecallantide, icatibant, C1-inhibitor derived from human plasma, or recombinant C1- inhibitor are used for acute attacks. Recombinant C1-inhibitor can be used for attacks and prophylaxis. Avoidance of triggers, estrogens, and ACE-inhibitors are included in the management plan.

questions.text: A gastroenterologist is studying the role of compound mucous glands present in the first few centimeters of duodenum. Which of the following is correct regarding the functioning of these glands?

choices.text: Helps in the digestion of proteins
Acidic secretion potentiating the action of gastric juices
Alkaline secretion prevents corrosion by gastric juices

questions.solution:
Brunner’s glands are located in the first few centimeters of the submucosa of the duodenal wall. They secrete alkaline mucus which protects the duodenum from highly acidic gastric juices. 

The number of Brunner's glands is maximum in the proximal duodenum and keeps decreasing towards the distal duodenum. It secretes large amounts of alkaline mucus containing HCO3- in response to tactile stimuli on the duodenal mucosa, vagal stimulation, and GI hormones, especially secretin. It is inhibited by sympathetic stimulation.

Mucus secreted by Brunner’s glands helps to protect the duodenal wall as the high HCO3- content of the mucous neutralizes the acidic chyme from the stomach.

Note:

The most alkaline secretion is Brunner’s gland secretion with a pH of 8.0 – 8.9. The second most alkaline secretion in the GI tract is the pancreatic juice.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl was brought with the complaint of sudden and inappropriate outbursts of laughter for no apparent cause in the past 6 months. Her examination reveals developmental delay. Her brain MRI shows the following feature. Considering the suspected diagnosis, which other feature is most likely to be seen with this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient seems to be suffering Gelastic seizures. Her brain MRI image shows a pedunculated mass in the floor of the 3rd ventricle which is suggestive of a hypothalamic hamartoma. Thus, the other feature most likely to be seen in this condition is precocious puberty.

Precocious puberty in a girl is the appearance of any of the secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years. Precocious puberty in boys is the onset of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 9 years. 

Hypothalamic hamartoma arises from a neuronal migration defect between 35 to 40 days of intrauterine life. They present with a classical triad of:

  • Gelastic epilepsy
  • Precocious puberty
  • Developmental delay

Other clinical features can include hypothalamic signs like diabetes insipidus, adipsia, hyperthermia, cachexia, and obesity.

A gelastic seizure is a rare type of seizure that involves a sudden burst of energy, usually in the form of laughing or crying. They have been associated classically with hypothalamic hamartomas. 

Treatment of Hypothalamic Hamartoma involves

  • GnRH agonists (depot-forms or implant) are the treatment of choice for tumor-induced central precocious puberty                 
  • In patients with hypothalamic hamartoma and associated intractable gelastic or psychomotor seizures, stereotactic radiation therapy (Gamma Knife surgery) is more effective and has fewer risks than neurosurgical intervention.

questions.text: A patient was prepared for surgery and anesthesia was induced with ketamine. In which of the following patients is induction with ketamine contraindicated?

choices.text: Rapid sequence anesthesia induction in trauma patients

questions.solution:
Induction of anesthesia with ketamine is contraindicated in patients with uncontrolled hypertension.

Ketamine causes significant increases in arterial blood pressure and heart rate. This is due to central stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system and inhibition in norepinephrine reuptake at the nerve terminals. There is also an increase in pulmonary artery pressure and myocardial work. Thus, it should be avoided in patients with coronary artery disease, uncontrolled hypertension, congestive heart failure, or arterial aneurysms.  

Other contraindications for ketamine are as follows: 

  • Open eye injury or other ophthalmic disorder with increased intraocular pressure
  • Ischemic heart disease, vascular aneurysm
  • Schizophrenia
  • Known drug hypersensitivity
  • Pregnancy or breastfeeding due to the potential for being secreted into breast milk
  • Intoxication with ethanol

Ketamine is related to phencyclidine that is used for general anesthesia either alone or in combination with other drugs. It produces dissociative anesthesia. It is used for the induction and maintenance of general anesthesia, sedation, and analgesia. 

It has a fast onset (within seconds when given intravenously and within minutes when given intramuscularly) with a short duration of action. 

Other options: 

Option A - Patients with hemorrhagic shock can benefit from ketamine as it is the only anesthetic to increase peripheral arteriolar resistance. It stimulates the sympathetic nervous system leading to increased blood pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output. 

Option C - Ketamine is the drug of choice in patients with reactive airway disease as it causes bronchodilation and can be used to treat bronchospasm. 

Option D - Ketamine can be used for rapid sequence anesthesia induction in trauma patients due to its short action and fast onset. It can be used for procedures requiring short-term sedation/and anesthesia in the emergency department.

questions.text: During the evaluation of a 32-year-old HIV positive female with headache and nuchal stiffness, the CSF sample reveals the following on microscopic examination with India-ink staining. What is the most likely mode of acquiring this infection?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the presence of encapsulated yeast cells in CSF with India Ink staining are suggestive of Cryptococcosis which is caused by Cryptococcus neoformans. It is an opportunistic fungus that is acquired by inhalation of yeast cells or spores which are found as a saprophyte in soil enriched with pigeon droppings.

In immunocompromised patients, the infection is acquired by inhalation of yeast cells or spores.

Cryptococcal meningitis and meningoencephalitis are the most vulnerable forms of cryptococcal infection. It is insidious in onset and often seen in AIDS patients. The CSF profile may show modest elevations in mononuclear cells and protein levels.

The diagnosis is made by the identification of yeast cells in CSF with India ink stain or by the detection of Cryptococcal antigen using latex agglutination(CrAg).

Cryptococcosis in HIV patients needs aggressive therapy. It includes

  • Induction therapy: IV or Liposomal Amphotericin B with Flucytosine daily for 2 weeks followed by fluconazole for at least 10 weeks.
  • Maintenance therapy: Oral Fluconazole lifelong

The given life cycle is of Cryptococcus species – Cryptococcus neoformans (common) and Cryptococcus gattii.


Other options:

  • Infection by tick-borne encephalitis viruses belonging to the Russian Spring-Summer Encephalitis complex are transmitted by the bite of Ixodid ticks
  • Cat scratch disease is caused by Bartonella henselae. It presents as a febrile illness with lymphadenopathy following a cat scratch.
  • Primary amoebic meningoencephalitis caused by Naegleria fowleri is acquired by swimming in freshwater rivers or ponds. Naegleria invades the nasal mucosa and passes through the olfactory nerve branches in the cribriform plate into the meninges.

questions.text: A G2P1 lady at 32 weeks of gestation presents with irregularly occurring abdominal pain and discharge per vaginum. On examination, uterine contractions were noted and a nonstress test reveals a reassuring fetal heart rhythm. Preterm labor would be suspected, if this patient reveals

choices.text: Uterine contractions of 9 per hour with cervical length of 32 mm
Uterine contractions of 7 per hour with cervical length of 22 mm
Uterine contractions of 6 per hour with cervical length of 34 mm
Uterine contractions of 3 per hour with cervical length of 26 mm

questions.solution:
Among the given options, you would suspect preterm labor in a G2P1 patient at 32 weeks of gestation having uterine contractions of 7 per hour with a cervical length of 22 mm.

Irrespective of uterine contractions, preterm labor is very unlikely when the cervical length is > 30 mm (Option A, & C). 

Preterm labor is defined as the labor that starts before the 37th completed week(< 259 days), from the first day of the last menstrual period.

Predictors of preterm labor:

Clinical predictors:

  • History of prior preterm birth
  • Multiple pregnancies
  • Presence of genital tract infection
  • Symptoms of preterm labor

Biophysical predictors:

  • Uterine contractions ≥4/hr
  • Bishop score ≥ 4
  • Cervical length (TVS) ≤ 25 mm (Option D)

Biochemical predictors:

  • Fetal fibronectin (fFN) in cervicovaginal discharge 

Diagnosis of preterm labor:

  • Regular uterine contractions of at least one in every 10 minutes with or without pain 
  • ≥ 2 cm dilatation and 80 % effacement of the cervix
  • Transvaginal ultrasound shows ≤ 25 mm length of the cervix and funneling of the internal os
  • Presence of backache, vaginal discharge, or bleeding 

Note: Fibronectin is a glycoprotein that binds the fetal membranes to the decidua which is found in the cervicovaginal discharge before 22 weeks and again after 37 weeks of pregnancy.

The presence of fibronectin in the cervicovaginal discharge between 24 weeks and 34 weeks is a predictor of preterm labor. If the test is negative, it reassures that delivery will not occur in the next 7 days.

questions.text: An elderly man is diagnosed with a slow-growing tumor in the deep perineal pouch. Which of the following structure would be most likely affected?
questions.solution:
A tumor in the deep perineal space is most likely to affect the bulbourethral glands as they are present in the deep perineal pouch.

Contents of deep perineal pouch:

  • Membranous urethra
  • Muscles: Sphincter urethrae and deep transverse perinei muscles
  • Nerves: Dorsal nerve of penis and muscular branches of the perineal nerve
  • Vessels: Artery of penis
  • Glands: Bulbourethral glands in males

Contents of superficial perineal pouch: 

  • Corpora cavernosa and corpus spongiosum
  • Three muscles – the ischiocavernosus, bulbospongiosus and superficial transverse perineal
  • The greater vestibular glands (Bartholin’s glands) in females and duct of bulbourethral glands in males.
  • Arteries: Branches of the perineal artery (posterior scrotal and transverse perineal arteries) and branches of artery of the penis (artery to the bulb, urethral artery, deep artery of the penis and dorsal artery of the penis)
  • Nerves: Long perineal nerve, branches of the perineal nerve (posterior scrotal, nerve to bulb and muscular branches)

  • Urethra in male

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents with a history of purulent urethral discharge and painful micturition for the past 2 days. Why is the following medium used to elicit the growth of the suspected pathogenic organism in this patient?

choices.text: Growth of other commensals is suppressed

questions.solution:
Thayer-Martin medium is shown in the above image, and it is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae because the antimicrobials present in it suppress the growth of other commensal organisms.

Gonorrhea in males most commonly manifests as acute urethritis - mucopurulent urethral discharge and burning micturition, as mentioned in the given clinical scenario. 

Contents of Thayer-Martin medium includes

  • Vancomycin: to inhibit most gram-positive bacteria
  • Colistin (Polymyxin E): to inhibit most gram-negative bacteria other than Neisseria
  • Nystatin or anisomycin: to inhibit yeast

Note: Contents of Modified Thayer-Martin medium are same as those of Thayer-Martin medium, except that the former contains an additional antibiotic trimethoprim to inhibit proteus.

Since N. gonorrhoeae, N. meningitidis, and N. lactamica are colistin-resistant they can be grown on these selective media.

Gonorrhea in males: 

  • The disease starts as acute urethritis. This infection may extend along the urethra to involve the prostate, seminal vesicles, and epididymis.
  • Chronic urethritis may result in stricture formation.
  • The infection may spread to the periurethral tissues causing abscess and multiple discharging sinuses (water can perineum).

Gonorrhea in females: 

  • The initial infection involves the cervix uteri and urethra which may extend to Bartholin glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes.
  • The vaginal mucosa is not usually affected in adults because of the stratified squamous epithelium. It is resistant to infection by the cocci, and also because of the acidic pH of vaginal secretions.
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease and salpingitis may result in sterility.
  • Rarely peritonitis may develop with perihepatic inflammation termed Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.

Other options:

Option A- Enrichment media are liquid media, which allow for the growth of certain organisms and inhibit the growth of others (natural flora). Substances having a stimulating effect on bacteria, which is to be grown, or an inhibitory effect on those to be suppressed are used in this medium. Examples include

  • Tetrathionate broth where tetrathionate allows typhoid-paratyphoid bacilli to grow and inhibits coliforms.
  • Selenite F broth for dysentery-causing bacteria 

Option C - McLeod medium is an indicator medium that contains potassium tellurite. Tellurite is reduced to metallic tellurium by Corynebacterium diphtheriae to produce black colonies.

Option D - Enriched medium: When a basal medium is added with additional nutrients such as blood, serum, or egg, it is called enriched medium. e.g. Lowenstein-Jensen medium is an inspissated selective egg medium containing fresh egg or egg yolk used for the primary isolation of Mycobacterium species.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with acute bleeding following delivery in the ambulance. On examination, a perineal tear was observed involving the anal sphincter and anal mucosa. The bleeding has been controlled. When is the ideal time to perform sphincter reconstructive surgery?
questions.solution:
As the patient was delivered in the ambulance on the way to the hospital, she has presented immediately (within 24 hours) with a complete perineal tear. Sphincter reconstructive surgery must be performed immediately.

A tear of the perineal body involving the sphincter ani externus with or without the involvement of anorectal mucosa is termed a complete perineal tear. Complete perineal tears (3rd or 4th-degree tears) that were not repaired in the first 24 hours should be operated on between 3-6 months after delivery.

In 3 months, local infection would subside with improvement in the general condition of the patient and baby can also be kept at home. Beyond 6 months, due to excessive fibrosis at the margin, it becomes inconvenient for the patient.
