questions.text: A 7-year-old intellectually disabled boy was brought with large warty crusts on the trunk, hands, and feet as shown below. Severe fissuring and scaling of the skin are present over the soles. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Norwegian scabies or human-crusted scabies.

Crusted scabies is characterized by hyperkeratotic skin crust and infestation of up to millions of mites. It occurs in people with an inadequate immune response to the mite, allowing them to multiply. Immunosuppression is a frequent association.

Clinical features include large warty crusts on the hands and feet. Palms and soles are irregularly fissured and thickened. Horny debris gets accumulated beneath the thickened and discolored nails. Erythema and scaling occur in the scalp face and seborrheic area. The itching will be absent often.

Diagnosis is confirmed by examining the scrappings which reveal mites and eggs. Management principles include hospitalization and isolation of patients due to the risk of transmission due to physical contact. Oral ivermectin, topical scabicide, and keratolytic agents are used for the crusting.

The images given below show hands in Norwegian scabies.

Other options:

Option A- Scabies incognito is a variant of scabies surrepticius that occurs due to inappropriate use of topical corticosteroids for scabies lesions. The steroids modify the clinical presentation of scabies and may mimic other dermatoses. The lesions might appear as vesicles, pustules, or nodules and could become diffuse.

Option B-  Animal scabies transmission to humans is rare. Hypersensitivity reactions for the mites and their products lead to intense pruritis and irritation. These lesions are usually self-limiting.

Option D-  Nodular scabies present as violaceous, pruritic localized nodules over the groin, axilla, and genitalia. They represent a hypersensitivity reaction to the mite antigens and can persist after treatment. 

The below image shows nodular scabies in the axilla.

questions.text: An autopsy was performed on a case of death due to bullet injuries. It showed linear fractures on the skull, as shown in the image below. Which of the following rules gives the sequence of the bullet injuries?
questions.solution:
The sequence of bullet injuries is given by Puppe’s rule.

Puppe’s rule: It is possible to determine the sequence of injuries in skull fractures caused by blunt injuries to the head because the second fracture ends at the point where a break in cohesion is already present.The fracture lines created by every other shot extend only up to the fractured lines produced by the previous shot without continuing over them. Even though this rule is true for all blunt injuries to the skull, it is of particular importance in gunshot wounds. 

Other options:

Option A- M'Naghten rule is a test to determine criminal responsibility and states that an accused person is not legally responsible if at the time of committing the crime, he/she was suffering from a defect of reason due to an abnormality of mind, which made him/her unaware of the nature and quality of the act he was doing or what he was doing was wrong. It comes under Section 84 of the Indian Penal Code.

Option C- Young's rule is used to calculate the dose of a drug for a child. It is calculated by multiplying the adult dose by the age in years and dividing the result by the sum of the child's age plus 12.

Option D- Durham's rule is a test to determine criminal responsibility and states that an accused person is not criminally responsible if the unlawful act is a product of mental disease (mental disorder) or mental defect (mental retardation).

questions.text: An infant was brought to the emergency department with a fever and persistent cough. On examination, chest retractions and tachypnea were noted and expiratory wheezes were heard over both lungs. The culture of the nasopharyngeal swab showed characteristic giant cells and syncytial formation. Which of the following is most likely to have caused this infection?
questions.solution:
The above clinical picture, along with the culture showing characteristic giant cells and syncytial formation, is characteristic of bronchiolitis, which is most likely to be caused by respiratory syncytial virus (RSV).

RSV is responsible for more than half of the cases of bronchiolitis in infants less than 1 year of age. Viral transmission is by close contact, droplet transmission, and through contaminated fingers and fomites.

The disease may begin as febrile illness, with cough and wheezing. RSV causes a broad range of respiratory illnesses. Outbreaks are commonly seen in pediatric wards, nurseries, and daycare centers. RSV also causes otitis media in children. 

Samples are collected by nasopharyngeal swabs and nasal washings. They are inoculated in cell culture (HeLa or Hep-2) immediately after collection. In cultured cells, RSV shows characteristic giant cells and syncytial formation. Cytopathic effects usually appear after 10 days of culture.   

The image given below shows giant cells and syncytial formation seen in RSV infection.

Continuous administration of ribavirin is found beneficial for hospitalized patients.

Other options:

Option A: Rhinovirus attaches to receptors on nasal ciliated epithelial cells, enters and replicates within them, spreading to other cells and causing local inflammation and the common cold.

Option B: Adenovirus types 3 and 7 cause pneumonia in adults. In infants and young children, type 7 causes serious and fatal pneumonia.

Option C: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) causes cytomegalic inclusion disease that occurs in infants born to mothers who develop primary CMV infection during pregnancy.

questions.text: Calculate the therapeutic index of a drug whose dose-response curves are plotted as shown below:
questions.solution:
The therapeutic index is 4.

In the above graph,

Median lethal dose (LD50) = 400

Median effective dose (ED50) = 100

Therapeutic index (TI) = LD50/ED50.

Hence,

Therapeutic index (TI ) = 400/100 = 4

Clinically, the therapeutic range bound by the dose that produces the minimal therapeutic effect and the dose that produces the maximal acceptable adverse effect is more relevant.

questions.text: On a cold winter night, a 2-week old neonate is brought by her concerned parents who observed some skin changes. On examination, red and blue lacy, reticulated patterns can be observed on the trunk and lower limbs. The baby is otherwise healthy and alert. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The child with lacy, reticulated red or blue cutaneous vascular patterns over the body surface as seen in the image above after exposure to cold temperatures is likely to have cutis marmorata.

This condition is usually is seen in an infant who is exposed to low environmental temperatures. It occurs as a result of an exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response. This response disappears as the children age but may also be present in older children.

It does not require treatment. 

 

Other options:

Option B- Salmon patch or naevus simplex is a small, pale pink vascular macule that occurs most commonly on the glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area. It occurs in normal newborns.

Option C- Neonatal pustular melanosis is a benign lesion characterized by the presence of superficial pustules, ruptured pustules, and hyperpigmented macules.

Option D- Harlequin color change- When the infant is placed on one side, the upper half of the body becomes pale and the dependent half becomes dark red. The color change lasts only for a few minutes. Changing the infant's position may reverse the pattern. It occurs due to the impairment of the autonomic vascular regulatory mechanism.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: Given below is a transverse B mode doppler ultrasound image done at the saphenofemoral junction in a 40-year-old male patient.  All of the following structures are responsible for this USG appearance except _________
questions.solution:
The given transverse B mode doppler ultrasound image of the saphenofemoral junction shows the Mickey Mouse sign and the internal iliac artery is not responsible for Mickey mouse sign.

Mickey mouse sign is formed by:

  • Common Femoral Vein (CFV)
  • Common Femoral Artery (CFA)
  • Greater Saphenous Vein (GSV) at the Saphenofemoral junction (SFJ).

It represents the normal anatomy of the femoral vessels as seen in a duplex ultrasound.

questions.text: A 70-year-old lady with recent-onset, progressive dementia presents with myoclonus. The brain imaging findings are shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD).

The imaging studies are diffusion-weighted imaging and T2-weighted-fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (T2-FLAIR) imaging. The findings of cortical ribboning and basal ganglia hyperintensity on the two abovementioned MRI modalities have a high sensitivity and specificity. This has diminished the need for brain biopsy in patients with suspected CJD.

CJD is a spongiform encephalopathy caused by a prion. It presents as rapidly progressive dementia and is usually fatal within 1 year of the onset of symptoms.

Symptoms are almost always rapidly progressive, and the clinical presentation includes the following:

  • Myoclonus
  • Higher cortical deficits
  • Psychiatric manifestations - depression, psychosis, and visual hallucinations
  • Profound dementia - memory loss, impaired judgment, intellectual decline
  • Visual impairment or cerebellar gait and coordination deficits in a few patients
  • Nonspecific prodromal symptoms - fatigue, sleep disturbance, weight, loss, headache, anxiety, vertigo, malaise, and ill-defined pain 
  • Extrapyramidal dysfunction - rigidity, masklike facies, choreoathetoid movements;
  • Seizures
  • Hypoesthesia
  • Supranuclear gaze palsy, optic atrophy

EEG shows repetitive, high-voltage, triphasic, and polyphasic sharp discharges in advanced cases. CSF analysis shows a positive assay for 14-3-3 protein. Brain biopsy shows the presence of prion protein scrapie (PrPSc).

Management is mainly supportive. 

Other options:

Option A: Dementia with Lewy bodies is the most common disorder to be mistaken for CJD. It has a subacute presentation with delirium, myoclonus, and extrapyramidal features. The absence of abnormalities on diffusion-weighted and T2-FLAIR MRI will almost always distinguish most dementias from CJD.

Option B: MRI in progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy reveals multifocal asymmetric, coalescing white matter lesions located in the periventricular region, in the centrum semiovale, parietal-occipital region, and in the cerebellum. These lesions show an increased signal on T2 and FLAIR. 

Option C: MRI in subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is usually normal in the early stages. Increased T2 signaling in the white matter of the brain is seen as the disease progresses.

questions.text: A 15-year-old patient presents with symptoms of night blindness, loss of peripheral vision, and myopia. Fundoscopic examination showed gyrate atrophy of the choroid and retina. This autosomal recessive condition is caused by the deficiency of which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
A fundoscopic picture showing gyrate atrophy of the retina and choroid is associated with an ornithine-Δ-aminotransferase deficiency.

Gyrate atrophy of the retina and choroid is an autosomal recessive disorder, caused by a deficiency of the enzyme ornithine-Δ-aminotransferase. Ornithine-Δ-aminotransferase (OAT) is a pyridoxal 5′-phosphate (PLP) dependent enzyme present in the mitochondrial matrix. It has prominent roles in ornithine degradation and in proline synthesis.

Defective ornithine metabolism leads to the accumulation of excessive ornithine in the plasma, urine, cerebrospinal fluid, and aqueous humor. This is responsible for the toxic effects of hyperornithinemia, especially on the retinal pigment epithelial cells.

OAT is expressed in the retinal pigment epithelium at high levels. Damage to the retinal pigment epithelium and choriocapillaris atrophy leads to the characteristic chorioretinal degenerative patches seen in gyrate atrophy.

The disease is characterized by progressive vision loss, nearsightedness (myopia), night blindness, and loss of peripheral vision, and cataracts.

Treatment mainly consists of diet modifications to lower the ornithine levels. The restriction of arginine, a precursor for ornithine in the diet, can lower plasma ornithine levels and slow the progression of chorioretinal degeneration.

Other options:

Option A: Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency leads to lethargy progressing to coma, protein aversion, intellectual disability, and hyperammonemia.

Option C: Argininosuccinate lyase leads to arginosuccinic acidemia with symptoms similar to ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency.

Option D: Branched chain ketoacid dehydrogenase deficiency leads to Maple syrup urine disease with symptoms of lethargy, vomiting, encephalopathy, seizures, intellectual disability, “maple syrup” odor, protein intolerance

questions.text: A patient presents with a lower gastrointestinal bleed. Sigmoidoscopy shows ulcers in the sigmoid colon. The histopathological image of the biopsy from the ulcer is given below.  Which of the following is the infective form of this organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the histopathological image showing flask-shaped ulcers are suggestive of intestinal amebiasis caused by Entamoeba histolytica. The mature quadrinucleate cyst is the infective form of E. histolytica.

In amebiasis, amoeba attach themselves to the colonic epithelium, induces apoptosis, invade crypts and burrow laterally into the lamina propria. This recruits neutrophils and causes tissue damage, resulting in flask-shaped ulcers with a narrow neck and broad base.

The following are the characteristic features of the various life stages of E. histolytica.

Trophozoite:

  • It is found only in tissues.
  • Its cytoplasm has a ground-glass appearance.
  • The nucleus has a central karyosome with radiating fibrils called the linin network, thus giving a cartwheel appearance.
  • Pseudopodia are present, which exhibit gliding motility.

The image given below shows the trophozoite form of E. histolytica.

Precystic stage:

  • It has a large glycogen vacuole and 2 chromatid bars.
  • It secretes a refractile cyst wall to become a cyst.

Cystic stage:

  • The mature cyst has 4 nuclei and no glycogen mass. It is passed in feces and can remain viable under moist conditions for about 10 days.
  • Chromatid bars disappear.

The image given below shows the cyst form of E. histolytica.

Treatment involves three classes of drugs: 

  • Luminal amebicides like diloxanide furoate, paromomycin which act in the lumen
  • Tissue amebicides like emetine and chloroquine
  • Both luminal and tissue amebicides like metronidazole and tinidazole.

The following image shows the life cycle and complications of E. histolytica.

questions.text:
A young female patient with SLE visits the doctor for a follow-up. Her urine analysis shows the presence of proteinuria and microscopic hematuria. The patient undergoes renal biopsy, and it shows focal glomerulonephritis involving less than 50% of all glomeruli. What is the class of lupus nephritis?

SLE - systemic lupus erythematosus
questions.solution:
Focal glomerulonephritis involving less than 50% of all glomeruli belongs to class III lupus nephritis (focal lupus nephritis).

Nephritis is a serious and life-threatening manifestation of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). In the initial stages, the patients are usually asymptomatic. Therefore, evaluating patients for renal function is important to prevent the progression of the disease. 

Symptoms of nephritis are proteinuria, hematuria, nephrotic syndrome, and hypertension. If the patient has clinical or laboratory evidence of nephritis, they have to undergo renal biopsy. Depending on the histopathological features, lupus nephritis is divided into six classes.

Class III or focal lupus nephritis shows focal, segmental, or global glomerulonephritis involving ≤ 50% of all glomeruli. Focal subendothelial deposits might also be present.

Immunofluorescence of the renal biopsy in lupus nephritis will show positive staining for all immune reactants (IgG, IgA, IgM, C1q, C3, kappa and lambda light chain). This is called a full house pattern.

Below image shows the deposition of all the immune reactants in the glomeruli:

questions.text: A 2-month-old baby is brought to the outpatient department for a facial defect. On examination, the following findings were noticed. The soft and the hard palate are intact. Which of the following is the most appropriate management in this child?

choices.text: Cleft lip repair at 9 to 12 months
Cleft lip repair at 4 to 6 months

questions.solution:
The given clinical image is that of a child with a cleft lip on the left side. The most appropriate management for this patient would be a cleft lip repair at 4-6 months.

Etiology of the cleft lip can include familial, protein and vitamin deficiency, rubella infection, radiation, chromosomal abnormalities, maternal epilepsy and drug intake during pregnancy (steroids/eptoin/diazepam)

Majority of the cases are unilateral and cleft lip alone is uncommon.

Millard Criteria (Rule of 10) is used to undertake surgery for cleft lip.

  • 10 pound in weight
  • 10 weeks old
  • 10g% Hemoglobin

Millard cleft lip repair by rotating the local nasolabial flaps is done.

The most appropriate management for this patient would be cleft lip repair at 4 to 6 months. 

According to Delaire timing of cleft surgery - unilateral cleft lip alone can be operated in one stage operation and is done at 4-6 months.

The different types of facial clefts are shown below:

  1. Unilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  2. Bilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  3. Unilateral cleft lip associated with cleft palate
  4. Bilateral cleft lip and palate
  5. Cleft palate only

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a history of weight loss, joint pain, and occasional fever. She has a malar rash, oral ulcers, telangiectatic vessels, non-blanching purpuric papules over her legs. She has elevated blood urea nitrogen and creatinine. An indirect immunofluorescence test was done and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the staining pattern?
questions.solution:
This patient with weight loss, joint pain, malar rash, oral ulcers, non-blanching purpuric papules over her legs, elevated blood urea nitrogen, and creatinine is likely to have systemic lupus erythematosus.

The image shows a homogenous or diffuse stained immunofluorescence pattern, indicating anti-nuclear antibodies, especially, antibodies against dsDNA, nucleosomes, chromatin, and histones, seen in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

SLE is an autoimmune disease involving multiple organs, with a vast array of autoantibodies, particularly antinuclear antibodies (ANA). The lesion occurs mainly by deposition of immune complexes and binding of antibodies to various cells and tissues.

Clinical criteria of SLE include:

  • Malar rash
  • Discoid rash
  • Diffuse thinning or hair fragility in the absence of other causes
  • Oral or nasopharyngeal ulceration
  • Nonerosive synovitis involving two or more peripheral joints
  • Pleuritis
  • Persistent proteinuria
  • Seizures, psychosis
  • Hemolytic anemia
  • Leukopenia
  • Lymphopenia
  • Thrombocytopenia

Anti-nuclear antibodies are seen in autoimmune diseases and are directed against nuclear antigens. They are broadly divided into four categories depending on their specificity for the nuclear components like DNA, histones, non-histone RNA bound proteins, and nucleolar antigens.

The test used for the detection of a specific type of ANA is called indirect immunofluorescence, in which the pattern of nuclear fluorescence suggests the type of antibody present in the patient’s serum.

Four basic patterns are recognized:

Homogeneous or diffuse staining of nuclei occurs with antibodies specific for dsDNA, nucleosomes, and histones. This is seen in systemic lupus erythematosus

The image below shows a homogenous or diffuse stained immunofluorescence pattern seen in SLE.

 

Speckled pattern is seen in the presence of antibodies reactive with nuclear antigens such as Smith(Sm) and ribonucleoprotein as shown below

 

Centromeric pattern is the characteristic for the presence of anti-centromere antibodies as seen in some cases of systemic sclerosis and Sjögren syndrome

The image below shows a centromeric pattern.

 

The nucleolar pattern is seen with antibodies against nucleolar proteins as shown below

The below image shows the basic patterns of ANA.

Other options: 

Option B- Sjogren syndrome shows specific antibodies directed against two ribonucleoprotein antigens, SS-A(Ro) and SS-B(La). It is characterized by dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and dry mouth (xerostomia) resulting from immunologically mediated destruction of the lacrimal and salivary glands. It occurs most commonly in women between 50 and 60 years of age.

Option C- Systemic sclerosis shows specific antibodies directed against

  • DNA topoisomerase I
  • Centromeric proteins A, B, c
  • RNA polymerase III

Systemic sclerosis is an autoimmune connective tissue disorder that results in interstitial and perivascular fibrosis of the skin, and various other internal organs along with widespread damage to blood vessels. It occurs commonly in women between 50 to 60 year age group.

Option D- Autoimmune myositis shows specific antibodies directed against Jo I and MDA5. These patients present with raynaud phenomenon, dermatomyositis, skin rash, and interstitial lung disease.

questions.text: A community health officer is assessing a healthcare facility under the scheme shown in the image below. Which of the following is the main objective of this scheme?

choices.text: To promote infection control practices in public health care facilities
To promote labor room quality and infrastructure
To provide physical aids and assisted-living devices for senior citizens
To improve the quality of care during the intrapartum and immediate postpartum period

questions.solution:
The above image shows the Kayakalp scheme. The main objective of the program is to promote cleanliness, hygiene, and infection control practices in public healthcare facilities. 

The Kayakalp scheme is a national initiative launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW) under Swachh Bharat Abhiyan.

Other main objectives:

  • To incentivize and recognize public healthcare facilities that adhere to standard protocols of cleanliness and infection control
  • To instill a culture of ongoing assessment and review of performance related to hygiene, cleanliness, and sanitation
  • To create and share sustainable practices to improve cleanliness in public health facilities linked to positive health outcomes

Other options:

Option B- To promote labor room quality and infrastructure is the main objective of LaQshya, a program launched by the MoHFW. 

Option C- To provide physical aids and assisted-living devices for senior citizens belonging to the BPL category is the main objective of Rashtriya Vayoshri Yojana, a scheme by the Ministry of Social Justice and Empowerment.

Option D- To improve the quality of care for mothers and newborns during the intrapatum and immediate postpartum period by strengthening the competency of care providers is the main objective of Dakshata, a program launched by the MoHFW.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child was brought with complaints of fever and sore throat. On examination, white-grey exudative substance adherent to his oropharynx as shown. He was prescribed erythromycin for the same. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
The mechanism of action of erythromycin is inhibition of the 50s subunit of the ribosome.

The above clinical scenario of fever, sore throat, extensive submandibular, cervical swelling and oral examination findings are suggestive of diphtheria. 

Erythromycin is a macrolide antibiotic. It is a bacteriostatic agent that inhibits protein synthesis by binding reversibly to 50S ribosomal subunits in susceptible microorganisms.

It is commonly used for the treatment of gram-positive infections. Erythromycin is the traditional drug of choice in diphtheria and in the carrier state. Erythromycin is also used for the treatment of atypical pneumonia. It is given for prophylaxis of endocarditis and rheumatic fever in people with valvular heart disease and allergic to penicillin respectively.

The adverse effects of anorexia, nausea, vomiting and diarrhea. Erythromycin acts on motilin receptors resulting in stimulation of the gastrointestinal motility and causing gastrointestinal disturbances. This therapeutic paradox has led to erythromycin's off-label use as a prokinetic agent in the intensive care setting and in patients with diabetic gastroparesis. Erythromycin, particularly the erythromycin estolate formulation result in cholestatic hepatitis (jaundice, impaired liver function) as a result of hypersensitivity reaction. It inhibits the cytochrome P450 enzyme and results in increased accumulation of various drugs like theophylline, warfarin, cyclosporine, and methylprednisolone.

Other options:

Option A- Tetracyclines (Eg. doxycycline, minocycline) and aminoglycosides (eg. gentamicin, tobramycin, amikacin) inhibit the protein synthesis by binding to the 30s subunit of the ribosomes of susceptible organisms.

Option C- Glycopeptides (Eg. vancomycin) inhibit the transglycosylase enzyme resulting in the prevention of elongation of peptidoglycans and cross-linking in the cell wall.

Option D- Beta-lactam group (penicillin group of drugs like cephalosporins, meropenems etc) of antimicrobials inhibit the cell wall synthesis by binding and inhibiting the cell wall transpeptidase.

Related Pearl: Protein synthesis inhibitors: Primary subunit of ribosome binding

Mnemonic: 50 CELLS arranged into 30 TEAM

  • E: Erythromycin (macrolides)
  • L: Lincosamides
  • L: Linezolid
  • S: Streptogramins

30s subunit binding

  • Te: Tetracyclines
  • Am: Aminoglycosides

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding complement factor C5a:

choices.text: C3b is responsible for its release from C5
It increases vascular permeability and vasodilatation
It is chemotactic for eosinophils and basophils
It helps in the formation of membrane attack complex

questions.solution:
Among the given options, The false statement about complement factor C5a is that it helps in the formation of membrane attack complex. Rather, complement factor C5b binds to the late components C6-C9, resulting in the formation of the membrane attack complex.

C5a is formed by the cleavage of C5, by C5 convertase, which itself is formed from C3b. The cleavage of C5 also yields C5b, which initially remains attached to the cell surface.

During inflammation, C5a, C3a, and C4a, which are all cleavage products of their corresponding complement components, stimulate mast cells to release histamine. They have effects similar to those of mast cell mediators involved in anaphylactic reactions and therefore, are called anaphylatoxins. Thereby increasing vascular permeability and vasodilatation.

C5a is also chemotactic for neutrophils, monocytes, eosinophils, and basophils. Additionally, it activates the lipooxygenase pathway of arachidonic acid metabolism in neutrophils and monocytes, resulting in the further release of inflammatory mediators.

The complement system is a collection of soluble proteins and their membrane receptors that help in host defence against microbes and pathologic inﬂammatory reactions; it consists of more than 20 proteins, some of which are numbered C1 through C9

An important step in complement activation involves the proteolysis of the third component, C3, which is also the most abundant complement, by one of the following three pathways:

  1. The classical pathway, triggered by fixation of C1 to either an IgM or IgG antibody
  2. The alternative pathway, triggered by microbial surface molecules like endotoxins
  3. The lectin pathway, in which C1 is activated by binding of plasma lectin to carbohydrates on microbes

Related Pearl: Functions of Complement

  • Inflammation: C3a, C5a, and, to a lesser extent, C4a are called anaphylatoxins.
  • C5a is also a chemotactic agent.
  • Opsonization and phagocytosis: C3b and its cleavage product iC3b (inactive C3b) act as opsonins and promote phagocytosis by neutrophils and macrophages.
  • Cell lysis

This role of complement is important mainly for the killing of microbes with thin cell walls, such as Neisseria species, and deficiency of the terminal components of complement predisposes to Neisseria infections.

questions.text: A term newborn with no risk factors does not cry at birth. The pediatrician notes that the baby is not breathing, so she warms and dries the baby, clears the airway, and stimulates the baby. After 30 seconds, she notices that the heart rate is 88 beats/ minute and that the baby is still apneic. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the neonate has a heart rate of less than 100 beats/ minute, is not crying, and is apneic at 30 seconds of evaluation. Thus, according to the American Heart Association guidelines for newborn resuscitation, positive pressure ventilation should be started. 

Positive pressure ventilation (PPV) is the primary method of providing support for newborns who are apneic, have bradycardia, or have poor respiratory effort. It is successful in producing a response in most babies, clinically evident by an improvement in heart rate, the establishment of breathing, or crying. 

It may be initiated with air (21% oxygen) in term and late preterm newborns and up to 30% oxygen in preterm babies. They should be monitored using a pulse oximeter. 

Other options: 

Option A - Chest compressions should be started if the heart rate is less than 60 beats/ minute despite adequate PPV. The ratio is 3 compressions to 1 inflation using the 2 thumbs, encircling hands technique. It should be 30 inflations and 90 compressions per minute. 

Option B - IV epinephrine should be administered if the heart rate is less than 60 beats/ minute despite 60 seconds of chest compressions and adequate PPV. 

Option D - Volume expansion is indicated when there is known blood loss based on history and examination, and no response to epinephrine.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with complaints of epistaxis while playing cricket. There is no history of trauma or fall. He also gives a history of recurrent spontaneous nasal bleeding and earache. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is taken which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.

The above clinical scenario of an adolescent boy of age 12 years presenting with recurrent spontaneous epistaxis, earache, and contrast-enhanced CT scan showing anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus (Antral sign/ Holman Miller sign) is suggestive of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.

Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign but locally invasive tumor predominant in adolescent males in the age group of 10-20 years. It arises from the posterior part of the nasal cavity that is close to the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen. These patients have a hamartomatous nidus of vascular tissue in the nasopharynx that forms angiofibroma when testosterone appears. Therefore, it is thought to be testosterone-dependent.

Angiofibroma can extend into the nasal cavity causing obstruction, epistaxis, paranasal sinuses, pterygomaxillary fossa, infratemporal fossa, cheek, orbits causing proptosis, frog-face deformity, and cranial cavity. The clinical features include:

  • Profuse, recurrent, spontaneous epistaxis- most common
  • Progressive nasal obstruction and denasal speech- due to mass in the postnasal space
  • Conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion- due to obstruction of the Eustachian tube
  • Sessile, lobulated, or smooth mass in the nasopharynx
  • Other clinical features include the broadening of the nasal bridge, proptosis, cheek swelling, involvement of II, III, IV, and VI cranial nerves

Diagnosis: It is mostly clinical. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is the investigation of choice that reveals anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus (Antral sign/Holman Miller sign) which is pathognomonic of angiofibroma as shown below.

Carotid angiography is also done which shows the extent of the tumor with its vascularity. The feeding vessels mostly come from the external carotid artery. In large tumors with intracranial extension, vessels come from the internal carotid system also. 

Biopsy of the mass is avoided due to the risk of bleeding.

Staging of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

Stage Spread
IA Limited to the nose and/or nasopharynx
IB Extension into ≥ one paranasal sinus
IIA Minimal extension into the sphenopalatine foramen with minimal part of pterygopalatine fossa
IIB Full occupation of pterygopalatine fossa with Holman-Miller sign, may with erosion of orbital bones
IIC Extension into the cheek, temporal fossa, or posterior to pterygoids through the pterygomaxillary fossa
IIIA Erosion of skull base with minimal intracranial
IIIB Erosion of skull base with extensive intracranial with or without cavernous sinus

Treatment: Surgery is the treatment of choice. Embolization of the vessels can be done prior to surgery to reduce the risk of bleeding during the surgery. Radiotherapy, chemotherapy, and hormonal therapy can also be considered.

Other options:

Option A- Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a malignant tumor closely associated with Epstein-Barr virus infection. They are predominantly seen in the fifth to the seventh decade of life. Cervical lymph nodes involvement, nasal obstruction, epistaxis, nasal discharge, conductive hearing loss with serous otitis media, squint, and diplopia due to involvement of the cranial nerves III, IV, and VI.

Trotter's triad, characterized by conductive deafness, ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, and palatal paralysis may be seen. 

Option C- Inverted papilloma/ Ringertz tumor/ Schneiderian papilloma is the tumor of the non-olfactory mucosa and paranasal sinuses. It is caused due to human papillomavirus. It is more commonly seen in males of the age group 40-70 years. Patients will almost always present with unilateral nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and epistaxis. Orbital invasion can result in proptosis, diplopia, and lacrimation. CT scan shows the location and extent of the tumor.

Below is the CT image showing an inverted papilloma. 

Option D- Blow-out fracture is the isolated fracture of the floor of the orbit. The clinical features include ecchymosis of the lid, conjunctiva, enophthalmos, diplopia, and hypoesthesia of the cheek and upper lip. Water's view on radiograph and CT scan shows a characteristic convex opacity bulging into the antrum from above known as the tear-drop sign.

Below is the CT image showing the tear-drop sign of blow-out fracture.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents to the emergency room with diabetic ketoacidosis. He is a known case of heart failure and diabetes mellitus and is on medications. On examination, the below finding was noted as shown in the image. Which of the following drugs is the likely cause for his presentation?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a diabetic, heart failure patient presenting with diabetic ketoacidosis and the image showing Fournier's gangrene is suggestive of canagliflozin as the likely causative drug.

Canagliflozin is a sodium-glucose transporter 2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor. Other SGLT-2 inhibitors include dapagliflozin and empagliflozin. They act by inhibiting the SGLT-2 transporter which is present on the proximal segment of the renal tubule and responsible for the reabsorption of 80-90% of filtered glucose. It inhibits glucose reabsorption resulting in glycosuria and change in the renal threshold. This results in a decrease in the blood glucose level. 

SGLT-2 inhibitors have a cardioprotective effect resulting from improved cardiac cell metabolism, improvement of ventricular loading mechanism, and reduction of cardiac cell necrosis and fibrosis. It also has a renoprotective property.

The common side effects include urinary tract infections and genital mycotic infections due to the high glucose content of the urine. Fournier's gangrene is also one of the important adverse effects. There is a risk of the development of euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis. It increases the risk of fractures and lower limb amputations due to the creation of an imbalance with the minerals and circulating parathormone and vitamin D. 

Other options:

Option A- Acarbose is an α-glucosidase inhibitor that inhibits the α-glucosidase enzyme in the brush border epithelium of the intestine and reduces the absorption of starch, dextrin, and disaccharides. The most important adverse effects are malabsorption, flatulence, diarrhea, and abdominal bloating. Hypoglycemia can occur when it is given along with insulin or insulin secretagogues.

Option C- Metformin belongs to the biguanide class of hypoglycemic drugs that activate AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) and reduce hepatic glucose production. The most common adverse effects of metformin include anorexia, abdominal discomfort, diarrhea, vitamin B12 deficiency, and lactic acidosis. Metformin should be used cautiously in renal failure patients.

Option D- Pioglitazone belongs to the thiazolidinediones class of hypoglycemic drugs that stimulate the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPAR-γ) in muscle, fat, liver, and reduce insulin resistance. The most common adverse effects include weight gain and edema due to an increase in adiposity and fluid retention. They can increase the incidence of heart failure and the risk of fractures. Some cases of macular edema have been reported.

questions.text: All of the following enzymes are a part of the CAD enzyme complex involved in pyrimidine biosynthesis except:
questions.solution:
All of the following enzymes are a part of the CAD enzyme complex involved in pyrimidine biosynthesis except carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I. It initiates the biosynthesis of urea.

The CAD multi-protein complex comprises the first three letters of enzymes involved in the first three reactions of pyrimidine biosynthesis. These enzymes are:

  1. Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II is a cytosolic enzyme responsible for the synthesis of carbamoyl phosphate in the presence of glutamine, CO2, and ATP. It is activated by phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate and inhibited by uridine triphosphate.
  2. Aspartate transcarbamoylase catalyzes the synthesis of carbamoyl aspartate from carbamoyl phosphate and aspartate. This is the rate-limiting step.
  3. Dihydroorotase is involved in the synthesis of dihydro-orotic acid from carbamoyl aspartate.

Whereas, carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I is a mitochondrial enzyme that uses ammonia as a nitrogen donor. It is involved in the synthesis of citrulline from ornithine in the urea cycle. It is not a part of the CAD complex. 

The pyrimidine synthesis pathway is shown in the image below.

A defect in the enzymes of pyrimidine synthesis can give rise to the following conditions:

 Enzyme deficiency  Disorder  Features
Uridine-5-monophosphate synthase Hereditary orotic aciduria Megaloblastic anaemia, growth retardation, neurologic abnormalities, crystalluria, obstructive uropathy
Pyrimidine-5-nucleotidase  Hemolytic anemia Basophilic stippling of erythrocytes, high levels of cytidine and uridine ribonucleotides 
Dihydroprimidine dehydrogenase  Convulsive disorders, motor retardation, and mental retardation increased urinary excretion of uracil, thymine

questions.text: A female patient presents to the outpatient for a routine medical examination. Her chest X-ray is given below. The diagnosis in this patient is.
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the chest X-ray showing the figure of 3 sign is suggestive of coarctation of the aorta.

The image given below shows a figure of 3 sign on a chest x-ray.

Coarctation of the aorta refers to the congenital narrowing of a part of the aorta. It is most commonly seen just beyond the origin of the left subclavian artery or distal to the insertion of the ligamentum arteriosum.

Coarctation of the aorta may be asymptomatic in adulthood and picked up during routine examination. Clinically patients present with complaints of headache, cold extremities, and leg fatigue with exercise. Infants present with poor feeding, evidence of shock with poor perfusion, auscultatory gallop, and mitral regurgitation murmur. Clinical signs classically worsen after the closure of ductus arteriosus

Clinical examination reveals:

  • Upper limb hypertension, with a systolic blood pressure difference of at least 10 mm Hg between brachial artery > popliteal artery.
  • Radial-femoral pulse delay.
  • Interscapular systolic murmur originating from the coarctation site
  • A crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur throughout the chest wall from the intercostal collateral arteries.
  • Funduscopy may show a corkscrew tortuosity of retinal arterioles

X-ray features:

  • The figure of 3 sign - Refers to the indentation of the aorta at the site of coarctation with pre and post-stenotic dilatation.
  • Notching of 3rd and 9th ribs due to rib erosion by dilated collateral vessels.

The image given below shows rib notching on a chest x-ray.

Other options:

Option B: Boot-shaped heart is seen in the tetralogy of Fallot.

Option C: Egg on side appearance is seen in transposition of great vessels.

Option D: Money bag heart is seen in pericardial effusions.

questions.text: A middle aged man comes with complaints of early ejaculation. He reports that ejaculation usually occurs within 15 seconds of vaginal penetration. Which phase of the normal sexual cycle does this disorder belong to?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of ejaculation within 15 seconds of vaginal penetration is suggestive of premature ejaculation. It is a disorder of the orgasm phase of the normal sexual cycle.

In premature ejaculation, there is a persistent or recurrent achievement of orgasm and ejaculation before the patient actually wishes to. Difficulty in ejaculatory control can be associated with anxiety regarding the sex act, unconscious fears about the vagina, or negative cultural conditioning. According to DSM-5, it is classified as:

  • Mild if ejaculation occurs within approximately 30 sec­onds to 1 minute of vaginal penetration
  • Moderate if ejaculation occurs within approximately 15 to 30 seconds of vaginal pen­etration
  • Severe if ejaculation occurs at the start of sexual activity or within approximately 15 seconds of vaginal penetra­tion.

Sexual response is a true psycho-physiological experience. Normally, men and women experience a sequence of physiological responses to sexual stimulation. The phases of the normal sexual response cycle are:

  • Desire phase - consists of sex fantasies and the desire to have sex
  • Excitement/Arousal phase - heightened excitement before orgasm (longest phase)
  • Orgasmic phase - a subjective perception of a peak physical reaction and release occurs, along with a feeling of well-being (shortest phase). It is marked by ejaculation.
  • Resolution phase - return to the baseline.

Following orgasm, men experience a refractory period during which they cannot be restimulated to further arousal. Women do not have a refractory period and can experience multiple, successive orgasms.

Disorders of the orgasm phase also include other conditions like female orgasmic disorder and delayed ejaculation.

Other options:

Option A: Desire phase disorder includes male hypoactive sexual desire disorder. It is characterized by a deficiency or absence of sexual fantasies and a desire for sexual activity. This should be present for at least 6 months.

Option B: Arousal disorders include female sexual arousal disorder and male erectile disorder. Women with sexual arousal disorder are unable to feel sexual interest or arousal. Male erectile disorder refers to difficulty obtaining and/or maintaining an erection during sexual activity. There may or may not be decreased erectile rigidity.

Option D: The resolution phase lasts for 10-15 minutes. If no orgasm is achieved, it can last for 1/2 -1 day. It is marked by full detumescence in 5-30 minutes. Detumescence is the release of vascular activity and muscle tone after orgasm.

questions.text: Which of the following structures passes through the opening of the diaphragm marked as '?' in the image below?
questions.solution:
The opening of the diaphragm marked in the given image is the esophageal opening. Among the given options, the structure that passes through this opening is the left vagus nerve. 

The esophageal opening passes through a major opening in the muscular part of the diaphragm at the level of the T10 vertebra, a little to the left of the aortic hiatus. The structures passing through the esophageal opening are:

  • Right and left vagal trunks
  • Esophageal branches of the left gastric vessels

Option B: The superior epigastric artery passes through a minor opening called the Space of Larry (Costo-Xiphoid gap) between the sternal and costal parts of the diaphragm.

Option D: The right phrenic nerve passes through the opening in the central tendon at the level of T8 along with the inferior vena cava.

questions.text: You are a part of a water purification program, where you are explaining chlorine as a disinfectant. Which among the following is the most effective form of chlorine for water disinfection?
questions.solution:
Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine for water disinfection.

Action of chlorine:

When chlorine is added to water, there is the formation of hydrochloric acid (HCl) and hypochlorous acids (HOCl), as follows.

H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl

The hydrochloric acid is neutralized by the alkalinity of the water.

The hypochlorous acid (HOCl) ionizes to form hydrogen ions (H+) and hypochlorite ions (OCl-), as follows:

HOCl → H+ + OCl-

The disinfecting action of chlorine is mainly due to hypochlorous acid, which is 70-80 times more effective than the hypochlorite ions.

The formation of hypochlorous acid is predominant, when the pH of the water is around 7. If the pH exceeds 8.5, chlorine is unreliable as a disinfectant, as about 90% of the hypochlorous acid that is formed gets ionized to hypochlorite ions.

Most waters have a pH between 6 to 7.5.

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for the large-scale purification of drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • It oxidizes iron, manganese, and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odour producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • The action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    •  Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination:
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action, and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for the application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines would have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve the appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in a 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water that contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorine.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorine separately.

Related Pearl: Horrock’s Apparatus

  • Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water.
  • This is widely used in the disinfection of wells to find out how much bleaching powder is required.
  • Contents of this water-testing apparatus:
    • 6 white cups of 200 ml each and one black cup with a circular mark
    • 2 metal spoons (each holds 2g of bleaching powder)
    • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
    • Two droppers
    • Starch-iodide indicator solution
  • Procedure:
    • Use 2g of bleaching powder to create a thin paste in the black cup. It is now called the Chlorine stock solution.
    • The six white cups are filled with the water to be tested
    • Add one drop of the stock solution to the 1st cup, two drops to the 2nd cup, three drops to the 3rd cup, and so on till adding six drops to the 6th cup.
    • Stir the cups and wait for half an hour.
    • Add 3 drops of starch-iodide indicator to each cup
    • Development of blue color in the apparatus indicates free residual chlorine. 
    • The first cup which develops this color gives an estimate of the amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 Litres of the sample water.
  • Chlorine demand or the dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) g for 455 liters of water, i.e., (n x 2) g of bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 liters of water. Here, n represents the position of the cup (1, 2, 3, etc.) that was first to show a distinct blue color.

questions.text: You have ordered a patch test for an 8-year-old boy with a history of allergic contact dermatitis. After the application of the patch, when should you ask him to return for removal?
questions.solution:
In patch testing, the patch is removed after 48 hours to examine the site of reaction.

Patch testing is a test to detect sensitivity to a specific allergen. A battery of suspected allergens is applied to the patient’s back under occlusive dressings or patches. It is allowed to remain in contact with the skin for 48 hours.

  • 48 hours:  Patch removal for initial reading to detect delayed hypersensitivity reaction.
  • 72-96 hours: Final reading done for confirmation. 

Note: Since the question is regarding the timing of patch removal and not regarding the final diagnosis, 48 hours is the answer.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a dense cataract has been posted for cataract surgery. Since fundus examination was not possible due to dense cataract, the surgeon advises getting an electrophysiological test to assess the retinal function. The record obtained is as shown below. Which of the following waves represent the metabolic activity of pigment epithelium?
questions.solution:
The image shown is a normal electroretinogram(ERG). The metabolic activity of pigment epithelium is represented by a C wave.

Electroretinography (ERG) is the record of changes in the resting potential of the eye induced by the stimulation of a flash of light.

Waves of normal ERG

  • a-wave is a negative wave possibly representing the activity of rods and cones
  • b-wave is a large positive wave that is generated by Muller cells. They represent the activity of the bipolar cells
  • c-wave is a positive wave representing the metabolic activity of pigment epithelium

ERG is used in the diagnosis and prognosis of retinal disorders like retinitis pigmentosa, Leber’s congenital amaurosis, retinal ischemia, and other chorioretinal degenerations.

It helps to assess retinal function when fundus examination is not possible like in the presence of dense cataracts and corneal opacity. It is also used to assess the retinal function of the children where possibilities of impaired vision are considered.

A subnormal B wave is seen in early cases of retinitis pigmentosa. 

An extinguished response is seen when there is complete failure of rod and cone function in advanced retinitis pigmentosa, complete retinal detachment, and central retinal artery occlusion. 

A negative response is seen when there is gross disturbances of retinal circulation.

questions.text: A nursing student uses a modified WHO partograph to monitor the progress of labour in a 39 weeks primigravida woman. Which phase of labour does the nurse need not plot on this partograph?
questions.solution:
Modified WHO Partograph doesn't need plotting of the latent phase of labour.

The reason for excluding the latent phase was more likelihood of interventions due to prolonged latent phase which was overdiagnosed. There was also difficulty reported in transferring the dilatation from latent phase to active phase.

The first stage of labour has got two phases:

  1. Latent phase 
  2. Active phase 

The latent phase of labour is defined as the period between the onset of true labour pain and the point when the cervical dilatation becomes 3–4 cm. The normal duration of the latent phase of labour in a primigravida is about 20 hours (average 8.6 hours) and 14 hours (average 5.3 hours) in a multipara.

The active phase has got three components:

  1. Acceleration phase with cervical dilatation of 3–4 cm.
  2. The phase of maximum slope of 4–9 cm dilatation.
  3. The phase of deceleration of 9–10 cm dilatation.

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient presents with a high-grade fever, headache, and weakness for 5 days. He gives a history of blood transfusion 4 months back. The microscopic examination of the thin blood smear is given below. What is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
High-grade fever, headache, weakness and microscopy showing Maltese crosses or tetrads are suggestive of babesiosis caused by Babesia microti.

The definitive host for babesia is the ixodid tick and the reservoir hosts are wild or domesticated animals. Man is an incidental, dead-end host. It is transmitted to man through the bite of an ixodid tick or blood transfusions. Patients present with fever, malaise, headache, myalgia. 

On microscopic examination of Giemsa stained peripheral smears, babesia trophozoites appear as intraerythrocytic round or pyriform or ring forma. The ring form is the most common and it lacks the central hemozoin deposit present in P. falciparum. Other distinguishing features are the absence of schizonts and gametocytes and the presence of tetrads/Maltese crosses, which are pathognomic of B. microti. 

The below image shows Maltese cross appearance of Babesia microti.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient underwent bypass surgery for obesity. She has noticed sweating, palpitations, colicky pain, and loose stools on consuming bulky foods. These episodes start immediately post meals and last for 1 hour. They are relieved by lying down. What is the mainstay of treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The mainstay of treatment for this condition is small, frequent low carbohydrate meals.

A 50-year-old female with symptoms of sweating, palpitations, colicky pain, and loose stools on consuming bulky foods after undergoing gastric bypass surgery for obesity is highly suggestive of dumping syndrome. Dietary manipulation with small, frequent low carbohydrate meals is the mainstay treatment.

Dumping syndrome can be early or late.

  • Early dumping syndrome is due to the high osmotic load that reaches the small bowel, leading to sequestration of fluid from the circulation into the gastrointestinal tract (GIT). This shift induces autonomic responses. It is characterized by more GI and fewer cardiovascular effects. It appears to be secondary to the release of several humoral agents, such as serotonin, bradykinin-like substances, neurotensin, and entero- glucagon.
  • Late dumping syndrome is due to the high carbohydrate load in the small intestine, which causes an increase in insulin levels and secondary hypoglycemia. This hypoglycemia activates the adrenal gland to release catecholamines, which results in diaphoresis, tremulousness, light-headedness, tachycardia, and confusion.

Dietary manipulation is the mainstay of treatment of early dumping syndrome. The patient is asked to consume small, dry, more frequent food with avoidance of carbohydrates.

Other options:

Option A: Octreotide, a somatostatin analogue is used in intractable syndromes and is administered subcutaneously before meals. It not only inhibits gastric emptying but also affects small bowel motility. Hence, the intestinal transit of the ingested meal is prolonged.

Option B: Oral rehydration solution (ORS) is used for the supportive treatment of diarrhoea. The absorption of water and nutrients is dependent on the osmotic gradient created by sodium transport via neutral NaCl absorption, sodium absorption coupled to the absorption of organic solutes such as glucose and electrogenic sodium absorption. In diarrheal disease, disruption of these processes occurs except the absorption of sodium, coupled with glucose and other organic solutes. The preservation of this facilitated cotransporter is the scientific rationale for the development of the ORS.

Option D: Surgical treatment is considered when all other methods fail; available options include pyloric reconstruction or conversion to a Roux-en-y gastrojejunostomy.

questions.text: The liver specimen obtained after the autopsy of a patient is given below. What could be the likely cause of this finding?
questions.solution:
In the image, the liver specimen shows a nutmeg liver appearance, which occurs in congestive hepatomegaly.  This is secondary to passive congestion due to right heart failure.

In right heart failure, there is congestion of hepatic and portal vessels, greatest around the central veins. This leads to increased liver size and weight. The pericentral zones become congested and red-brown. The periportal regions are normal coloured and tan. This leads to a nutmeg liver appearance. With longstanding failure, the central areas can become fibrotic, eventually culminating in cardiac cirrhosis.

Pathological changes are also seen in the spleen and the gastrointestinal tract. Portal venous hypertension also causes the enlargement of the spleen, with platelet sequestration. This is known as congestive splenomegaly. This can also contribute to chronic congestion and oedema of the bowel.

questions.text:
A young boy who underwent an ileal resection developed bilateral centrocecal scotomas. Which of the following enzymes are dependent on the vitamin that is deficient in this condition?

1. Methylmalonyl CoA mutase
2. Cystathionine synthase
3. Folate reductase
4. Methionine synthase
questions.solution:
The clinical stem of bilateral centrocecal scotomas in a patient who had an ileal resection is suggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency. Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase and methionine synthase (1 and 4) are vitamin B12–dependent enzymes.

Vitamin B12 is absorbed by the terminal ileum. Thus, after ileal resection as in this patient, the development of vitamin B12 deficiency is likely. 

The vitamin B12–dependent enzymes:

  • Methionine synthase (homocysteine methyltransferase): It catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine to methionine.
  • Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase: It catalyzes the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA. The activity of this enzyme is greatly reduced in vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to an accumulation of methylmalonyl-CoA and urinary excretion of methylmalonic acid, which is used to assess vitamin B12 nutritional status.

Urinary excretion of methylmalonic acid is also used to differentiate between megaloblastic anemia due to folate and vitamin B12 deficiency.

Other options:

Option 2- Cystathionine synthase is involved in the production of cystathionine from homocysteine and serine. Pyridoxal phosphate (the active form of vitamin B6) is required for this reaction. Hence, in vitamin B6 deficiency, homocysteine levels are elevated.

Option 3- Dihydrofolate reductase catalyzes the conversion of dihydrofolate and tetrahydrofolate. It is an NADPH-dependent reaction.

questions.text: A new factory has been given a license to fortify salt with iodine. What is the minimum recommended content of iodine in salt at the production level?
questions.solution:
The minimum recommended content of iodine in salt at the production level is 30 ppm.

Level of iodization

  • At consumer level: 15 ppm
  • At production level: 30 ppm

Goitrogens are chemical substances that interfere with iodine utilization by the thyroid gland, leading to the development of goiter. The brassica group of vegetables like cabbage and cauliflower contain goitrogens.

The daily requirement of iodine is 150 mcg for adults and 250 mcg in pregnancy.

Disorders due to iodine deficiency:

  • Goiter
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Retarded physical and mental development
  • Intrauterine death (spontaneous abortion and stillbirth)
  • Endemic cretinism

The National Iodine Deficiency Disorders Control Program conducts surveys to assess the magnitude of iodine deficiency disorders. The program conducts a resurvey every 5 years to assess the effect of the impact of iodized salt. They also supply iodized salt and conduct laboratory monitoring of iodized salt and urinary iodine excretion.

Global Iodine Deficiency Disorders Prevention Day is observed on 21st October every year.

questions.text: A patient with a pituitary tumor has increased levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). This leads to the excess synthesis of thyroid hormones. Which of the following proteins is upregulated by the TSH to increase iodine uptake into thyroid follicular cells?
questions.solution:
The TSH upregulates the Na-I symporter (sodium-iodide symporter) to increase iodine uptake into thyroid follicular cells.

Na-I symporter (NIS) is the protein on the basolateral membrane of thyrocytes facing the capillaries. It mediates the entry of iodide into thyrocytes through secondary active transport. It transports two ions of sodium and one ion of iodine in the same direction (symporter) utilizing energy from the Na, K ATPase pump. TSH controls both the expression and retention of NIS in the basolateral membrane.

It is responsible for the uptake of iodide in the thyroid, salivary, mammary, gastric, and intestinal glands. It is regulated transcriptionally by the action of TSH.

The absence of NIS is implicated in causing congenital hypothyroidism. NIS is also upregulated in some thyroid cancers like papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. This is used in the targeted treatment of thyroid cancers using therapeutic doses of radioiodine, which will be accumulated into cancer cells because of NIS.

Iodide exit from thyrocytes into colloid occurs on the apical surface and is mediated via Cl-I exchanger. It is also known as pendrin. A defect in this protein is associated with Pendred syndrome (thyroid dysfunction and deafness).

questions.text: A 53-year-old menopausal lady presents with bleeding per vagina. Ultrasound of her pelvis shows a thick endometrial stripe, which on biopsy showed grade 1 adenocarcinoma of the endometrium. Identify the true statements regarding this condition.

choices.text: Glandular pattern is maintained and cells do not show atypia
Glandular pattern is maintained but cells show atypia
Glandular pattern is lost but cells do not show atypia
Glandular pattern is lost and cells show atypia

questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation is indicative of endometrial cancer. Grade 1 endometrial carcinoma shows cellular atypia and the regular glandular pattern is maintained.

The grading of endometrial tumors is based on differentiation, glandular architecture, and anaplasia of the cells. It is as follows,

  • Grade 1: The glandular pattern is maintained, but cells show atypia.
  • Grade 2: Some glands show the papillary pattern and are solid.
  • Grade 3: The glands are solid with cellular proliferation, and glandular architecture is lost. The endometrium is packed with glands and little stroma.

The histopathology image below shows endometrioid endometrial adenocarcinoma with malignant endometrial glands and metaplasia at high magnification.

Histopathological image (a) and (b) of a well-differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma is shown below.

Histologically, adenocarcinoma is the most common type of endometrial carcinoma amounting to 75%. The rest are clear cells, squamous and serous variety. They are more malignant than adenocarcinoma.

Patients with endometrial cancer present with post-menopausal bleed or abnormal uterine bleeding in the perimenopausal period.

Aspiration cytology from the uterine cavity every 6 months is an effective method of screening in high-risk cases. Ultrasonography is a useful modality for the assessment of endometrial thickening and associated ovarian tumors.

questions.text: A patient was administered with an epidural block with 1.5 % lignocaine with epinephrine. After 20 minutes, the patient went into bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea presenting 20 minutes after epidural injection suggest accidental subdural injection.

Clinical presentation of subdural anesthesia is similar to that of high spinal anesthesia, with the exception that the onset may be delayed for 15–30 min and the block may be patchy.

Unlike the epidural space, the subdural space extends intracranially. Hence, the anesthetic injected into the subdural space can ascend to higher levels than epidural medications.

As with high spinal anesthesia, treatment is supportive and may require intubation, mechanical ventilation, and cardiovascular support.

Other options: 

Option B - Accidental intrathecal injection would result in total spinal anesthesia. Onset is rapid because the amount of anesthetic required for epidural anesthesia is five to ten times more than what is required for spinal anesthesia. Incidence can be reduced by carefully aspirating the needle before every injection. 

Option C - Accidental intravascular injection manifests as seizure, unconsciousness, hypotension, arrhythmias, and decreased contractility. Incidence can be reduced by carefully aspirating the needle before every injection. 

Option D - Epidural hematoma would present with sharp back and leg pain with motor weakness or sphincter dysfunction. It can occur immediately, on inserting or removal of an epidural catheter.

questions.text: A study was done in 1978 in which babies born between 1969 to 1975 were investigated for the effects of electronic fetal monitoring during labor. The number of neonatal deaths was measured. This is an example of which of the following type of study?
questions.solution:
This is an example of a retrospective cohort study since the outcome (neonatal death) has already occurred before the start of the investigation. The investigators went back in time (1969 to 1975) to select the study groups.

Cohort study: It progresses from cause to effect, as exposure has occurred but not the disease.

  • Prospective/ concurrent cohort study: The outcome has not occurred at the time the investigation begins. It will start in present and continue in the future.
  • Retrospective/ historical cohort study: The outcome has already occurred at the time the investigation begins. The investigation started in the past and continued till the present.
  • Combination of prospective and retrospective cohort study: Outcome has already occurred at the time investigation begins. The investigation is done from the past to the present. And then from the present, it is followed up in the future, looking at the effects of the outcome.

In a case-control study, progression is from effect to cause as an outcome or disease has already occurred. It uses a control group to compare and support the inference.

A nested case-control study is a case-control study nested in a cohort study. Cases of a disease occurring in a defined cohort are identified. Their controls are those who have not developed the disease by the time the disease occurred in the case. They are also taken from the same cohort.

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

Related Pearl: Randomized Controlled Trials

Randomized controlled trials are a type of experimental studies.

Types

  • Clinical trials
  • Preventive trials
  • Risk factor trials
  • Cessation experiments
  • Trial of etiological agents
  • Evaluation of health services

General Design of an RCT

Steps of an RCT

  • Drawing up a protocol
  • Selecting reference and experimental population
  • Randomization
  • Manipulation or intervention
  • Follow-up
  • Assessment of outcome.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with burns is brought to the emergency room. On examination, he weighs approximately 80kgs and is found to have burns over 30% of his total body surface area. The rate at which Ringer's lactate should be administered to him initially is:
questions.solution:
The rate at which Ringer's lactate should be administered to him is 300 mL/hr.

The initial rate at which Ringer's lactate can be administered is rapidly estimated by multiplying the total body surface area (TBSA) burned by 10 in adults. Thus, the rate of infusion for a man with a 30% TBSA burn would be:

%TBSA x 10 = 30% x 10 = 300 mL/hr

An alternate method of calculating is by using the ATLS- 10th edition guidelines. Initial fluid resuscitation for adults with deep partial and full-thickness burns involving >20% of the total body surface area (TBSA) is calculated as:

2 ml of Ringer’s lactate x patient’s body weight in kg x % TBSA

= 2 x 80 x 30 = 4800 ml.

Half of this is given in the first 8 hours and the remaining half in the next 16 hours. Therefore, 4800/2= 2400ml is to be provided in the initial 8 hours. The rate of fluid administration will be:

2400/8 = 300 mL/h

These formulas give a starting target rate. The amount of fluid administered should eventually be adjusted based on urine output. The target urine output is 0.5 mL/kg/hr for adults.

Ringer's lactate is preferred for initial resuscitation because its composition and osmolality closely resemble normal bodily physiological fluids. It also contains lactate which may buffer metabolic acidosis in the early postburn phase.

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.
