2nd/3rd-degree burns Adults  2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 0.5
<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text:
A 19-year-old female patient presented to the emergency with an altered sensorium. A non-contrast CT revealed hydrocephalus, requiring urgent surgical intervention. The patient had nobody accompanying her or any identity proof. Under which of these sections of the BNS (IPC) can the neurosurgeon perform the procedure without obtaining informed consent from the guardian?

IPC- Indian Penal Code
questions.solution:
BNS Sec 30 (92 IPC) deals with an act that is done in good faith without consent.

The following situations would apply:

  • Emergency (No need to take consent during emergencies)
  • The person is incapable of giving consent
  • The person has no guardian to give consent

Other options:

Option A- BNS Sec 28 (90 IPC) deals with consent known to be given under fear or misconception and consent of the insane person.

Option C- BNS Sec 33 (95 IPC) deals with the act causing slight harm.

Option D- BNS Sec 26 (88 IPC) deals with acts done by consent in good faith for a person's benefit, not intended to cause death.

questions.text: Which of the following treatment mode is not recommended in patients diagnosed with acute respiratory distress syndrome?
questions.solution:
High-frequency oscillatory ventilation is not recommended in patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). 

Recommended therapies in ARDS with clinical or supportive evidence are:

  • Low tidal volume mechanical ventilation
  • High PEEP (positive end-expiratory pressure)or open lung mechanical ventilation
  • Prone position
  • Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO)

Low tidal volume mechanical ventilation has a significantly low mortality rate than conventional tidal volume mechanical ventilation. Mechanical ventilation in prone positioning improves arterial oxygenation and reduction in mortality.

High PEEP to atelectatic lung can increase oxygenation but mortality reduction is not observed. Improvement in mortality of patients ARDS is observed in lung replacement therapy with ECMO.

ARDS is a clinical syndrome of severe dyspnea of rapid onset, hypoxemia, and diffuse pulmonary infiltrates resulting in respiratory failure. 

Majority of ARDS cases are associated with clinical disorders like pneumonia and sepsis followed by gastric content aspiration, multiple transfusions, and drug overdose.

Surgical conditions associated with ARDS in patients with trauma are pulmonary contusion, multiple bone fractures, and chest wall trauma.

The three characteristic phases of ARDS are:

  • Exudative phase
  • Proliferative phase 
  • Fibrotic phase

Chest radiographs show bilateral opacities consistent with pulmonary edema.

The initial management of ARDS includes treating the underlying medical and surgical disorders, early volume or pressure-limited ventilation, oxygenation, correction of acidosis, and diuresis.

questions.text: What drug is used to estimate pseudocholinesterase function?
questions.solution:
Dibucaine is a local anaesthetic which measures pseudocholinesterase function but not the amount of enzyme.

It inhibits normal pseudocholinesterase activity by 80% but inhibits atypical enzyme activity by only 20%.

Dibucaine number refers to the percentage of inhibition of pseudocholinesterase activity. A patient with normal pseudocholinesterase has a dibucaine number of 80.

Therefore, the adequacy of pseudocholinesterase can be determined:

  • Quantitatively in units per liter - in the laboratory
  • Qualitatively by dibucaine number 

Related Pearl: Dibucaine number

  • High dibucaine number (80) means the high quantity of normal and low quantity of atypical pseudocholinesterase: normal response to succinylcholine and mivacurium.
  • Low dibucaine number (<30) means the low quantity of normal and high quantity of atypical pseudocholinesterase: prolonged succinylcholine and mivacurium block.

questions.text: A patient with complaints of nasal obstruction and nasal discharge was diagnosed to be a case of an antrochoanal polyp. All of the following statements are true about the condition except
questions.solution:
All of the above statements about the antrochoanal polyp are true except it is bilateral.

Antrochoanal polyp is a type of non-neoplastic nasal polypoidal masses of edematous nasal or sinus mucosa. It arises from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum near its accessory ostium, comes out of it, and grows in the choana and nasal cavity. It is usually single and unilateral which are more commonly seen in children and young adults. 

It has 3 parts namely

  • Thin antral stalk,
  • Round and globular choanal part, and
  • Flat nasal part.

The clinical features include unilateral nasal obstruction, mucoid nasal discharge, and a hyponasal voice.

Anterior rhinoscopy may miss the antrochoanal polyp when it starts to grow posteriorly. A large polyp may protrude from the nasal cavity and may appear pink and congested. It is soft and can be moved with a probe. Posterior rhinoscopy may reveal a globular mass filling the choana and hanging down behind the soft palate.

Diagnosis is made by radiograph of the paranasal sinuses reveals opacity of the involved antrum. Non-contrast CT scan reveals the extent of the polyp. Endoscopic examination reveals the antrochoanal polyp hidden posteriorly in the nasal cavity.

Endoscopic sinus surgery is the treatment of choice. Recurrence is uncommon after the complete removal of the polyp.

Related Pearl: Antrochoanal Polyp

  • Main etiological factors: Infection and allergy
  • Usually affects children
  • Site of origin: Mucosa of the maxillary antrum
  • Clinical features:
    • Usually single and unilateral
    • Unilateral nasal obstruction which becomes bilateral when it grows posteriorly and obstructs opposite choana
    • Mucoid nasal discharge
    • Hyponasal voice
  • Findings:
    • Grows posteriorly and usually missed on anterior rhinoscopy
    • Posterior rhinoscopy: Globular mass filling the choana or nasopharynx
  • Investigation: Nasal endoscopy: Shows nasal polyps that are pale, gelatinous and pedunculated. NonContrast CT scan: Gives exquisite bony detail of the paranasal sinus anatomy. It is the primary diagnostic imaging modality.
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

questions.text: Which of the following antidepressants causes the least sexual dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Among the given options mirtazapine causes the least sexual dysfunction.

Mirtazapine and mianserin block histamine H1 receptors and also have high antagonistic activity against 5HT2A, 5HT2C, and 5HT3 receptors. Sexual dysfunction is not a known side-effect of mirtazapine.

Due to its sedative effect, mirtazapine is used in depression with insomnia. 

Option A: Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) that can cause side effects like GI disturbances, sexual dysfunctions, may increase the risk of suicidal thoughts or behavior, risk of serotonin syndrome with MAOIs, and some CYP interactions. Vilazodone is an SSRI not associated with sexual dysfunction or weight gain.

Option B: Serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors like venlafaxine have side effects that include nausea and dizziness, may increase the risk of suicidal thoughts or behavior, and can also cause sexual dysfunctions.

Option D: Tricyclic antidepressants like imipramine have side effects like orthostatic hypotension, weight gain, GI disturbances, sexual dysfunction, seizures, and irregular heartbeats.

questions.text: A male patient has presented with complaints of excessive sweating,  severe muscle aches, yawning, profuse diarrhea, and insomnia. He had been using methadone twice daily and stopped the use two days back. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is opioid withdrawal, due to the sudden stoppage of methadone, an opioid agonist.

Opioid withdrawal arises after cessation or reduction of heavy and prolonged opioid use. It can also be due to the administration of an opioid antagonist after a period of opioid use. Some of the clinical features are dysphoria, nausea, vomiting, muscle aches, lacrimation, yawning, and fever. Diarrhea, insomnia, pupillary dilation, and sweating can also be seen. It results in clinically significant distress and impairment of social or occupational functioning. A single injection of morphine or heroin during the abstinence period alleviates all the symptoms.

Morphine, heroin, methadone, and meperidine are the various opioid drugs. Methadone withdrawal generally begins in 1-3 days after the last dose and ends in 10-14 days.

Other options:

Option A: Cocaine use disorder is marked by irritability, inability to concentrate, insomnia, nasal congestion, and weight loss. Social and occupation functioning is usually impaired.

Option B: Opioid intoxication is characterized by bradycardia, hypotension, respiratory depression, hypothermia, and pinpoint pupils. Respiratory depression can even result in death.

Option C: Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) usage results in dilated pupils, increased deep tendon reflexes, and muscle tension. Mild motor incoordination and ataxia are also common features.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman was brought with complaints of confusion and agitation. Her husband reports that she drinks 2-3 beers a day and that she had taken excessive alcohol the previous day. On examination, she had difficulty in walking and horizontal nystagmus. The vitals and results of laboratory investigations are given below. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

Vitals and laboratory investigations:

  • BP: 138/90 mmHg
  • Pulse: 85 beats/min
  • Temp: 98.7 F
  • Hb: 11.3 g/dL
  • MCV: 110 fL
  • Fingerstick glucose (GRBS): 64 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The patient presents with confusion, agitation, and horizontal nystagmus. This clinical history along with the recent history of heavy alcohol intake is suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy.

The current standard of treatment for patients with symptoms of Wernicke's encephalopathy is to give thiamine (vitamin B1) 100 mg intravenously before administering glucose-containing IV fluids.

Chronic alcoholics have thiamine (B1) deficiency, which gets exacerbated with recent excessive intake.

Thiamine deficiency leads to the following:

  • Wernicke’s encephalopathy: It is more commonly seen in alcoholics with chronic thiamine deficiency. It is characterized by :
    • Global confusion
    • Truncal ataxia
    • Ophthalmoplegia
    • Horizontal nystagmus 
  • Korsakoff psychosis: symptoms in addition to those of Wernicke's encephalopathy include:
    • Memory loss
    • Confabulation
  • Beriberi: It can present with sensorimotor peripheral neuropathy, and muscle weakness (dry beriberi) or tachycardia, cardiomegaly, high-output cardiac failure (wet beriberi).

Hence, the initial treatment in a patient with high alcohol intake with new-onset ataxia should be emergent IV thiamine infusion to prevent the progression of Wernicke encephalopathy.

Other Options:

Option B- IV glucose: It should be given after IV thiamine in an alcoholic patient to treat hypoglycemia. Because if given before, it will worsen thiamine deficiency and will deteriorate this patient's condition.

Option C- IV naltrexone: It is given to abstain from alcohol use, not for treatment of Wernicke encephalopathy

Option D- IV vitamin B12: Although this patient has macrocytosis and difficulty walking, nystagmus is not a feature of vitamin B12 deficiency. Hence, it is not given. Macrocytosis in this patient is due to chronic alcohol use.

questions.text: A 23-year-old patient with sickle cell anaemia presents with fever and malaise. IgM ELISA confirms a parvovirus B19 infection. Which of the following crises will you expect to see in this patient?
questions.solution:
Aplastic crisis in sickle cell anaemia is caused by parvovirus B19. It is a transient arrest of erythropoiesis, usually triggered by an acute parvovirus infection. Parvovirus infects and kills red cell precursors. It occurs in sickle cell disease and other hemolytic anaemias.

Vaso-occlusive crises (pain crises) are episodes of hypoxic injury and infarction that cause severe pain in the affected region. The most commonly involved sites are the bones, lungs, liver, brain, spleen, and penis. Acute chest syndrome is a type of vaso-occlusive crisis involving the lungs. It typically presents with fever, cough, chest pain, and pulmonary infiltrates. Pulmonary inflammation may cause blood flow to become sluggish and “spleenlike,” leading to sickling and vaso-occlusion. 

Sequestration crises occur in children with intact spleens. Massive entrapment of sickle red cells leads to rapid splenic enlargement, hypovolemia, and sometimes shock. Both sequestration crises and acute chest syndrome may be fatal and sometimes require prompt treatment with exchange transfusions.

questions.text: A drug trial compares the effect of a drug compared to placebo in decreasing cholesterol levels in 2 groups of 500 individuals each. A side effect to be studied simultaneously is the elevation of creatine kinase due to rhabdomyolysis. 10 individuals who received the drug develop this side effect, while only 5 individuals who are on placebo have this side effect. Calculate the number needed to harm (NNH).
questions.solution:
The number needed to harm (NNH) for this particular drug is 100.

The number needed to harm is given as the number of individuals we need to treat, to encounter an effect or side-effect of a particular drug. The higher the NNH, the better is the drug.

For example, if we see a side effect of a drug in 1 out of every 100 patients we are treating, it is better as compared to encountering 1 side effect after treating 10 patients.

The NNH to harm is 100 and 10 respectively in these cases, and the former drug is better because it has lesser side effects.

NNH is calculated as 1/absoulte risk increase (i.e. 1/ARI).

Step1: Calculate the risk of side effects with the drug as well as placebo

The risk with drug = 10/500

The risk with placebo = 5 /500

Step 2: Calculate the absolute risk increase:  ARI= side effect with drug-side effect even with placebo

10/500 - 5/500 = 5/500 = 1/100 = 0.01

Step 3: Calculate the NNH

1/ARI = 1/0.01 = 100

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is referred to an endocrinologist with severe obesity and insatiable hunger despite adequate nutrition. Due to the early-onset severe obesity, genetic testing was done and revealed inactivating mutations in the leptin gene. Which of the following neuroendocrine abnormalities is this child most likely to develop?
questions.solution:
The most prominent neuroendocrine abnormality seen in obese individuals with inactivating mutations in the leptin (ob gene) or leptin receptor (db gene) is hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

Leptin mutations are responsible for a rare form of obesity that runs in families. These mutations prevent leptin from delivering satiety signals. Hence, the brain perceives starvation despite adequate nutrition. It results in morbid, early-onset obesity.

Mutations in the following genes can cause obesity in humans:

  • Lep (ob)
  • LepR (db)
  • POMC
  • PC-1
  • MC4R

questions.text: The following egg belongs to:
questions.solution:
The image shows a non-operculated, yellowish-brown egg with a lateral spine near the rounded posterior end is suggestive of Schistosoma mansoni.

Adult worms of S. mansoni live in the inferior mesenteric vein and their infective form is fork-tailed cercaria.

Following skin penetration by cercariae, a pruritic rash termed cercarial dermatitis or swimmers itch develops locally which is self-limiting.

After 4- 8 weeks of the cercarial invasion, high worm load, and egg antigen stimuli lead to the formation of immune complexes which result in serum sickness-like illness termed Katayama fever. They present with high-grade fever, rash, arthralgia, hepatosplenomegaly. lymphadenopathy and eosinophilia. 

When eggs get deposited in the small intestine, patients develop abdominal pain and blood dysentery for a long time called intestinal bilharziasis. The eggs deposited in the intestinal wall lead to microabscesses, granulomas, hyperplasia, and fibrosis. 

The drug of choice is praziquantel 40mg/kg single oral dose. Oxamniquine 15mg/kg single oral dose is also an effective dose. It distorts the tegument of the male worm and makes the worm more susceptible to the lethal action of the immune system.

Other options:

Option B- In Schistosoma hematobium, the egg has a terminal spine.

Option C- In Schistosoma japonicum, the egg has no spine but shows a lateral small rudimentary knob.

Option D- Schistosoma mekongi is similar to S.japonicum but is slightly smaller and round.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic woman presents with an ulcerative vulval lesion that bleeds. Biopsy confirms a diagnosis of vulvar carcinoma. The gynecologist is concerned about the involvement of lymph nodes. Which nodes are usually the first to be involved in such cases?
questions.solution:
The superficial inguinal lymph nodes are usually the first to be involved in vulvar carcinoma.

Vulval cancer is generally seen in elderly women and they present with vulvar pruritus, vulvar swelling, lump, or an ulcer. The lump is papular with a raised pigmented area. The ulcers have often everted margins with fissured, cracked, and indurated surrounding skin. They usually bleed and cause offensive vulval discharge. The lesions are most commonly seen over the labia major.  HPV or HIV infection, diabetes, hypertension, and obesity are associated with vulval cancers. 

The order of lymph node involvement in vulval cancer includes mainly the superficial inguinal lymph node, deep inguinal lymph node, and femoral group of lymph nodes. The external iliac, obturator, and common iliac nodes are also involved in the advanced stages.

Surgical morbidity in early vulval cancer can be reduced by restricting unnecessary lymph node dissection but it is necessary for the determination of the extent of primary lymph node (sentinel) involvement. Lymphatic mapping and sentinel node biopsy (frozen section) before or during surgery help to attain an adequate surgical procedure with a good prognosis.

Mapping is done by:

  • Intraoperative intradermal injection of blue dye around the tumor has reported a detection rate of 100%
  • Localization of radioactive tracer-labeled tissue with a hand-held detector
  • Lymphoscintigraphy also gives a 100% detection rate

For the treatment of vulval cancer in young women, conservative ablative surgery, as well as wide local excision, is adequate. A simple vulvectomy is performed in elderly women. Radical vulvectomy is recommended in patients with regional lymph node involvement.

The prognosis depends upon the lymph node status.

  i) Upper urethral and/or vaginal mucosa, bladder mucosa, rectal mucosa, or fixed to the pelvic bone, or
  ii) Fixed or ulcerated inguinofemoral lymph nodes
IVB Any distant metastasis including pelvic lymph nodes

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented with complaints of a runny nose and multiple bouts of sneezing. He has had such symptoms on and off since childhood and his symptoms worsen in the spring and when he goes out of the house. He is given a drug that has the action of leukotriene receptor antagonism for his condition. Which among the following drugs is the drug given to the patient?
questions.solution:
Zafirlukast and montelukast are leukotriene receptor antagonists. 

The leukotrienes are proinflammatory mediators produced from arachidonic acid via the 5-lipoxygenase (5-LO) pathway. These drugs are competitive antagonists of the cys LT1 receptor and hence decrease bronchoconstriction, airway mucus secretion, increased vascular permeability, and recruitment of eosinophil.

This patient with symptoms of runny nose and multiple bouts of sneezing along with worsening of his symptoms in spring and outside environment strongly suggests allergic rhinitis as the diagnosis.

Uses: 

Montelukast and Zafirlukast are indicated for the treatment of allergic rhinitis. Antileukotrienes are useful in preventing exercise-induced asthma. They act mainly by inhibiting bronchoconstriction.

In some patients, anti leukotriene agents are effective as monotherapy in the treatment of mild to moderate persistent asthma, although the mean efficacy of anti leukotriene agents is lower than that of inhaled glucocorticoids (IGCs). Thus, IGCs are preferred first-line controller agents, and anti leukotriene agents are considered alternatives, particularly in patients who have difficulty with adherence or inhaler technique.

Adverse effects:

  • Zileuton, montelukast, and zafirlukast are all associated with rare cases of hepatic dysfunction. Hence, liver function tests should be monitored during the course of their therapy.
  • Churg-Strauss syndrome consisting of vasculitis with eosinophilia is associated with the use of montelukast and zafirlukast. 

Other options:

Option A- Ketotifen is a mast cell stabilizer used for the management of bronchial asthma and allergic disorders such as atopic dermatitis, allergic rhinitis/conjunctivitis, and chronic urticaria. Oral ketotifen possesses both anti-mediator and mast cell-stabilizing properties.

Option B- Cromolyn sodium is a mast cell stabilizer. It inhibits the release of mediators of inflammation, including histamine and leukotrienes, from the mast cells that are induced by reactive antigens that result in allergic symptoms and bronchoconstriction.

Option D- Zileuton is a 5-lipoxygenase inhibitor and helps to reduce inflammation, edema, mucus secretion, and bronchoconstriction in the airways.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was brought to the orthopedic department with pain and swelling in the right thigh for a few weeks. X-ray of the right femur showed a lesion as shown below.  Biopsy from the lesion showed small blue tumor cells which are PAS-positive. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A clinical scenario of a 6-year-old boy with painful swelling in his thigh and an X-ray showing onion skin periosteal reaction with biopsy demonstrating PAS-positive cells is suggestive of Ewing sarcoma.

Ewing sarcoma is the second most common non-hematologic primary bone malignancy in patients younger than 30 years. They are commonly seen in young patients aged 5 to 25 years and predominantly in males.

They commonly occur in the metaphysis of long bones which extend into diaphysis too. Most of the patients present with pain that is insidious in onset. Fever, swelling, and erythema may also be present. Laboratory findings may show an elevated WBC count, ESR, and CRP.

Radiological examination shows a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of long bones with onion skin periosteal reaction.

Cytogenetic examination of showing t(11:22)(q24:q12)is the most common translocation diagnostic of Ewing's sarcoma.

Histology shows small blue round tumor cells that are PAS-positive, as tumor cells are rich in glycogen. However, they stain negatively for reticulin.

The image given below shows PAS staining done in Ewing's sarcoma.

Note: Lymphomas are PAS negative and reticulin positive.

Ewing sarcoma is radiosensitive. Large unresectable tumors are treated with radiation while small resectable tumors are more likely to be treated with surgery. Treatment always includes adjuvant or neoadjuvant chemotherapy. 

Histologic grade doesn't have any prognostic significance since all Ewing sarcoma are considered as high grade.

Poor prognostic factors of Ewing sarcoma :

  • Distant metastases
  • Size of the primary lesion
  • Fever, anemia
  • Elevated WBC count, ESR, and LDH
  • Age between 12- 15 years

Other options:

Option B: Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignancy of bone. It has a bimodal age distribution- at adolescence and in the seventh decade. It is typically seen in metaphyseal regions of the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. 

X-ray shows periosteal reaction and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance as shown below.

Option C: Chondroblastoma is a benign cartilaginous tumor occurring mainly in long bones. On X-rays, they appear as a well-circumscribed, round, or oval lytic lesion in the center of the epiphysis of long bones with areas of calcification within the tumor. On histology presence of "chicken wire calcification" is pathognomic.

The image below shows an X-ray with a well-circumscribed, round lytic lesion in the center of the epiphysis of the tibia suggestive of chondroblastoma.

Option D: Chondrosarcoma is the second most common primary malignant bone tumor after osteosarcoma. It can present between the 3rd-8th decade of life. They are slow-growing tumors that produce deep pain with an enlarging mass and arise in any bone-derived from enchondral ossification. Radiographically, they appear as large, intraosseous, osteolytic tumors with irregular granular calcifications giving a 'honeycomb' or 'popcorn' appearance. CT and MRI are useful in the diagnosis. Chondrosarcoma is resistant to both chemotherapy and radiation. Surgical excision is the only treatment.

The below radiograph shows popcorn calcification in chondrosarcoma.

questions.solution:
A secondary hydrocele is most commonly caused by an acute or chronic epididymo-orchitis. Other causes of secondary hydrocele include torsion of the testis and testicular tumors.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man was diagnosed with major depression and started on SSRIs. After 1 week of treatment, he returns stating that the medication has not helped him. In the absence of adverse reactions, how long will you continue the medication before considering it as a treatment failure?
questions.solution:
The medication should be continued for 4-6 weeks in major depression before considering it as unsuccessful, provided there are no adverse reactions to it.

Most patients show at least a partial reduction in pretreatment depres­sive symptoms by the 4th week. Lack of a partial response by 4 to 6 weeks indicates that a treatment change is needed. Switching to another drug is preferred over augment­ing the dose of the same drug in the case of initial medication failure.

Antidepressant treatment should be maintained for at least 6 months or the length of a pre­vious episode, whichever is greater. When antidepressant treatment is stopped, the dose should be tapered gradually over 1 to 2 weeks, depending on the half-life of the drug.

Criteria for diagnosing depression:

  1. Depressed mood most of the day
  2. Anhedonia- diminished interest in day to day activities
  3. Significant weight loss or weight gain. Change in appetite.
  4. Insomnia or hypersomnia
  5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation
  6. Fatigue or loss of energy
  7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive, inappropriate guilt
  8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, indecisiveness
  9. Recurrent thoughts of death, suicidal ideation

At least five symptoms must be present over a two-week period and one symptom must be depressed mood or anhedonia.

questions.text: A young female patient is undergoing evaluation for infertility and is posted for a hysterosalpingogram. Which of the following is not a contraindication for hysterosalpingography?
questions.solution:
All of the following are contraindications for hysterosalpingography (HSG) except option C. Uterine synechiae is an indication for HSG.

Contraindications for HSG:

  • Presence of genital tract infection and bleeding
  • Genital Tuberculosis, due to the risk of spreading infection.
  • Suspected pregnancy
  • Allergy to the dye
  • Premenstrual phase
    • If by chance pregnancy has occurred, it may be dislodged.
    • Thick endometrium might prevent the smooth flow of the dye, at the cornual end.
    • There is a risk of embolism and endometriosis if HSG is done during this phase.

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is an imaging technique used for visualization of the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes by the injection of a radiopaque dye. 

It is best performed between day 5 and day 10 of the menstrual cycle.

10-15ml of the dye is injected using a Leech-Wilkinson cannula, Rubin's cannula, or Foley's catheter. If the tubes are patent, the dye will spill out of the tubal ostia and smear the adjacent bowel.

It is used to detect:

  • Tubal patency
  • Uterine anomalies
  • Uterine polyps
  • Uterine synechiae
  • Feasibility of tuboplasty, by studying the location and extent of tubal pathology

questions.text: A 30-year-old man suffered a traumatic brain injury on falling from his motorcycle. When he meets his family, he was not able to identify their faces, however, he could identify them by their voice.  Which of the following areas of the brain is likely to have been injured in this patient?

choices.text: Posterior end of superior temporal gyrus
Inferior end of motor cortex in  frontal  lobe

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of difficulty in identifying known faces is called prosopagnosia. It is due to the lesions in the right inferior temporal lobe in right-handed individuals.

Patients with prosopagnosia can recognize forms and reproduce them. They can recognize people by their voices. Most of them show autonomic responses when they see familiar as opposed to unfamiliar faces. But, they cannot identify the familiar faces they see. 

Other options:

Option A: The region at the posterior end of the superior temporal gyrus is called the Wernicke area. The patient fails to comprehend the meaning of spoken or written words. The speech is full of jargon and neologisms that do not make sense.

Option B: Damage to the inferior and lateral parietal regions of the right hemisphere causes phonagnosia. It is the inability to recognize familiar voices.

Option D: The region at the inferior end of the motor cortex in the frontal lobe is called the Broca area. In this area, the information received from the Wernicke area into a detailed and coordinated pattern for vocalization. A lesion causes nonfluent aphasia characterized by slow speech and difficulty in generating verbal and written words.

Note:

Acalculia is the selective impairment of mathematical ability due to frontal lobe lesions.

questions.text: A teenager was admitted to the hospital for evaluation of mental retardation and delayed growth and sexual development. Ultrasonography revealed thyroid atrophy. Which of the following nutrient deficiency is most likely to be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Selenium deficiency is most likely to be associated with mental retardation and, delayed growth and sexual development in this patient.

The clinical presentation of the child is indicative of a myxedematous type of endemic cretinism, which can be caused by a deficiency of selenium and iodine.

Endemic cretinism includes two overlapping syndromes: a neurologic type and a myxedematous type.

Persons with myxedematous syndrome are intellectually challenged, deaf, and they have delayed growth and sexual development, myxedema, and thyroid atrophy. Delayed skeletal maturation is present, which may extend into the 3rd decade or later.

Selenium deficiency has been implicated in the myxedematous syndrome; it decreases the synthesis of thyroid hormones by impaired functioning of selenoproteins like iodothyronine deiodinases, which are responsible for the conversion of T4 to T3. This decreased production of thyroid hormones leads to the stimulation of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis due to the lack of negative feedback control, thereby, increasing TSH production. TSH stimulates the iodothyronine deiodinases to convert T4 to T3, with consequent production of hydrogen peroxide, which accumulates itself in the thyroid tissue causing thyrocyte damage with subsequent fibrosis. Therefore, serum T4 levels are low and TSH levels are markedly elevated. It also contributes to antioxidant defense in the thyroid. Ultrasonographic examination shows thyroid atrophy.

Other causes of the myxedematous type of endemic cretinism include foods like linseed, sorghum, sweet potato, cabbage, cauliflower, turnips, soy and millet, which are all goitrogenic; thiocyanates and Yersinia.

Deficiency of selenium can also give rise to depressed mood and hostile behaviour; it is implicated in Keshan disease, which is congestive cardiomyopathy along with heart failure, ECG abnormalities, cardiac enlargement and cardiogenic shock, seen in children and women of child-bearing age and in Kashin-Beck disease, which is characterised by bone, cartilage and joint deformity. Additionally, selenium along with vitamin E is essential for normal functioning glutathione peroxidase, an enzyme that protects cell membranes and lipid-containing organelles from peroxidative damage.

Other options:

Option B: Chromium deficiency leads to impaired glucose tolerance.

Option C: Fluoride deficiency leads to an increased susceptibility to dental caries.

Option D: Copper deficiency leads to anemia, growth retardation, defective keratinization and pigmentation of hair, hypothermia, degenerative changes in aortic elastin, osteopenia and mental retardation.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman came with throat pain radiating to the jaw, fever, tremors, palpitations, and heat intolerance for the past 3 weeks. She had an upper respiratory tract infection a few days before these symptoms. Examination reveals a slightly enlarged, extremely tender thyroid gland. Radioiodine uptake scan with scintigraphy will show:

TSH level: 0.04 mIU/L

free T4 level: 2.8 ng/dL

Erythrocyte sedimentation rate: Elevated

Total WBC count: normal
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and elevated ESR are suggestive of the thyrotoxic phase of subacute thyroiditis. It shows reduced uptake of radioiodine on scintigraphy.

Subacute (painful) thyroiditis is also known as de Quervain’s thyroiditis, granulomatous thyroiditis, or viral thyroiditis. It is usually precipitated due to a viral infection, but may also be seen in periods of stress.

They are predominantly seen in the age group of 30-50 years with a female preponderance. 

Patients with subacute thyroiditis usually present with a sore throat, referred pain to neck or ear, history of upper respiratory tract infection. Examination reveals enlarged tender thyroid. 

Thyroid function tests evolve through three distinct phases:

  • In the initial thyrotoxic phase, T4 and T3 are elevated and TSH is suppressed. It is confirmed by high ESR and low radioiodine uptake
  • Hypothyroid phase
  • Later recovery phase

The initial phase of follicular destruction releases thyroid hormones leading to increased circulating T4 and T3 and suppression of TSH.

Treatment is aimed at symptomatic relief. NSAIDs are often effective for mild-to-moderate disease, but glucocorticoids may be necessary for more severe or refractory pain. Anti-thyroid drugs are not effective for the thyrotoxic phase.  Levothyroxine can be given in the prolonged hypothyroid phase. 

Other conditions in which the radioactive iodine uptake is low are:

  • postpartum thyroiditis
  • thyrotoxicosis factitia
  • excessive circulating exogenous iodine (contrast dyes)

Other options:

Option B: Increased patchy uptake is seen in toxic multinodular goiter.

Option C: Increased diffuse uptake is seen in Graves' disease.

questions.text: A 60-year-old chronic smoker presented with progressive dyspnea and mild cough associated with scanty sputum. His chest x-ray showed hyperinflated lung fields and pulmonary function tests showed reduced diffusion capacity of the lung. The gross specimen of a patients lung with similar findings is shown below. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the gross specimen image showing large subpleural bullae in the lung apex are suggestive of emphysema.

Emphysema is a chronic obstructive pulmonary disease commonly seen in patients who are between 50–75 years of age characterized by irreversible dilation and destruction of airspaces distal to the terminal bronchiole (alveoli).

Emphysema is particularly severe in patients with α1-antitrypsin deficiency, and in smokers. Lung tissue destruction is caused by toxic injury, protease- antiprotease imbalance, oxidative stress and infection. As a result, the diffusing capacity may be reduced.

In emphysema, the upper two-thirds of the lungs are markedly affected. Due to hyperinflation, the lungs become voluminous completely eclipsing the heart anteriorly. 

Patients present with chronic cough with expectoration, with dyspnea that progressively worsens, are the disease progresses. their breathing is characteristically through pursed lips. This style of breathing increases airway pressure and prevents bronchial collapse during expiration. They are often referred to as "pink puffers" due to their typical thin non-cyanotic (pink) appearance with severe dyspnea even at rest. 

On microscopy, a thin septum with focal centriacinar fibrosis is seen between abnormally large alveoli. Airspaces with blebs or bullae are seen in advanced disease. There is a loss of elastic tissue in the walls of alveoli in the proximity of bronchioles, due to which there is respiratory collapse during expiration. 

X-ray shows the presence of hyperinflated lung fields as shown below.

The severity of COPD is assessed by using the Global Initiative for Lung Disease (GOLD) criteria. In pulmonary function testing, a postbronchodilator FEV1/FVC ratio of <0.70 is considered diagnostic for COPD.

Other options:

Option B: Chronic bronchitis is a form of COPD, characterised by hyperplasia and hypersecretion of the mucous glands, due to insult by tobacco smoke or air pollutants, mostly in the bronchus and presents with persistent cough and sputum production for 3 months, in at least 2 consecutive years, without any other identifiable cause.

Option C: Bronchiolitis is a disease of the small airways like bronchioles, characterized by scarring of the airways affected due to inflammation and obstruction. The chief symptoms include cough and dyspnea.

Option D: Bronchiectasis is a lung pathology characterized by irregular and irreversible dilatation of bronchi and bronchioles due to the permanent destruction of smooth muscle and elastic components in their walls. Patients present with fever, in addition to symptoms like cough and purulent sputum production.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient came with sharp, severe, constant, burning pain over his right back. On examination, a rash is seen, with lesions as seen in the image below. The area is also tender to light touch. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an elderly patient with burning pain and the image showing a localized, unilateral rash consisting of grouped red papules and a few vesicles are suggestive of herpes zoster. Oral acyclovir 800 mg five times a day for 7-10 days is the treatment of choice.

Herpes zoster is due to the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus (VZV) from the dorsal root ganglia of a sensory nerve following initial infection with varicella (chickenpox) during childhood. The risk of VZV reactivation is greatest in those with advanced age due to waning cell-mediated immunity. Recent trauma also increases the risk due to traumatic sensory nerve stimulation.

It manifests as dermatomal pain (burning, throbbing, stabbing, pruritic) that precedes the rash by days or weeks followed by a unilateral dermatomal rash. The rash begins as erythematous papules, grouped vesicles, and crusts within 7-10 days. The characteristic feature is cut-off at the mid-line. Mucous membranes within the affected dermatome are also involved. The lymph nodes are tender and enlarged.

Treatment involves starting oral acyclovir 800 mg five times a day for 7-10 days or valacyclovir 1 g three times a day for 7 days when the patient presents with one or two days of rash.

The commonest and most intractable sequel of zoster is post‐herpetic neuralgia, generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than a month after the onset of zoster, but better considered after 3 months.

Other Options:

Option A- Oral amitryptiline, a tricyclic antidepressant, is used to treat postherpetic neuralgia. It is not used in the acute phase of herpes zoster.

Option B- Rest and analgesics can be advised in young individuals with mild attacks.

Option C- Intravenous acyclovir is used in immunosuppressed patients and is the second line of treatment.

questions.text: You are assisting a consultant in surgery and at the end of the procedure, you observe him apply sutures in a manner shown in the image below. Identify the suturing technique depicted:.
questions.solution:
Subcuticular sutures have been depicted in the image.

In this technique of suturing, the suture is anchored at one end of the wound. Small bites of subcuticular tissue are taken on alternate sides of the wound and then pulled together gently at the apex. This approximates the wound edges together. The final bite leaves a trailing loop of the suture, and a knot can be tied.

The knots can be tied loosely or secured by means of a collar and bead when non-absorbable sutures are used. If the suture is absorbable, a buried knot is used.

This suturing technique is applied where cosmetic appearance is important and where skin edges are approximated easily.

Other options:

Option A: Interrupted sutures require the needle to penetrate the skin surface at a 90° angle. The distance from the needle to the edge of the wound should be approximately the same as the depth of the tissue being sutured. The suture is then tied using a surgeon's knot in case of nonabsorbable suture or a square knot for absorbable sutures.

The image below shows interrupted sutures.

Option C: Mattress sutures can either be vertical or horizontal. The initial suture is inserted as in an interrupted suture. The needle can then be moved either horizontally or vertically, traversing both edges of the wound once again. Such sutures are very useful in producing an accurate approximation of irregular wound edges. They can produce either eversion or inversion of a wound edge.

The images below show horizontal and vertical mattress sutures.

Option D: Continuous sutures are similar to interrupted sutures but unlike simple interrupted sutures, knots are not tied at every stitch. Only the first and last stitches are fixed by knotting.

Initially, a simple interrupted stitch is placed at one end of the wound but the suture is knotted and not cut. Simple continuous sutures are placed over the length of the wound and each stitch should be placed at an equal distance. The application is terminated by a single knot at the end of the suture line.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with intermittent hematuria and pain in the left flank. He is a chronic smoker and is under medications for hypertension. On examination, the patient appears weak and has a palpable mass in the left flank. His hemoglobin level is found to be 16.5 g/dl. Which of the following mutation will not lead to the condition that the patient has?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario (hematuria, palpable mass, flank pain along with polycythemia) is suggestive of renal cell carcinoma (RCC). MSH2 mutation is not associated with RCC.

Renal cell carcinoma can be sporadic or inherited. Various mutations are implicated in familial cancers. The most common mutation is VHL mutation (clear cell RCC).

Other mutations that can cause renal cell carcinoma include MET mutation (Papillary type RCC), BHD mutation (Birt-Hogg-Dubé syndrome), Xp11 translocation (a subtype that occurs in young patients due to overexpression of TFE3 transcription factor).

MSH2 mutation results in DNA mismatch repair which causes colon cancers including familial hereditary nonpolyposis colon carcinoma and endometrial cancers.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman undergoes hip arthroplasty. The consultant advises starting the patient on anticoagulation to prevent venous thromboembolism.  He specifically asks to administer an anticoagulant that acts by directly inhibiting the thrombin enzyme. Which of the following drugs is the most likely anticoagulant given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor (DTI). They represent a new class of anticoagulant drugs.

Direct thrombin inhibitor – Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTIs) prevent thrombin from cleaving fibrinogen to fibrin. They bind to thrombin directly, rather than by enhancing the activity of antithrombin, as is done by heparin.

  • Parenteral DTIs include bivalirudin, argatroban, and desirudin. 
  • The only oral DTI available for clinical use is dabigatran.

Indications:

  • Prevention of embolic stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation (without valvular heart disease)
  • Venous thromboembolic disease (VTE)
  • Postoperative thromboprophylaxis in patients undergoing hip and knee arthroplasty

Dabigatran is the only oral DTI available for clinical use and is generally given at a fixed dose without monitoring. Maximum anticoagulant effects are achieved within two to three hours of ingestion. Excretion of the unchanged drug by the kidney is the predominant elimination pathway. 

The major adverse effect of dabigatran is bleeding. There is an additional risk for bleeding in renal impairment and concurrent use of antiplatelet agents or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. Dabigatran is contraindicated for stroke prevention in patients with mechanical heart valves.

Other options:

Option A- Warfarin is an anticoagulant that inhibits the enzyme (vitamin K reductase) that catalyzes the conversion of oxidized vitamin K to the reduced form of vitamin K. The reduced vitamin K is involved in the carboxylation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, X, and proteins C and S.

Options B and D- Rivaroxaban and apixaban are direct oral factor Xa inhibitors that inhibit the free and clot-associated factor Xa resulting in reduced thrombin generation.

questions.text: A young woman undergoing vaginal delivery started bleeding after the expulsion of the placenta. Medical management was unsuccessful in arresting the bleeding. So the device shown below was used. What amount of fluid should be instilled into this device to arrest hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
The image shows a Bakri balloon. 300-500 ml of fluid should be instilled into it for it to be effective in arresting hemorrhage

A Bakri postpartum balloon may be inserted and inflated to tamponade the endometrial cavity and stop bleeding in patients with atonic PPH (postpartum hemorrhage) who are unresponsive to medical management. The Bakri balloon has a three-way valve and a separate tubing to drain the blood from the uterine cavity.

Insertion is achieved with help of two or three team members:

  • One to perform abdominal sonography during the procedure
  • Second member to place the deflated balloon into the uterus and stabilize it.
  • The third member instils fluid to inflate the balloon. Inflated rapidly by infusing at least 150 mL followed by further installation over a few minutes for a total of 300 to 500 mL to arrest hemorrhage.

The balloon is usually removed after 12 hours of insertion. It is successful in most cases of atonic PPH and helps to avoid hysterectomy in the majority of cases. 

Segstaken­ Blakemore, Rusch, and ebb balloons, Foley's catheter, and condom catheters can also be used instead. In the technique where Foley's catheter is utilised, a 24F-30F size catheter with a 30ml balloon is used, the tip is guided into the uterine cavity and filled with 60-80ml of saline.  Once the bleeding subsides, the catheter can be removed after 12 -24 hours.

The following are the steps used in controlling the postpartum haemorrhage:

  • Feel the uterus to know the cause of the haemorrhage. If the uterus feels flabby, bleeding is likely to be due to atonicity. If it is firm and contracted, it is likely to be traumatic in origin.
  • In case of an atonic uterus, massage the uterus and start the patient on oxytocin drips or methergine. 
  • If the uterus remains atonic, manual exploration of the uterus is done for removing any retained placental fragments. Blood transfusion is started and oxytocin drips are continued. Other uterotonic agents can also be given.
  • Uterine massage and bimanual compression
  • Uterine tamponade using a hydrostatic balloon catheter (balloon tamponade)
  • Surgical methods to control PPH are outlined as stepwise uterine devascularization procedures:
    • Compression sutures: B-Lynch suture
    • Ligation of uterine arteries
    • Ligation of ovarian and uterine anastomosis
    • Ligation of internal iliac artery
    • Angiographic embolization of the bleeding vessel
  •   Hysterectomy

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient underwent hysterectomy a week ago. Postoperatively she complains of urine dribbling from the vagina. On examination, a vesicovaginal fistula is observed. Which technique of fistula repair is suitable in this case?
questions.solution:
The preferred technique of repair of the vesicovaginal fistula which occurred post-hysterectomy is Latzko's procedure.

Latzko's procedure: It is done by denudation of vaginal epithelium around fistulous edges, freshening the edges, and approximation of raw surface with absorbable sutures. This technique is suited for post-hysterectomy fistula that is caused by a cancer cervix. It can lead to the narrowing of the vagina or vaginal atresia.

Fistula located at the vaginal vault post hysterectomy is the most difficult to treat, this technique is suited for such cases.

In the case of an established fistula, it is better to wait for about 3 months for all tissue inflammation to subside, before surgery is undertaken.

Most vesicovaginal fistulae are repaired vaginally.

The various surgeries done for the repair of VVF (vesicovaginal fistula) are as follows:

  • Latzko procedure
  • Chasser Moir technique
  • Ureteric implantation

Other options:

Option A: Chassar Moir technique widely separated the vagina and bladder all around by the flap-splitting method and suturing the bladder and vagina separately into two. It has the advantage of tension-free sutures and avoidance of the superior position of the bladder over the vaginal suture. 

Option C: Ureteric implantation is considered in cases with extensive loss of bladder tissue, or repetitive failures to close the fistula. Here ureters are implanted into the sigmoid colon creating an ileal loop bladder, or rectal bladder. The disadvantage of this procedure is the high incidence of ascending infection to the kidneys and the risk of electrolyte imbalance.

Option D: Kelly's repair is the anterior colporrhaphy with bladder neck plication done for stress urinary incontinence.

Related Pearl: Difference between bladder fistula & ureteric fistula

Obstetric causes:

  • Prolonged obstructed labor
  • Instrumental deliveries
  • Iatrogenic injury during caesarean section or sling operations

Surgical injury during:

  • Abdominal hysterectomy
  • Vaginal hysterectomy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
  • Laparoscopic surgeries
  • Caesarean section

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is unable to micturate

The patient is able to micturate

Intravenous pyelography Normal Hydronephrosis and hydroureter present on the affected side

 

Related Pearl: Methylene blue - 3 swab test

In the methylene blue 3-swab test, a catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile cotton swabs. One at the vault, one at the middle, and one just above the introitus. A diluted solution of methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a transurethral catheter. After 15 to 30 minutes, the swabs are removed serially and inspected for dye.

Interpretation:

  • Upper swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter: Ureterovaginal fistula
  • Middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder: Vesicovaginal fistula
  • Lower swab gets stained - the leak is from the urethra: Urethrovaginal fistula

The given image shows the 3-swab test.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient reports to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain, distention and vomiting after intake of food. On further investigation, he is found to have gastric outlet obstruction. Identify the false statement regarding this condition

choices.text: Should be considered malignant until proven otherwise
There is hyperkalemia and urine is acidic
Endoscopic biopsy is essential to ascertain the cause
Severe cases are treated with gastroenterostomy

questions.solution:
The false statement is that the patient has hyperkalemia with acidic urine. Patients with gastric outlet obstruction have hypokalemia and acidic urine.

Gastric outlet obstruction (GOO) is a clinical syndrome characterized by epigastric abdominal pain and postprandial vomiting due to mechanical obstruction.

The two common causes of gastric outlet obstruction are gastric cancer and pyloric stenosis secondary to peptic ulceration. Gastric cancer is more common. Therefore, gastric outlet obstruction should be considered malignant until proven otherwise.

In benign gastric outlet obstruction, there is usually a history of peptic ulcer disease. Patients also present with abdominal pain which may become unremitting or completely stop.

The vomitus is non-bile-stained. The food that was consumed even a few days back can be recognized. The patient complains of weight loss, appears unwell and dehydrated. Examination of the patient shows a distended stomach. A succussion splash may be audible on shaking the patient’s abdomen.

Due to the vomiting, there is the elimination of hydrochloric acid and resultant hypochloraemic alkalosis in the body. Initially, the urine has a low chloride and high bicarbonate content. This bicarbonate is excreted along with sodium. With time, the patient becomes progressively hyponatremic and profoundly dehydrated.

Due to this dehydration, a phase of sodium retention occurs. Potassium and hydrogen get excreted preferentially. This results in the urine becoming paradoxically acidic and hypokalaemia ensues. Additionally, tetany can occur as alkalosis leads to a lowering of circulating ionized calcium.

Treatment involves correcting the metabolic abnormalities and management of the mechanical obstruction. The patient should be rehydrated with intravenous isotonic saline with potassium supplementation. Replacing the sodium chloride and water allows the kidney to correct the acid-base abnormality.

The stomach should be emptied using a wide-bore gastric tube. This allows for investigation of the patient with endoscopy with biopsy, which is essential to determine whether the cause is a malignancy. A biopsy done is usually of the area around the pylorus.

Early cases may settle with conservative treatment and only severe cases are treated surgically. The procedure preferred is a gastroenterostomy. Endoscopic balloon dilatation may be most useful in cases with an early presentation.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room with excruciating burning pain over the palms and soles, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and ringing sensation in the ears. On examination, he has thickening of lips, frontal bossing, corneal opacities, and skin lesions as shown in the image below. This X-linked disorder is caused due to which enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Fabry's disease and it is caused due to the deficiency of α-Galactosidase. 

Fabry disease is an X-linked, multisystem, lysosomal storage disorder caused due to mutations in the gene that codes for α-Galactosidase, resulting in decreased activity of the enzyme. This leads to accumulation of globotriaosylceramide. It is seen in both men and women (less severe).

It usually manifests in childhood or adolescence, with symptoms of severe agonizing pain in the palms of hands, soles of feet, and proximal extremities called acroparesthesia, aggravated by changes in temperature, exercise, fatigue, or fever and may last anywhere from a few minutes to many days.

There is a characteristic facial appearance of frontal bossing, thickening of the lips, and prominent supraorbital ridges. Angiokeratomas, as seen in the image above are present, which are lesions that are dark-red to blue-black, flat or slightly raised, punctate, and usually seen between the umbilicus and the knees (called the 'bathing suit area') and the trunk.

Patients also have diarrhea, abdominal distension, heat intolerance, and tinnitus. Late presentations include renal failure, and cardiovascular or cerebrovascular disease, which are the leading causes of death in these patients.

Urinalysis shows proteinuria. An enzyme assay, genetic testing, or a skin or kidney biopsy showing glycolipid deposits helps establish the diagnosis.

Treatment is with enzyme replacement therapy (recombinant alpha-Gal A or migalastat).

Other options:

Option B: β-Glucosidase deficiency manifests as Gaucher disease, which gives rise to symptoms of hepatosplenomegaly, erosion of long bones and mental retardation in infants.

Option C: Sphingomyelinase deficiency manifests as Niemann-Pick disease, with patients presenting with symptoms of hepatosplenomegaly and mental retardation. It is usually fatal in early life.

Option D: Ceramidase deficiency manifests as Farber disease, characterised by dermatitis, hoarseness, skeletal deformities and mental retardation. It is fatal in early life.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented to the emergency room with severe breathlessness. He was referred from another hospital with the diagnosis of acute left heart failure associated with pulmonary edema.  On examination, his blood pressure was 220/120 mmHg. Fundoscopy revealed papilledema. Which of the following drugs is preferred to control his hypertension?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of severe headache, blood pressure of 220/120 mmHg, and fundoscopy showing papilledema is suggestive of a hypertensive emergency. Sodium nitroprusside is the drug infused in the scenario.

A hypertensive emergency is diagnosed when the systolic blood pressure is > 180 mmHg or diastolic blood pressure is>120 mmHg with the presence of end-organ damage.

Sodium nitroprusside is an anti-hypertensive drug. It acts by releasing nitric oxide that activates the guanylyl cyclase. It acts by dilating both arterioles and venules resulting in venous pooling and reduced arterial impedance. 

Sodium nitroprusside is used in the management of hypertensive emergencies and can be used in the short reduction of cardiac preload or afterload. It has been used in reducing blood pressure in acute aortic dissection. It is also used in the management of congestive heart failure associated with pulmonary edema that does not respond to other treatments. 

When nitroprusside is administered at a high rate, it can result in the production of cyanide. Cyanide is further metabolized to thiocyanate. On prolonged infusion, thiocyanate toxicity can also occur especially in patients with renal failure. Excessive concentrations of thiocyanate can result in hypothyroidism. The short-term side effect is hypotension. Nitroprusside can worsen arterial hypoxemia in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease because the drug interferes with hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction and therefore promotes mismatching of ventilation with perfusion.

Other options:

Options A & B - Labetalol is a beta 1 and beta 2 receptor blocker with additional alpha-receptor blocking properties and esmolol cardioselective beta blocker (beta 1). Beta-blockers are contraindicated in the treatment of acute pulmonary edema.

However intravenous esmolol is the preferred drug for hypertensive emergency in aortic dissection where rapid reduction of blood pressure within 5-10 min is essential. If there is no improvement in blood pressure, nitroprusside or nitroglycerin is administered. The target blood pressure is SBP <120mmHg.

Option D- Telmisartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker. It is used in the management of hypertension.

questions.text: A patient was admitted for acute diarrhea and vomiting 2 days ago. The doctor on duty assessed that he has recovered from dehydration and ordered discontinuation of the IV fluids. The ward nurse by mistake administered 0.45% NaCl to this patient. Which of the following Darrow-Yannet diagrams represents the fluid shift in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient did not need IV fluids but was administered hypotonic saline (0.45% NaCl). The Darrow Yannet diagram in image 3 represents the fluid shift in case of hypotonic fluid administration as seen in this patient. 

Darrow Yannet diagrams depict the change in plasma osmolarity and plasma volume in various conditions. The dotted line in the diagram is the change after either the addition or removal of fluid.

Hypotonic saline leads to the decreased osmolarity of the ECF. This causes a shift of fluid from the ECF to the ICF until the osmolarity of both compartments becomes equal. The fluid influx leads to a decrease in the osmolarity of the ICF as well. The net result is the decreased osmolarity and increased volume of both the compartments.

Other options:

Image 1- Normal ECF and ICF balance.

Image 2- The addition of isotonic saline to ECF does not cause any fluid shift from the ICF. Hence, it only leads to an increase in ECF volume without causing any change in osmolarity.

Image 4- The addition of hypertonic saline to the ECF pulls the fluid from the ICF into the ECF. This results in a decreased volume of ICF, increased volume of ECF, and increased osmolarity in both ECF and ICF.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presents with severe dysmenorrhoea and dyspareunia. Examinations reveal a tender retroverted uterus along with a cobblestone feel of the uterosacral ligaments. There are blue-black puckered, tender spots in the posterior and lateral fornices. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the treatment modalities for this condition?

LUNA- Laser uterosacral nerve ablation

choices.text: Gestrinone to decrease the LH surge
Pulsatile GnRH for atrophy of lesions
Mirena IUCD for dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of endometriosis and continuous GnRH administration is used in this condition as it causes endometrial atrophy. It can be given IV and intranasally. 

Endometriosis is defined by the presence of ectopic endometrial tissue at a site outside of the uterus. It is a benign condition but it is locally invasive and it shows the malignant transformation.

Some of the common sites of endometriosis are ovaries, pelvic peritoneum, pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligaments, rectovaginal septum, and sigmoid colon. 

Patients with endometriosis mainly present with progressively increasing secondary dysmenorrhea, menorrhagia, infertility, dyspareunia, and chronic pelvic pain.

MRI is the diagnostic tool, it shows the characteristic hyperintensity on T1 weighted images and hypointensity on T2 weighted images. Laparoscopy confirms the diagnosis.

Medical management of endometriosis:

  • Gestrinone is an anti-estrogenic, anti-progestational, and mildly anabolic drug that reduces sex-hormone-binding globulin to release free testosterone. It also decreases the LH surge. It causes regression of lesions and amenorrhea. It is a 19-nortestosterone derivative similar to danazol, but with fewer side effects. 
  • Combined oral contraceptives are used for symptom control and alleviating disease. These also cause menstrual cycle regulation and delay pregnancy. 
  • Oral progestogens exert an anti-estrogenic effect and cause decidualization and endometrial atrophy. This causes disease regression. It doesn't prevent ovulation, thus is suitable for women who are trying to conceive. 
  • Mirena IUCDs reduce dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia. It is a single-sitting treatment with minimal side effects. 
  • Aromatase inhibitors like letrozole are anti-estrogens given for disease regression. 
  • Anti-inflammatory drugs like mefenamic acid and naproxen relieve dysmenorrhea.

Therapeutic procedures:

  • Aspiration of peritoneal fluid from the cul-de-sac removes PGE2, relieves dysmenorrhea, pelvic pain, and improves fertility 
  • Destruction of endometriotic lesions <3cm with diathermy, Nd-YAG laser, or CO2 vaporization can be attempted. 
  • Larger lesions and chocolate cysts can be excised. 
  • Laparoscopic breaking of adhesions relieves dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain. It also restores tubal patency and improves ovulation. Pre-sacral neurectomy can be done simultaneously. 
  • Laser uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA) is done for pelvic pain.

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: A multiparous woman presents at 36 weeks of gestation. On examination, fundal height is less than the period of amenorrhea. In the fundal grip, the fetal pole is not palpable and in the pelvic grip, the lower pole of the uterus is empty. On the lateral grip, a soft, irregular breech is felt on one side of the midline. Identify the most common fetal position in the given presentation?
questions.solution:
The given examination findings are suggestive of a transverse lie. The most common fetal position in a transverse lie is dorso-anterior.

Transverse lie occurs when the long axis of the fetus lies perpendicularly to the maternal spine or centralized uterine axis.

The position of the fetus in a transverse lie is determined by the direction of the back, which is the denominator. The position may be:

  • Dorsoanterior, which is the most common. (60%)
  • Dorsoposterior, where the chance of fetal extension is common with increased risk of arm prolapse
  • Dorsosuperior 
  • Dorsoinferior

According to the position of the head, the fetal position is termed right or left, the left one being more common.

Abdominal examination findings:

On inspection, the uterus looks broader and is often asymmetrical. It does not maintain the pyriform shape.

Palpation:

  • Fundal height is less than the period of amenorrhea.
  • Fundal grip: Fetal pole (breech or head) is not palpable.
  • Lateral grip: A smooth, hard, and globular head is felt on one side. A soft, broad, and irregular breech is felt on the other side.
    • In dorso-anterior: The back is felt anteriorly across the long axis 
    • In dorso-posterior: Irregular small parts are felt anteriorly
  • Pelvic grip: The lower pole of the uterus is empty.

questions.text: A researcher was studying the symptoms of COVID 19 infection. He found that temporary loss of function of the sustentacular cells of the olfactory epithelium is implicated in anosmia. Which of the following accurately describes these cells?
questions.solution:
The sustentacular cells are supporting cells of the olfactory epithelium.

The nuclei of these cells are oval and lie near the free surface of the epithelium. The free surface of each cell bears numerous microvilli which are embedded in overlying mucous. The cytoplasm contains a yellow pigment termed lipofuscin that gives olfactory mucosa its yellow color. 

Sustentacular cells also may be phagocytic, and the pigment in them may represent remnants of phagocytosed olfactory cells.

Other options:

Options B and C: Olfactory cells or olfactory receptor cells are modified neurons and each has a rounded nucleus in the central part. 

Option D: Basal cells lie deep in the epithelium and will not reach the luminal surface. They divide to replace olfactory cells to replace those that die.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with symptoms of pain, itching and bloody discharge from the right nipple. On examination, there is a crusted lesion that is erythematous and thickened with irregular borders, involving the nipple and areola. A full-thickness wedge biopsy of the lesion was done and the finding is shown in the image below. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Paget's disease of the nipple.

The histologic image shows the presence of malignant, intraepithelial adenocarcinoma cells called Paget cells. They occur singly or in small groups within the epidermis of the nipple.

Paget's disease is a superficial manifestation of underlying breast carcinoma. It is an uncommon presentation of breast carcinoma affecting women between 50 and 60 years of age.

Patients may initially have pain, burning, and pruritus of the nipple. On examination, a crusted lesion with irregular borders or a scaly, raw, vesicular, or ulcerated lesion that begins over the nipple and spreads to the surrounding areola is seen. This may be accompanied by a bloody discharge. Paget's disease is usually unilateral and nipple retraction is a rare finding but may occur with advanced disease.

A bilateral breast examination should be performed. Nipple scrape cytology can accurately diagnose Paget's disease, but the diagnosis is usually established by a full-thickness wedge or punch biopsy of the nipple. 

The histologic hallmark of the disease is the presence of Paget cells. The cells are often large and the cytoplasm is pale to clear, and the nuclei are usually high-grade with prominent nucleoli. 

Management is based on the stage of the tumor and prognostic factors. Simple mastectomy and breast-conserving treatment (BCT) are two of the most common procedures used in the surgical management of the tumour. Sentinel lymph node biopsy should also be done to look for axillary lymph node involvement.

Other options:

Option A: Acute mastitis is usually seen in lactating women, with common etiological factors being inadequate milk sucking by the infant, milk expression causing stasis, and infection from the mouth of the infant. Staphylococcus aureus is the most commonly implicated organism. The affected breast or a segment of it shows the classical signs of acute inflammation which include redness, swelling, and pain. 

Option C: Eczema of the nipples is a rare condition and is often bilateral. It occurs in the younger age group and is also associated with eczema elsewhere over the body. It frequently begins in the areola and may then involve the nipple while Paget's disease originates on the nipple and secondarily involves the areola.

Option D: Duct papillomas are polyploid lesions of epithelial-lined breast ducts. They are often located close to the areola, but when located close to the nipple, blood-stained nipple discharge can be present. They are not associated with an increased risk of breast cancer. On histology, there is a fibrovascular mass from the wall of the duct. The papillae arborize in the lumen as shown in the image below.
