questions.text: A worker at a textile mill complains of exhaustion and fatigue and says he works around 72 hours per week. According to the Factories act of 1948, what are the maximum hours of work per day for an industrial worker?
questions.solution:
According to The Factories act, 1948, the maximum hours of work per day for an industrial worker is 9 hours. It should not be more than 48 hours per week, if working overtime, it should not exceed 60 hours per week. 

Adolescents between 15 and 18 years of age can only be employed in certain industries, and their work hours should not exceed four and a half hours per day.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

questions.text:
You are studying the lung volumes of a patient with COPD using an instrument shown below. Which of the following lung volumes cannot be measured using this instrument?

COPD: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
questions.solution:
The given image shows a spirometer. Residual volume (RV) cannot be measured using this instrument. It also cannot measure any capacity that involves residual volume i.e., functional residual capacity (FRC) and total lung capacity (TLC).

Residual volume is the amount of air remaining in the lung after forceful expiration. As we cannot expire this air, it cannot be directly measured by spirometry.

To measure RV, we need to first measure FRC by the helium dilution technique and then calculate RV by subtracting expiratory reserve volume (ERV) from FRC.

RV = FRC - ERV

A typical basic spirometer consists of a drum inverted over the chamber of water, along with a drum counterbalanced by a weight. When a person breathes into and out of the chamber, the drum rises and falls and recordings are made.

The image below shows a typical basic spirometer.

In the modern dry spirometer, the patient is asked to breathe in and exhale forcefully. The spirometer calculates the volume of air passing through it as a function of time. It hence gives us various parameters useful for the diagnosis of pulmonary/airway disease.

The image below shows the modern dry spirometer.

Related Pearl: Lung volumes and capacities

Measurement

Description

Normal Value

Tidal volume (TV)

The amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration (or the amount that moves out with each expiration) during quiet breathing

500–750 mL.

Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)

The air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the TV

∼3 L

Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)

The volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration

∼1.1 L

Residual volume (RV)

The air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort

∼1.2 L

Total lung capacity (TLC)

IRV+TV+ERV+RV

∼5.8 L

Vital capacity (VC)

IRV+TV+ERV

∼4.5 L

Inspiratory capacity (IC)

TV+IRV

∼3.5 L

Expiratory capacity (EC)

TV+ERV

∼1.6 L

Functional residual capacity (FRC)

ERV+RV

∼2.3 L

questions.text: A 20-year-old man was sexually assaulted by his aunt when he was a child. He remembers the people and events that preceded the assault and the events that followed. However, when asked general questions about his aunt, he does not have any memory of her and cannot remember anything about the time he was sexually assaulted by her. What type of amnesia is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has features of dissociative amnesia. This patient's inability to remember a specific category of information, in this case, about one particular person is indicative of systematized amnesia.

Dissociative amnesia is defined as an inability to recall important auto­biographical information that is successfully stored in memory and ordinar­ily would be readily remembered. It is potentially reversible (unlike amnesias due to neuro-biological damage). The amnesia is predominantly retrograde with minimal anterograde amnesia.

It is usually found in those people who have experienced extreme acute trauma, be it physical, sexual or even in cases involving betrayal by those they implicitly trust. Patients have profound emotional stress and may also present with altered sensorium, depersonalization, trance states, depression and suicidal thoughts.

The DSM-5 diagnostic criteria of dissociative amnesia are:

  • Inability to remember relevant autobiographical information that is inconsistent with ordinary forgetting, with the information being of a traumatic or stressful nature
  • The symptoms cause significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning
  • The disturbance is not attributable to physiological effects of a substance or a neurological/other medical condition
  • The disturbance is not better explained by dissociative identity disorder, posttraumatic stress disorder, acute stress disorder, somatic symptom disorder or other neurocognitive disorders

It is further categorized into the following types:

  • Generalized amnesia - failure to recall one’s entire life. (Option A)
  • Selective amnesia - the ability to remember some, but not all, of the events occurring during a circumscribed period of time. (Option D)
  • Localized amnesia - inability to recall all events related to a circumscribed period of time. 
  • Continuous amnesia - failure to recall successive events as they occur. 
  • Systematized amnesia - amnesia for certain categories of memory, such as all memories relating to one’s family or a particular person.

Note- Anterograde amnesia (Option B) refers to loss of memory for events subsequent to the onset of the amnesia. It is common after a trauma.

Related Pearl: Dissociative Disorders

DSM-5 Classification and characteristics of dissociative disorders:

Dissociative disorder
Characteristic features

Dissociative amnesia:

Failure to remember important information about oneself after a stressful event.

Amnesia usually resolves in minutes or days but may last years. Retrograde amnesia > antegrade amnesia

Dissociative fugue:

Amnesia combined with sudden wandering from home after a stressful event.

Adoption of a different identity. The patient denies memory loss during the fugue state.

Dissociative identity disorder:

Previously called multiple personality disorder.

At least two distinct personalities (“alters”) in an individual.

More common in women (particularly those sexually abused in childhood)

In a forensic setting (Eg: jail), malingering and alcohol abuse must be considered and excluded

Depersonalization disorder:

Recurrent, persistent feelings of detachment from one’s own body, the social situation, or the environment (derealisation) when stressed.

 Understanding that these perceptions are only feelings, i.e., normal reality testing.

Dissociative disorder not otherwise specified:

Dissociate symptom (Eg: trance-like state, memory loss) in - 
  • Persons exposed to intense coercive persuasion (Eg: brainwashing)
  • Indigenous to particular locations or cultures (Eg: Amok in Indonesia)
 

ICD-11 classifies Dissociative Disorders as:

  • Dissociative Identity Disorder
  • Partial Dissociative Identity Disorder
  • Depersonalization-Derealization disorder
  • Dissociative Amnesia
  • Trance Disorder
  • Possession Trance Disorder
  • Dissociative Neurological symptom disorder
  • Secondary Dissociative syndrome

questions.text: A patient with a history of using well water for cooking and consumption presents with vomiting, diarrhea and abdominal pain. On examination, there is jaundice, hemoglobinuria, Mees lines on the nails, and features of hypovolemic shock. A toxicology screen is done, and the 24-hour urine sample is found to contain high amounts of a toxin.  Which enzyme of Kreb's cycle will be inhibited by this toxin?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of arsenic toxicity. Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase (AKG) of Kreb's cycle is inhibited by this toxin, arsenite (inorganic arsenic salt).

α-Ketoglutarate is a rate-determining intermediate in Kreb's cycle. It has a crucial role in cellular energy metabolism as it acts as a precursor of glutamate and glutamine and promotes protein synthesis.

Alpha-ketoglutarate undergoes oxidative decarboxylation to form succinyl-CoA and CO2 with the help of the multienzyme complex, AKG dehydrogenase. This enzyme complex requires the cofactors, thiamin diphosphate, lipoate, NAD+, flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD), and coenzyme A.

Arsenite inhibits this decarboxylation reaction and causes the substrate, α-ketoglutarate, to accumulate. 

Arsenic toxicity is either due to inhalation of toxic arsenic gas or chronic consumption of foods cooked in contaminated well water. It presents with malaise, headache, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, jaundice, hemoglobinuria, and renal failure. There may be hemorrhagic gastroenteritis, hypovolemic shock, and cardiovascular manifestations such as QT prolongation, polymorphous ventricular tachycardia, and congestive cardiomyopathy. Mees lines is a common dermatologic manifestation characterized by transverse white striae on the nail.

Arsenic toxicity is detected by measuring the 24-hour urine excretion of arsenic.


Other options: 

Option A: Glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase is inhibited by iodoacetate. It is not a part of Kreb's cycle.

Option C: Aconitase is inhibited by fluoroacetate.

Option D: Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by malonate.

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

questions.text: The structure marked as '?' in the image below connects which of the following two ventricles?

choices.text: Third ventricle with the lateral ventricles
Third ventricle with the fourth ventricle
Lateral ventricle with the fourth ventricle

questions.solution:
The structure marked in the above image is the cerebral aqueduct of Sylvius which connects the third ventricle with the fourth ventricle.

The cerebral aqueduct is a small, approximately circular tube with a diameter of 1-2 mm. It runs along the midline of the dorsal quarter of the midbrain, surrounded by the periaqueductal (central) grey matter. At the rostral end, it starts just below the posterior commissure and connects to the caudal aspect of the third ventricle. At the caudal end, it continues into the fourth ventricle, located at the junction of the midbrain and pons. In children with von Recklinghausen's disease, primary aqueductal stenosis is a characteristic feature.

 

Other options:

Option A - The third ventricle is connected to the lateral ventricles via the interventricular foramina of Monro on either side.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man who recently read about the Pegasus controversy feels that he is being tracked by government officials. He thinks that someone is recording his movements, and is plotting to kill him. Which of the following statements is true about his condition?

choices.text: It is a true, firm, unshakeable belief
It is also known as Capgras syndrome
It is the most common type of delusion
It is only seen in schizophrenia

questions.solution:
In the clinical scenario, thoughts of being followed and harmed by people represent delusion of persecution. It is the most common type of delusion.

A delusion is a false, firm, fixed (unshakable) belief that is not in keeping with the patient’s socio-cultural and educational background. 

They are of two types based on their origin:

  • Primary - Arise de-novo and cannot be explained based on previous experiences, characteristic of schizophrenia.
  • Secondary - Delusions that are secondary to other morbid psychological conditions like depressive moods and hallucinations.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: A patient comes to you complaining that he experiences a sensation of the room spinning when his head is in a specific position. You diagnose benign paroxysmal positional vertigo in this patient. All of the following statements are true regarding this condition except?
questions.solution:
The posterior semicircular canal is involved in benign paroxysmal positional vertigo. (BPPV)

Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo is characterized by vertigo when the head is placed in one certain critical position. It is not associated with hearing loss or neurological symptoms. It is caused due to the disorder of the posterior semicircular canal.

They are always provoked by changes in head position. The attacks are caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals usually dislodged from the posterior canal. A positive Dix-Hallpike maneuver confirms the diagnosis of BPPV. It is due to otoconial debris getting into the posterior semicircular canal from the utricle. The patient complains of vertigo on moving or tilting the head to the affected side. 

Steps of Dix-Hallpike maneuver:

  • The maneuver starts with the patient in a sitting position.
  • Their head is turned 45 degrees towards the ear to be tested.
  • The examiner quickly brings the patient to a supine position with their head 30 degrees below the horizontal.
  • The 45-degree head rotation is maintained during the procedure.
  • Now the examiner observes the patient eye for nystagmus.

In up to 90 percent of the patients, it can be relieved by administering a therapeutic Epley maneuver on the affected side. Epley's maneuver is performed to reposition the crystals into the macula from the semicircular canals.

questions.text: While recording evidence in the court of law, the lawyer who had called the witness conducts an examination on the witness. He does this to clarify certain doubts and details raised in the cross-examination. What is this procedure called?
questions.solution:
The above procedure is called the re-direct examination.

Re-direct examination is the procedure done by the lawyer who summoned the witness to correct any mistake or clarify or add any details to the statements of the witness made during the cross-examination.

The witness is not allowed to provide any new matter at this stage. The opponent's lawyer will be allowed to do a re-cross examination (option D) on any new point raised in the re-direct examination. Leading questions are not allowed in re-direct examination.

The sequence of examination in the recording of evidence is as follows -

Sequence of Examination Objective

Examination-in-chief/direct examination (options A and B) by the party that summoned the witness 

To elicit the facts of the case from the witness.

Leading questions are not allowed.

Cross-examination by the defense lawyer

To elicit facts favorable to their case and test the reliability of the witness.

Leading questions are allowed.

Re-examination by the party that summoned the witness

 To resolve doubts that formed during cross-examination and re-emphasize the party's perspective.

questions.text: A patient presented with a sudden onset of symmetrical, bilateral, tender, erythematous, warm nodules and raised plaques involving the shins, ankles, and knees, as shown below. Which of the following is the most common infectious trigger of this condition?
questions.solution:
The description is classical of erythema nodosum. The most common infectious cause of erythema nodosum is group A beta hemolytic streptococcus.

Aetiological factors in erythema nodosum:

  • Infections: Group A β-hemolytic streptococcus infection, tuberculosis, leprosy, brucella, toxoplasmosis, mycoplasma pneumonia, CMV, E.coli, yersinia, tuberculosis
  • Idiopathic, pregnancy
  • Drugs including oral contraceptives, hormonal replacement therapy, sulphonamides, and penicillin
  • Sarcoidosis, Sweet syndrome, SLE, RA, Reiter's syndrome
  • Ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease, Behcet's disease
  • Malignancy

Pathophysiology:

Erythema nodosum is the result of a non-specific cutaneous reaction to various antigens. It is postulated to be a type IV delayed hypersensitivity reaction to various antigens. 

Clinical features: The prodromal phase includes fever, joint, and muscle pains, and an alteration in general health. It is followed by the development of painful, tender, nodules on the extensor surfaces of legs. knees and forearms. It usually resolves spontaneously in about 10 days. Treatment is mostly supportive.

The image below shows erythema nodosum.

Related Pearl: Skin rashes (Erythemas)

Erythema marginatum is an evanescent, non-pruritic rash over the trunk and extremities seen in rheumatic fever.

 

Erythema nodosum is an acute, nodular, erythematous, painful eruption, occurring probably due to a delayed hypersensitivity reaction to a variety of antigens. Lesions are usually seen over the extensor aspects of the legs. Its causes include infections (tuberculosis), autoimmune (IBD and sarcoidosis), idiopathic.

 

Erythema migrans has a bull's-eye appearance (central erythema and necrosis) and is seen in Lyme disease.

 

Erythema multiforme lesions usually have a target appearance; it is mediated by the deposition of immune complexes in the superficial microvasculature of the skin and oral mucosal membrane. It is usually triggered by certain infections (herpes simplex virus) and drugs.

questions.text: A 68-year-old post kidney transplantation patient came with complaints of increased frequency of painful micturition and blood in the urine for 7 days. He was diagnosed with acute hemorrhagic cystitis. All the following organisms can be a causative agent for this condition except?
questions.solution:
Among the given options except for the Norwalk virus, all other viruses cause acute hemorrhagic cystitis in post kidney transplantation patients. Norwalk virus can cause diarrhea and vomiting, and epidemics of gastroenteritis among children.

Adenoviruses types 11 and 21 are responsible for acute hemorrhagic cystitis. They mainly affect children aged between 5-15 years and immunosuppressed adults. Patients often present with dysuria, frequency, and gross bloody urine. Nephritis occurs in recipients of hematopoietic stem cell transplants.  Hematuria subsides in 3 days and other symptoms get resolved later.  Other viruses causing similar scenarios are BK polyomavirus, cytomegalovirus, JC virus, and herpes virus.

questions.text: A patient with severe depression is scheduled for electroconvulsive therapy. A drug is to be administered for anesthesia prior to starting therapy. Which of the following is the drug of choice for providing anesthesia during this therapy?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice to provide anesthesia for electroconvulsive therapy is methohexitol.

It belongs to the barbiturate class of drugs. Barbiturates act on the GABA-A receptor causing enhancement of the inhibitory neurotransmitters and blockade of the excitatory neurotransmitters. This leads to anesthesia and sedation. They increase the duration of the opening of the receptor without changing the frequency or conductance. Barbiturates are metabolized hepatically. The exception is phenobarbitol, which is cleared in an unchanged form by the kidney.

They are used for induction and maintenance of anesthesia.

Methohexital is the drug of choice for providing anesthesia during electroconvulsive therapy (ECT). This is because methohexital is cleared faster than thiopental and takes a longer time for the accumulation and saturation of peripheral sites. It can be given as a premedication drug in pediatric patients via rectal administration.

Barbiturates are contraindicated in acute intermittent porphyria. This is because they may precipitate or accentuate acute attacks. Adverse effects of barbiturates include respiratory depression, apnea, cardiovascular depression, hiccoughs, and laryngospasm. 

Other options: 

Thiopental, propofol, and etomidate can also be used for electroconvulsive therapy. Propofol and thiopental are considered to be less effective due to shorter seizure duration. Etomidate is an acceptable alternative if barbiturates are contraindicated in the patient.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the phases of the ventricular muscle action potential as shown below. Which phase represents the closing of fast sodium channels?
questions.solution:
Phase 1 represents the closure of fast sodium channels.

Phases of the cardiac muscle action potential:

Phase 0 (Depolarization): Opening of fast sodium channels. When the cardiac cell is stimulated, the fast sodium channels(voltage-gated sodium channels) open and cause sodium influx. This depolarizes the cell and the membrane potential becomes positive. It reached about +20 mV and the sodium channels close. 

Phase 1 (Initial repolarization): Closing of fast sodium channels. The fast sodium channel close and the potassium channels open. the potassium ions leave the cell leading to repolarisation. 

Phase 2 (Plateau): Fast potassium channels close and calcium channels open. The slowly opening voltage-gated Ca2+ channels start opening in phases 0 and 1. The influx of calcium through these channels is balanced by the decrease in the efflux of potassium via the potassium channels. This produces the plateau. 

Phase 3 (Rapid repolarization): Slow potassium channels open and calcium channels close. The potassium ions leave the cell through slow potassium channels and the calcium channels close stopping the influx of calcium ions. This ends the plateau and brings the membrane potential to resting level. 

Phase 4 (Resting membrane potential):  around −80 to −90 millivolts.

questions.text: You are a biochemist working on various cytogenetic abnormality. You use the following cytogenetic technique to study the abnormality from a tissue specimen. Which of the following cytogenetic abnormality cannot be picked up by this technique?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an array - comparative genomic hybridization (CGH). This cytogenetic technique cannot detect balanced translocation.

Array-based Comparative Genomic Hybridization:

In array CGH, two genomes are compared. The test DNA and the reference DNA are labeled with two different fluorescent dyes (red and green respectively) and are added to a DNA chip spotted with the entire human genome.

  • If the contribution of both samples is equal for a given chromosomal region, then all spots on the array will fluoresce yellow.
  • If the test sample has amplification, that spot will fluoresce red
    • If the test sample has a deletion, that spot will fluoresce green

Uses of Array CGH:

  • To detect gene amplification
  • To detect gene deletion 
  • To detect copy number variations

Limitations:

Cannot detect balanced translocations. Reason being as follows:

If there is less DNA in the patient than the control for a particular probe, the a-CGH will show a deletion of material from the patient for that particular locus; if there is more DNA in the patient than the control for a particular probe, the a-CGH will show a gain of material from the patient for that locus. In a balanced translocation, there is no gain or loss of material, so the probes will show that the patient and the control have equal amounts of DNA in those translocated regions.

Other methods for molecular analysis of genetic alterations include:

  • Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH)
  • Southern blotting
  • SNP - single nucleotide polymorphisms genotyping arrays
  • Multiple ligation dependant probe assays (MLPA)

Comparison of different cytogenetic techniques:

Method Required growing of cells Detects deletions and duplications Detects balanced structural re-arrangements Detects uniparental disomy Lower limits of deletions
G Banding YES YES YES NO 5-10 mb
Metaphase FISH YES YES YES NO 40-250 thousand mb
Interphase FISH NO YES SOME NO 40-250 thousand mb
CGH Array NO YES NO NO single exon or single gene
SNP array NO YES NO SOME single exon or single gene

Related Pearl: Fluorescent In Situ Hybridisation (FISH)

It is a simple technique for the detection of specific genetic information on a morphologically intact tissue using fluorescent probes.

The fluorescent probes are added to cells usually arrested in the metaphase stage of cell division (when every chromosome is separately).

Types of FISH:

1) Chromosomal painting: Each chromosome is identified by using a different colour of the fluorescent probe, however, each chromosome does not have a unique colour. Since the fluorescent dyes are limited.

2) Multicolour FISH: 23 distinct fluorescent colours made by mixing 5 fluorophores. Thus each chromosome is identified by a unique colour. It is also known as spectral karyotyping (SKY). It offers various advantages such as

  • Detects structural and numeric abnormalities in chromosomes.
  • Detects gene amplification and subtle microdeletions
  • Maps a newly isolated gene to its correct chromosomal loci

However, this process requires prior knowledge of the genes and chromosomes.

3) Interphase FISH: It is a rapid procedure of FISH, wherein growing cells are not needed. It is used in prenatal diagnosis and in tumour diagnosis.

The image shown is of a Multicolor FISH also known as Spectral karyotyping with a unique colour to each chromosome pair.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presented to the clinic with an acute respiratory tract infection. He has a history of asthma associated with recurrent respiratory tract infections and sinusitis. Genetic testing in childhood had revealed CFTR mutations. Which of the following is likely to be decreased in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cystic fibrosis. In these patients, sperm count is most likely to be decreased.

Male patients with cystic fibrosis usually have infertility due to failure of development of Wolffian duct structures leading to congenital absence of bilateral vas deferens. There is defective sperm transport resulting in obstructive azoospermia.

The sexual function is generally unimpaired.

Option A: Sweat chloride levels are elevated (≥60 mEq/L) due to abnormalities in the CFTR protein leading to defective chloride transport. 

Option B: Serum bicarbonate levels are increased due to excessive loss of salt in the sweat resulting in hypochloremic alkalosis.

Option D: Patients with cystic fibrosis have fat malabsorption secondary to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, hence the increased stool fat.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with features of angular stomatitis and a magenta tongue. Deficiency of which of the following vitamin will result in the above features?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario presence of angular stomatitis and magenta tongue is suggestive of vitamin B2 / riboflavin deficiency.

Riboflavin (vitamin B2)

The active form of riboflavin is Flavin mononucleotide(FMN) and Flavin Adenine Dinucleotide (FAD). FMN is present in Complex I of ETC and FAD is present in Complex II in ETC.

FAD-dependent enzymes include succinate dehydrogenase, pyruvate dehydrogenase, alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, xanthine oxidase, and acyl CoA dehydrogenase

Riboflavin is synthesized in the body by intestinal flora. Dietary sources rich in riboflavin are liver, dried yeast, egg, and whole milk. Fish, whole cereals, legumes, and green leafy vegetables are also good sources of riboflavin. Riboflavin is light-sensitive. Hence riboflavin supplementation may be required during phototherapy for hyperbilirubinemia 

Clinical features of riboflavin deficiency include the proliferation of the bulbar conjunctival capillaries(the earliest sign of riboflavin deficiency) angular stomatitis, circumcorneal vascularization, cheilosis, magenta-colored tongue, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis. Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro.

Other options

Option B: Vitamin B3/ niacin deficiency leads to pellagra, which is characterized by a pigmented rash in sun-exposed areas, bright red tongue, diarrhea, apathy, memory loss, and disorientation.

Option C: Vitamin B6/ pyridoxine deficiency leads to symptoms such as seborrhea, glossitis, convulsions, neuropathy, depression, confusion and microcytic anemia.

Option D: Vitamin E is a fat-soluble vitamin and is not soluble in water. Its deficiency leads to peripheral neuropathy, spinocerebellar ataxia, skeletal muscle atrophy, and retinopathy.
